BOARD OF HEALTH
(Rep. by Ord. 572, 5-26-1999)
CHAPTER 2
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
(Rep. by Ord. 572, 5-26-1999)
CHAPTER 3
CIVIL DEFENSE
SECTION:
2-3-1: Establishment
2-3-2: Officers
2-3-3: Directors
2-3-4: Duties of Directors
2-3-5: Functions
2-3-6: Service as Mobile Support Team
2-3-7: Agreements With Other Political Subdivisions
2-3-8: Emergency Action
2-3-9: Compensation
2-3-10: Reimbursement by State
2-3-11: Purchases and Expenditures
2-3-12: Oath
2-3-13: Office
2-3-14: Appropriation; Levy of Taxes
2-3-15: Emergency Municipal Government
2-3-16: Plans Approved
2-3-17: Blackout and Air Raid Regulations
2-3-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby established a local Civil Defense organization to prevent,
minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from disaster caused
by enemy attack, sabotage, or other hostile action, or from natural disaster or
catastrophe, in accordance with the provisions of "the Illinois Civil Defense
Act of 1951", as amended.
2-3-2: OFFICERS:
The local Civil Defense organization shall consist of a Director, two (2)
assistant Directors and such additional members as may be selected by the
Director.
2-3-3: DIRECTORS:
The Directors of the Creve Coeur Civil Defense organization shall consist of
persons appointed by the President of the Board of Trustees, with the consent
of the Village Board, and they shall serve until removed, for cause, by the
same.
2-3-4: DUTIES OF DIRECTORS:
The Director shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training, and operation of the Civil Defense organization,
subject to the direction and control of the Village President, as provided by
Statutes.
In the event of the absence, resignation, death, or inability to serve of the
Director, an assistant Director shall assume his position, and the President or
any other person appointed by him, shall act as Director until a new
appointment is made, should such be necessary, as provided by this Chapter.
2-3-5: FUNCTIONS:
The Creve Coeur Civil Defense organization shall perform such civil defense
functions within this Municipality as shall be prescribed in and by the State
Civil Defense plan and program prepared by the Governor, and in addition shall
perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required pursuant to
any Mutual Aid agreement with any other political subdivision, municipality or
quasi-municipality entered into as provided by the "Illinois Civil Defense Act
of 1951", as amended.
2-3-6: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any member of the Creve Coeur Civil Defense organization may be
designated as members of a Mobile Support Team created by the State Director of
Civil Defense as provided by law.
The leader of such Mobile Support Team shall be designated by the Director of
the Creve Coeur Civil Defense Organization.
Any member of a Mobile Support Team is a municipal employee or officer while
serving on call to duty by the Governor, or the State Director of Civil
Defense, and shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties,
rights, and immunities incident to such employment or office. Any such member
who is not a paid officer or employee of this municipality, while so serving
shall receive from the State reasonable compensation as provided by law.
2-3-7: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The Director of the Creve Coeur Civil Defense organization may negotiate Mutual
Aid agreements with other municipal corporations or political subdivisions of
the State, but no such agreement shall be effective until it has been approved
by the Village Board and by the State Director of Civil Defense.
2-3-8: EMERGENCY ACTION:
If the Governor declares that a Civil Defense emergency exists in the event of
actual enemy action or attack upon the United States or the occurrence within
the State of Illinois of major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other
hostile action or from natural causes or disaster, it shall be the duty of the
Creve Coeur Civil Defense organization to cooperate fully with the State
Director of Civil Defense and with the Governor in the exercise of emergency
powers as provided by law.
2-3-9: COMPENSATION:
Members of the Civil Defense organization who are paid employees of this
Village, if called for training by the State Director of Civil Defense, shall
receive for time spent in such training the same rate of pay as is attached to
the position held; members who are not such Municipal employees or officers
shall receive for such training time such compensation as may be established by
the Village Board to justly compensate for time and expense lost.
2-3-10: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The State Treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund and
reimbursement by the State to the Village for expenses incident to training
members of the Civil Defense, compensation for services and expenses of members
of a Mobile Support Team while serving outside the Village in response to a
call by the Governor or State Director of Civil Defense, as provided by law,
and any reimbursement made by the State incident to Civil Defense activities,
as provided by law.
2-3-11: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
The Village Board may, on recommendation of the Creve Coeur Civil Defense
Director, authorize any purchase or contracts necessary to place the Village in
a position to combat effectively any disaster resulting from the explosion of
any nuclear or other bomb or missile, and to protect the public health and
safety, protect property, and provide emergency assistance to victims in the
case of such disaster, or from natural causes.
In the event of enemy caused or natural disaster, the Creve Coeur Director of
Civil Defense is authorized, on behalf of this Village, to procure such
services, supplies, equipment, or materials as may be necessary for such
purpose, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or
formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or
obligations, as authorized by "The Illinois Civil Defense Act of 1951", as
amended, or obligations, provided that, if the Village Board meets immediately
at such time, he shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed
by this Village Board.
2-3-12: OATH:
Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Creve Coeur Civil
Defense organization, shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the
following oath, which shall be filed with the Director:
"I,                  , Local Civil Defense Director of the Creve Coeur Civil
Defense Organization of Creve Coeur, Illinois, do solemnly swear (or affirm)
that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of
Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public
and private, against all enemies, foreign or domestic; that I take this
obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and
that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to
enter, and I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I nor
have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or
violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Creve Coeur
Civil Defense organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any
political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government
of the United States or of this State by force or violence."
2-3-13: OFFICE:
The Village President is authorized to designate adequate space in the Village
Hall or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the Village Board for the Creve
Coeur Civil Defense Organization as its office.
2-3-14: APPROPRIATION; LEVY OF TAXES:
The Village Board may have an appropriation for Civil Defense purposes in the
manner provided by law, and may levy in addition for Civil Defense purposes
only, a tax not to exceed five cents (5¢) per one hundred dollars ($100.00) of
the assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as
provided by "The Illinois Civil Defense Act of 1951", as amended.
2-3-15: EMERGENCY MUNICIPAL GOVERNMENT:
In the event of any disaster, herein referred to, should it be necessary or
advisable, the municipal government of the Village shall establish such seat of
government, within or without the corporate limits of this Village, or within
or without this State, and any such action taken by them, shall be as binding
as if held within the usual, designated seat of government, as provided by the
said "The Illinois Civil Defense Act of 1951", as amended.
2-3-16: PLANS APPROVED:
The Civil Defense organization of this Village and the plans, tables,
agreements, mutual aid agreements and programs, heretofore adopted and
established, are hereby approved, and any such changes as may be made and as
are authorized from time to time, as provided by law, are approved by this
Chapter. (Ord. 257, 9-16-59)
2-3-17: BLACKOUT AND AIR RAID REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Authority: In order to protect life and property in the Village from
enemy action the President of the Board of Trustees is authorized and directed
to carry out blackouts and air raid protection measures in said Village at such
times and for such periods as are authorized or ordered by the Army or Navy and
to promulgate such orders, rules and regulations as may be necessary to insure
the success of blackouts and air raid protection measures and to protect life
and property during said periods. Said orders, rules and regulations shall
include traffic movements of emergency or other vehicles, evacuation of
residents, congregation of persons on public streets and sidewalks and in
public places or buildings, but this enumeration shall not be a limitation on
the power to promulgate orders, rules and regulations governing any other
subject, persons or property which must be regulated in order to insure the
proper carrying out of any duly authorized blackout or air raid protection
measure. Practice blackouts and air raid drills may be carried out at such
times and for such periods as the President shall in his discretion deem
appropriate or necessary, but subject always to the orders and directions of
the Army or Navy and the orders, rules and regulations authorized herein.
   (B)   All orders, rules and regulations authorized by this Section for the
conduct of the general public shall be in writing and shall be available for
public inspection at the place and during the hours fixed by the President.
   (C)   Any order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the authority
conferred by this Section shall be in force and effect from the time of
promulgation until amended or repealed by the President or until repealed by
the President and Board of Trustees.
   (D)   The President may appoint for a specified time as many temporary
special police, without pay, from among residents of the Village as may be
deemed advisable for service in connection with any blackout or air raid
protection measure. During the term of service of such temporary special
police, they shall possess all the powers and perform all the duties of members
of the standing police force of the Village. Said temporary special police must
wear such identifying emblem as may be prescribed by the President and it shall
be unlawful for any said temporary special policeman to attempt to carry out
any order, rule or regulation promulgated under the authority conferred by this
Section when he is not wearing said identifying emblem.
   (E)   Any unauthorized person who shall operate a siren or other device so
as to simulate a blackout signal or air raid warning, or the termination of a
blackout or air raid, shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this Section.
   (F)   This Section is an exercise by the Village of its governmental
functions for the protection of the public peace, health and safety and neither
the Village, the agents and representatives of said Village, nor any individual
in good faith carrying out, complying with or attempting to comply with any
order, rule or regulation promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this
Section shall be liable for any damage sustained to person or property as the
result of said activity.
   (G)   Any light displayed contrary to any order, rule or regulation
promulgated pursuant to the provisions of this Section constitutes a public
nuisance, and when deemed necessary in order to protect life or property during
a blackout or air raid the police, or the temporary special police authorized
herein, are authorized and directed to enter upon any premises within the
Village, using reasonable force if necessary, and extinguish lights or take
other necessary action to make effective any order, rule or regulation
promulgated under the authority conferred by this Section.
   (H)   At all times when the orders, rules and regulations made and
promulgated pursuant to this Section shall be in effect, they shall supersede
all existing ordinances, orders, rules and regulations insofar as the latter
may be inconsistent therewith.
   (I)   This Section shall not be construed so as to conflict with any State
or Federal Statute or with any Military or Naval order, rule or regulation.
(Ord. 128, 7-15-42)
CHAPTER 4
WATERWORKS COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 572, 5-26-1999)
CHAPTER 5
FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-5-1: Commission Created
2-5-2: Members
2-5-3: Duties
2-5-4: Rules And Regulations
2-5-5: Duties Adopted
2-5-6: Removal
2-5-7: Rates Of Pay
2-5-8: Payment
2-5-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
Pursuant to action of the electors upon February 25, 1967, the Act of the
General Assembly providing for the creation of a Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners is adopted in this Village, and there is hereby created a Board
of Fire and Police Commission consisting of three (3) members appointed by the
President of the Village Board, with the consent of the Trustees. (Ord. 311, 2-
8-1967)
2-5-2: MEMBERS:
All members of the Fire and Police Commission heretofore appointed under prior
act of this Board, for the terms of their respective appointments, shall remain
in the office until the expiration of their respective terms, and all of the
acts and doings of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, heretofore
taken, are hereby confirmed and validated and all appointments taken as
strictly in compliance with their duties and the law, and all future
appointments and actions of said Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall
be in accordance with the provision of the Illinois Municipal Code and of the
amendatory act of 1965 and all amendments thereto. (Ord. 311, 2-8-1967)
2-5-3: DUTIES:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners of this Village shall make all
appointments to the regularly constituted Police Department of all offices
hereafter to be filled, except for the Police Chief, which shall be made by
appointment by the Village President acting with the advice and consent of the
Village Board of Trustees. Should a member of the Department as regularly
constituted be appointed to the office of Chief, then such member shall retain
his permanent status in the rank held at the time of such hiring to the office
of the Chief of the Department. Seniority shall continue to run while that
person is serving in the Department. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners
shall, except as to Chief officers, take all disciplinary actions, including
the discharge of members of the Department for cause, as provided by law and
the rules promulgated in matters therein contained. (Ord. 354B, 6-11-1997)
2-5-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall adopt rules and regulations
for the conduct of the duties of their office and publish the same as provided
by law. The rules and regulations approved by the Board of Trustees pertaining
to conditions of employments, as heretofore adopted and in force April 10,
1957, shall remain in full force and effect until changed by appropriate action
taken for that purpose. (Ord. 311, 2-8-1967)
2-5-5: DUTIES ADOPTED:
The duties and functions of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be
as prescribed by the Act of the General Assembly, being 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/10-2.1 et seq., State Bar Association Edition. (Ord. 311, 2-8-1967)
2-5-6: REMOVAL:
Members of the Fire and Police Commission may be removed as provided by law, as
in the case of any other appointee. (Ord. 311, 2-8-1967)
2-5-7: RATES OF PAY:
The rates of pay for members of the Board of Fire and Police Commission shall
remain the same as heretofore established by action of the Village Board and as
hereafter changed or modified from time to time. (Ord. 311, 2-8-1967)
2-5-8: PAYMENT:
Members of the Board of Fire and Police Commission shall be compensated in the
amount of ten dollars ($10.00) per meeting if each of the following conditions
are met:
   (A)   The Commissioner is present for a minimum of three-quarters (3/4) of
the meeting.
   (B)   The meeting is a regularly scheduled meeting of the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners, or, in the alternative, is a special meeting called
pursuant to sections 6(b)–(e) of the Rules and Regulations of the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners.
   (C)   Commissioners shall not be compensated for more than one Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners meeting per month. (Ord. 311-A, 9-22-1993)
CHAPTER 6
ZONING COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-6-1: Commission Created
2-6-2: Members
2-6-3: Duties
2-6-4: Records
2-6-1: COMMISSION CREATED:
A Zoning Commission for the Village is hereby created under the authority of an
act of the General Assembly of the State, entitled "Revised Cities and Villages
Act being Article 73-Zoning, Sections 1 to 10 inclusive, approved August 15,
1941, and subsequent amendments thereto".
2-6-2: MEMBERS:
The Zoning Commission shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the
President and approved and confirmed by the Board of Trustees.
2-6-3: DUTIES:
Said Zoning Commission shall:
   (A)   Recommend the boundaries of districts and appropriate regulations to
be enforced therein.
   (B)   Prepare a tentative report and a proposed zoning ordinance for the
entire Village.
   (C)   Hold a hearing thereon and shall afford persons interested an
opportunity to be heard, by publishing notices of such hearings at least
fifteen (15) days in advance thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in
the Village, which notice shall state the time and place of hearing and the
place where copies of the proposed ordinance will be accessible for examination
by interested parties. Such hearing may be adjourned, from time to time.
   (D)   Make a final report within thirty (30) days after the final
adjournment of such hearing, and submit the proposed ordinance for the entire
Village to the Board of Trustees, to be enacted with or without change, or to
be referred back to the Commission for further consideration.
2-6-4: RECORDS:
The Zoning Commission shall keep written records of its proceedings which shall
be open to inspection by the Board of Trustees at all times. (Ord. 144, 8-1-45)
CHAPTER 7
ECONOMIC AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT COUNCIL
SECTION:
2-7-1: Purpose
2-7-2: Members
2-7-3: Term Of Office
2-7-4: Procedure
2-7-5: Powers And Duties
2-7-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of the council is to plan and promote the growth and betterment of
Creve Coeur through economic and business development as well as planning
community events and activities. (Ord. 801, 9-23-2015)
2-7-2: MEMBERS:
Said council shall consist of no less than eight (8) members to a maximum of
twelve (12) members, citizens or business owners and operators of this village,
appointed by the mayor with advice and consent of the village board. (Ord. 801,
9-23-2015)
2-7-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
All members will serve a two (2) year term with terms expiring May 1 of the
second year after their appointment. All members shall serve without pay,
except that the village board if it deems it advisable may fix compensation,
from time to time in accordance with appropriation made for that purpose.
Necessary expenses in connection with the council and its functions shall be
paid by the village board in the event that those expenses are preapproved by a
vote of the village board. (Ord. 801, 9-23-2015)
2-7-4: PROCEDURE:
Immediately following the appointment of the council and the taking oath of
office, the members shall meet and organize. They shall schedule their regular
meetings for the year and give that schedule to the clerk for posting to ensure
compliance with the open meetings act 1 . Further, they shall select their own
chairman, and officers. The council's meetings shall be open to the public
(unless a meeting is specifically closed as allowed in the Illinois open
meetings act) and the council shall keep a record of its proceedings through
regularly kept and approved minutes. At least forty eight (48) hours prior to
the meeting of the council, the agenda to the meeting shall be posted by the
clerk as required by law. (Ord. 801, 9-23-2015)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
2-7-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The council shall have the powers and duties as follows:
   (A)   To recommend, plan and coordinate efforts to promote business and
economic development. Specifically, the council is charged with working with
existing businesses and property owners and reaching out to new businesses to
foster economic growth in Creve Coeur and promote the village as a location for
new business interests.
   (B)   To be aware of and willing to assist prospective business owners with
compliance with village requirements (code and zoning) so that new businesses
are viable and realistic on site plan approval.
   (C)   To recommend changes in policy to the village board that could
increase economic growth and community development.
   (D)   To develop, plan and coordinate community events within the village
that provides activities for our residents and our youth to foster a sense of
community. In this regard, the council is responsible for realistically
budgeting said events and bringing the events to the village board for
preapproval.
   (E)   To work with the zoning board of appeals to recommend amended zoning,
where necessary, in areas of the village to attract businesses and industry
according to any overarching development plan the council might suggest.
   (F)   To arrange and conduct any form or publicity relative to its
activities for the general purpose of public information and understanding.
   (G)   To cooperate with the Village Zoning Board and regional planning
commissions and other agencies or groups to further local planning programs and
to assure harmonious and integrated planning for the area.
   (H)   To exercise such other powers germane to the powers and authority
granted under authority of the act of the general assembly of the state of
Illinois, entitled "Illinois municipal code", as amended and as may be
conferred on the village. (Ord. 801, 9-23-2015; amd. Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
CHAPTER 8
ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
CHAPTER 9
ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS
SECTION:
2-9-1: Organization
2-9-2: Jurisdiction
2-9-3: Appeals
2-9-1: ORGANIZATION:
   (A)   The Zoning Board of Appeals is hereby created and established in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code, and is the
Zoning Board referred to in the Village Code. The Zoning Board shall consist of
seven (7) members appointed by the President and approved by the Board of
Trustees, one (1) of whom shall be named as Chairperson at the time of his or
her appointment. The amount of compensation to be paid to members, if any,
shall be fixed by the Village Board in its annual budget.
   (B)   All meetings of the Zoning Board shall be held at the call of the
Chairperson and at such times as the Zoning Board may determine. All hearings
conducted by the Zoning Board shall be open to the public. The Chairperson, or
in his or her absence the acting Chairperson, may administer oaths and compel
the attendance of witnesses. The Zoning Board shall keep minutes of its
proceedings, showing the vote of each member upon each question, or if absent
or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its
hearings, rulings and other official actions. No hearing shall be conducted
without a quorum of the Zoning Board being present. A quorum shall consist of a
majority of all the members. Any absent member who certifies that he or she has
read the transcript of the proceedings before the Board may vote upon any
question before the Zoning Board. A copy of every rule or regulation, every
order, requirement, decision or determination of the Zoning Board shall be
filed immediately with the Building Inspector and shall be a public record. The
Zoning Board shall adopt its own rules and procedures, not in conflict with
Title 10 of this Code or with the Illinois Municipal Code, and select or
appoint such officers as it deems necessary.
   (C)   All decisions and findings of the Zoning Board on appeal or upon
application after a hearing shall, in all instances, be final administrative
decisions and shall be subject to judicial review as provided by law.
   (D)   The concurring vote of four (4) members of the Zoning Board shall be
necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination made by
the Building Inspector or any other authorized official; to decide in favor of
the applicant upon any matter which it is required to pass; or to recommend any
amendment to Title 10 of this Code. (Ord. 882, - -2019)
2-9-2: JURISDICTION:
The Zoning Board is hereby vested with the following jurisdiction and
authority:
   (A)   To adopt rules of procedures for public hearings before the Board,
including, but not limited to, participation in the hearing, the right to cross
examine witness, present testimony and evidence, and any other relevant matter.
   (B)   To hear and decide appeals from any order, requirement, permit,
refusal, decision or determination made by the Building Inspector or any other
authorized official in carrying out or enforcing any of the provisions of Title
10 and Title 11 of this Code.
   (C)   To hear and pass upon all applications for variations from the terms
of Title 10 and Title 11 of this Code in the manner prescribed by and subject
to the standards established therein.
   (D)   To hear all applications for special use permits and report said
findings and recommendations to the Village Board in the manner provided in
Title 10 of this Code.
   (E)   To hear all applications for amendments to Title 10 of this Code, and
report said findings and recommendations to the Village Board in the manner
prescribed therein.
   (F)   To hear and decide all matters referred to in or upon which it is
required to pass under Title 10 and Title 11 of this Code or as prescribed by
the Illinois Municipal Code. (Ord. 882, - -2019; amd. Ord 962, 10-26-2022)
2-9-3: APPEALS:
   (A)   An appeal may be taken to the Zoning Board by any person or by any
office, department, board or bureau within the Village aggrieved by a decision
of the Building Inspector or other authorized official. Such an appeal shall be
taken within forty-five (45) days from the date of the action complained of, by
filing with the Building Inspector and the Zoning Board a notice of appeal
specifying the grounds thereof. The Building Inspector shall forthwith transmit
to the Zoning Board all of the papers constituting the record upon which the
action appealed from was taken.
   (B)   An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action
appealed from unless the Building Inspector or other authorized official
certifies to the Zoning Board, after notice of the appeal has been filed with
Building Inspector, that by reason of facts stated in the certification a stay
would, in his opinion, cause imminent peril to life or property, in which case
the proceedings shall not be stayed unless by a restraining order which may be
granted by the Zoning Board or the Tazewell County Circuit Court on application
of the Building Inspector and upon due cause shown.
   (C)   The Zoning Board shall fix a reasonable time and place for the hearing
of an appeal, give due notice thereof to the applicable parties, and render a
written decision without unreasonable delay. At the hearing, any party may
appear in person or by a duly authorized agent or attorney. The Zoning Board
may affirm or may, upon the concurring vote of four (4) members, reverse,
wholly or in part, or modify the order, requirement, decision or determination,
which in its opinion out to be made, and to that end shall have all the powers
of the Building Inspector. (Ord. 882, - -2019)
CHAPTER 10
CODE HEARING DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
2-10-1: Creation, Jurisdiction, And Purpose
2-10-2: Personnel And Duties
2-10-3: Notice
2-10-4: Service
2-10-5: Administrative Hearing Procedure
2-10-6: Default
2-10-7: Review Of Final Orders
2-10-7-1: Notification Of Debts Due
2-10-8: Enforcement Of Hearing Officer's Order
2-10-8-1: Interest On Fines And Collection Fees
2-10-9: Fines Payable To The Village Treasurer
2-10-10: Posthearing Motions
2-10-11: Ex Parte Disclosures
2-10-12: Waiver, Suspension Or Reduction Of Fines
2-10-13: Schedule Of Fines/Penalties
2-10-14: Severability
2-10-1: CREATION, JURISDICTION, AND PURPOSE:
   (A)   The Village hereby creates a Code Hearing Department pursuant to the
authority in the Illinois Municipal Code found at 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/1-2.2-1 et seq., allowing the administrative adjudication of ordinance
violations and 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-31.1-1 et seq., allowing the
administrative adjudication of violations of Building Code violations; as well
as the authority in the Illinois Vehicle Code found at 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-208.3, allowing the administrative adjudication of traffic
regulations concerning the standing, parking, or condition of vehicles.
   (B)   1.   Except as otherwise provided in this section, the Code Hearing
Department is authorized to conduct administrative adjudication of any
violation of the Village Code, including ordinances that establish
construction, plumbing, heating, electrical, fire prevention, sanitation,
violations of zoning, or other health and safety standards that are applicable
to structures in a municipality, or any Municipal ordinance that requires,
after notice, the cutting of weeds, the removal of garbage and debris, the
removal of inoperable motor vehicles or the abatement of nuisances from private
property.
      2.   Additionally, the Code Hearing Department is authorized to conduct
administrative adjudication of violations of any provision of title 9 of this
Code, restricting or regulating the standing or parking of vehicles or the
condition or use of equipment on a vehicle and the violation of any provision
of the Illinois Compiled Statutes adopted by reference in title 9 of this Code
that restricts or regulates the standing or parking of vehicles or the
condition or use of equipment on a vehicle.
   (C)   Pursuant to statute, the Code Hearing Department may not conduct
administrative adjudication of the following violations of the Village Code:
      1.   Any offense under the Illinois Vehicle Code or a similar offense
that is a traffic regulation governing the movement of vehicles.
      2.   Any reportable offense under section 6-204 of the Illinois Vehicle
Code.
   (D)   All fines imposed for any violation of village ordinances, including
the Building Code and any other provision of the Village Code, shall bear
interest at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum on the unpaid balance from
the date of imposition of the fine. A default in the payment of a fine and
costs or any installment imposed by the circuit court or by a hearing officer
may be collected by any and all means authorized for the collection of money
judgements. The Village may retain attorneys and private collection agents for
the purpose of collecting any default in payment of any fine or installment of
that fine. The fees and costs incurred by the Village in any such collection by
attorneys or private collection agents retained by the Village shall be charged
to the offender, provided that the amount shall not exceed thirty-five percent
(35%) of the unpaid fines and accrued interest. (Ord. 847, 1-10-2018; amd. Ord.
847B, 2-27-2019)
2-10-2: PERSONNEL AND DUTIES:
The Code Hearing Department shall consist of, upon appointment by the Mayor
with the advice and consent of the Village Board and under the direct
supervision of the Mayor, a Hearing Officer and an Administrative Assistant
(or, in the event an Administrative Assistant is not hired, the Village Clerk
shall perform the duties of the Administrative Assistant as listed below) and
any other such positions as may be approved by the Village Board of Trustees
with the powers and duties as set forth herein. Compensation for the Hearing
Officer and the Administrative Assistant (or additional compensation for the
Village Clerk for additional duties) shall be as approved by the Village Board.
   (A)   Hearing Officer Duties And Qualifications: A Hearing Officer must be,
prior to appointment, an attorney licensed to practice law for at least three
(3) years in the State of Illinois. The Hearing Officer shall have the
following powers and duties:
      1.   To administer oaths;
      2.   To hear testimony, to accept relevant evidence and to rule upon
motions and objections to the admissibility of evidence;
      3.   To issue subpoenas directing witnesses to appear and give relevant
testimony at the hearing upon requests of the parties and their
representatives;
      4.   To preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all
exhibits and evidence introduced at the hearing;
      5.   To issue a written finding, decision and order stating whether a
Village Code violation exists;
      6.   To impose penalties, sanctions or other relief consistent with
applicable Village Code provisions and to assess costs upon finding a party
liable for the charged violation, except however, that in no event shall the
Hearing Officer have any authority to impose a penalty of incarceration;
      7.   To review final determination of liability for an ordinance
violation in accordance with administrative review procedures hereinafter set
forth; and
      8.   To hold conferences for the settlement or simplification of issues.
   (B)   Training For Hearing Officers: Prior to conducting administrative
adjudication proceedings under this chapter, the Hearing Officer shall have
successfully completed a formal training program which includes the
requirements mandated by law including, but not limited to:
      1.   Instruction on the rules of procedure of the administrative hearings
over which the Hearing Officer shall preside;
      2.   Orientation to each subject area of code violations that he/she will
adjudicate;
      3.   Observation of administrative hearings; and
      4.   Participation in hypothetical cases, including ruling on evidence
and issuing final orders.
   (C)   Administrative Assistant Duties:
      1.   Receive violations from the Code Enforcement Officer and/or building
inspector, create an administrative adjudication file for each case and issue a
unique docket number to the case, set a hearing date at least thirty (30) days
from the date the violation is received but not more than forty (40) days from
the date the violation is received;
      2.   Create a proper notice and summons for the defendant as required by
law;
      3.   Have the summons and notice served on the defendant and schedule the
hearing with the Hearing Officer;
      4.   Keep accurate records of appearances and nonappearances at
administrative hearings, pleas entered, judgments entered, sanctions imposed,
if any, fines and penalties assessed and paid;
      5.   Issue succeeding notice of hearing dates and/or final determination
of liability;
      6.   Collect monies paid as fines and/or penalties assessed after a final
determination of liability;
      7.   Certify copies of final determinations of an ordinance violation
adjudicated pursuant to this chapter and any factual reports verifying the
final determination of any violation liability which was issued in accordance
with this chapter;
      8.   Collect paid fines and penalties; keep records; and issue payment
receipts;
      9.   If fines and penalties are not paid as agreed, set up payment plans
with the violators, employ a private collection agency to obtain the past due
amounts and/or direct the pursuit of all postjudgment remedies available by
law. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-3: NOTICE:
The administrative adjudication of any ordinance violation shall afford a party
due process of law. The notice charging a violation of this Code shall be
accompanied by a summons and shall contain, but not necessarily be limited to,
the following information:
   (A)   The name and address of the defendant.
   (B)   The date, time, and place the violation was observed.
   (C)   A citation for the ordinance violated.
   (D)   A description of the act or omission which violated the ordinance.
   (E)   The names of the witnesses to the violation(s).
   (F)   The signature of the person issuing the notice.
   (G)   The address of the structure where the violation is observed (if
applicable). (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-4: SERVICE:
Service of summons and the notice as listed above shall be served on the owner
of the property (if applicable) and/or the violator by first class mail or in
person with proof of service placed in the administrative adjudication file. If
the owner of the property cannot be ascertained or if service on the owner
cannot be made by mail, service may be made on the owner by posting or nailing
a copy of the violation report form on the front door of the structure where
the violation is found, not less than twenty (20) days before the hearing is
scheduled. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-5: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING PROCEDURE:
Any hearing must take place before a proper Hearing Officer.
   (A)   An attorney who appears on behalf of any person shall file with the
Hearing Officer an entry of appearance.
   (B)   The Hearing Officer may grant continuances only in cases where a
continuance is absolutely necessary to protect the rights of the defendant.
Lack of preparation by either party shall not be grounds for a continuance.
   (C)   All testimony shall be given under oath or affirmation.
   (D)   The Hearing Officer may issue subpoenas to secure the attendance and
testimony of relevant witnesses and production of relevant documents. Issuance
of subpoenas shall be subject to the restrictions contained herein.
   (E)   The formal and technical rules of evidence shall not apply to the
conduct of the hearing. Evidence, including hearsay, may be admitted only if it
is of a type commonly relied upon by reasonably prudent persons in the conduct
of his or her affairs.
   (F)   No violation may be established except upon proof by a preponderance
of the evidence (which means that the offense, more likely than not, occurred).
   (G)   Upon timely request of any party to a proceeding, any person, who the
Hearing Officer determines may reasonably be expected to provide testimony
which is material and which does not constitute a needless presentation of
cumulative evidence, shall be made available for cross examination prior to a
final determination of liability.
   (H)   The record of all hearings before a Hearing Officer shall include:
      1.   All documents presented at the hearing;
      2.   A copy of the notice of the violation or notice of the hearing;
      3.   A recording of the proceedings (either by tape recorder or digital
recorder); and
      4.   A copy of the findings and decisions of the Hearing Officer.
   (I)   Upon conclusion of a hearing, the Hearing Officer shall make a final
written determination on the basis of the evidence as to whether or not a code
violation exists. Upon issuing a final determination of liability, the Hearing
Officer shall:
      1.   Impose penalties and/or fines that are consistent with the
applicable provisions of this Code;
      2.   Issue orders that are consistent with the applicable provisions of
this Code, including, but not limited to, orders to cure or abate any
continuing violations of this Code; and
      3.   Assess costs reasonably related to instituting the hearing.
   (J)   In the issuance of the final determination of liability, a Hearing
Officer shall inform the defendant of defendant's right to seek judicial review
of the final determination in the Circuit Court of Tazewell County. (Ord. 803,
2-24-2015)
2-10-6: DEFAULT:
If at the time set for a hearing the recipient of a violation notice or a
notice of hearing, or the recipient's attorney of record, fails to appear, the
Hearing Officer may find the recipient in default and proceed with the hearing
and accept evidence relevant to the existence of a code violation and conclude
with a finding, decision and order. A copy of the order of default shall be
served in the same manner as the notice of hearing.
Within twenty one (21) calendar days from the issuance of an order of default,
a recipient of a violation notice or a notice of hearing who has been found to
be in default may petition the Hearing Officer to set aside the determination
and set a new hearing date on the basis that the failure to appear at the
hearing was for good cause. If the petition is granted, the Hearing Officer
shall serve notice of the new hearing date upon the petitioner, in the same
manner as the notice of hearing is served, no less than seven (7) calendar days
prior to the hearing date. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-7: REVIEW OF FINAL ORDERS:
A final order of a Hearing Officer shall constitute a final determination and
shall be subject to review under the Illinois Administrative Review Law. (Ord.
803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-7-1: NOTIFICATION OF DEBTS DUE:
   (A)   Any debt that arises from a Hearing Officer's order, or any other
expenses detailed in section
 2-10-8 of this chapter, or any other monies due for Village of Creve Coeur
services will be submitted for debt collection through the following process:
      1.   An original bill will be sent to the party with a due date,
      2.   If the debt is not satisfied prior to the due date, a second notice
will be sent, with any late fees applied,
      3.   If the debt is still not satisfied by the expiration of the final
due date, a final notice will be sent stating total amount owed.
      4.   In the event the debt is still not satisfied, the Village will
commence all debt collection efforts allowable under the law. (Ord. 847, 1-10-
2018)
2-10-8: ENFORCEMENT OF HEARING OFFICER'S ORDER:
Any fine, other sanction or costs imposed by a Hearing Officer's order and any
expenses incurred by the Village to enforce the order, including, but not
limited to, attorney fees, court costs and costs related to property demolition
or foreclosure, that remain unpaid after the exhaustion of, or the failure to
exhaust, judicial review of a Hearing Officer's final determination of
liability for a code violation, shall be a debt due and owing the Village. As
such, the Village may collect that debt in accordance with applicable law.
(Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-8-1: INTEREST ON FINES AND COLLECTION FEES:
All fines imposed by this Code and the ordinances of the Village shall bear
interest at the rate of nine percent (9%) per annum on the unpaid balance from
the date of imposition of the fine. A default in the payment of a fine and
costs or any installment imposed by the Circuit Court or by a Hearing Officer
may be collected by any and all means authorized for the collections of money
judgments. The Corporation Counsel may retain attorneys and private collections
agents for the purpose of collecting any default in payment of any fine or
installment of that fine. The fees and costs incurred by the Village or by
another governmental entity through an intergovernmental agreement in any such
collection by attorneys and private collections agents retained by the
Corporation Counsel or by another governmental entity through an
intergovernmental agreement for those purposes shall be charged to the
offender. (Ord. 854, 5-9-2018)
2-10-9: FINES PAYABLE TO THE VILLAGE TREASURER:
All fines and other monies paid to the Village in accordance with this chapter
shall be remitted to the Village Treasurer for deposit for the Village's
General Fund. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-10: POSTHEARING MOTIONS:
There shall be no posthearing motion practice before the Code Hearing
Department. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-11: EX PARTE DISCLOSURES:
The Village adopts and incorporates canon 3(A)(6) of the Code of Conduct of
Administrative Law Officers. Therefore Hearing Officers and other personnel of
the Code Hearing Department are required to refrain from public comment about a
pending proceeding before the Code Hearing Department. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-12: WAIVER, SUSPENSION OR REDUCTION OF FINES:
In instances where this Code calls for the imposition of a mandatory minimum
fine upon a finding of liability by a Hearing Officer, a Hearing Officer may
not waive, suspend or reduce the imposition of said mandatory minimum fine.
(Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-13: SCHEDULE OF FINES/PENALTIES:
For an ordinance violation of this Code, fine and penalties shall be as
established from time to time by the Mayor and the Board of Trustees. In no
event shall the fines and penalties exceed the amount allowed by law. (Ord.
803, 2-24-2015)
2-10-14: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter or the application of this chapter is held to
be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction,
such ruling shall not affect any other provision of this chapter which is not
specifically included in such ruling or which can be given effect without the
unconstitutional or invalid provision. (Ord. 803, 2-24-2015)
CHAPTER 11
PARK AND RECREATION ADVISORY BOARD
SECTION:
2-11-1: Board Created; Membership; Appointment; Term
2-11-2: Organization
2-11-3: Powers And Duties
2-11-1: BOARD CREATED; MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENT; TERM:
There is hereby created a Parks and Recreation Advisory Board consisting of no
less than four (4) members with a maximum of eight (8) members to be appointed
by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the Village Board of Trustees. The
members shall hold office for three (3) year terms. (Ord. 834, 3-8-2017)
2-11-2: ORGANIZATION:
One Trustee of the Village Board will serve as Chairperson. The members of the
Parks and Recreation Advisory Board shall organize by election a Co-Chairperson
and Secretary. The board shall meet at least monthly. (Ord. 834, 3-8-2017)
2-11-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   (A)   The Parks and Recreation Advisory Board shall manage the Park and
Recreation Department and shall serve as an advisory board, making
recommendations to the Village Board for the following items:
      1.   Park master planning.
      2.   Budget and financial planning.
      3.   Policies related to the use of the parks and recreational
facilities.
      4.   Fee structures.
      5.   Capital improvements.
      6.   Volunteer and employee procurement and coordination, and
      7.   Other matters as directed by the Village Board.
   (B)   The Advisory Board shall have the authority to develop and implement
recreational activities and programs without the Board of Trustees' approval,
provided such activities and programs are financially feasible. The board shall
forward a summary of the recreational programs offered at least once each
quarter to the Village Board for informational purposes. (Ord. 834, 3-8-2017)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
LIQUOR REGULATIONS
SECTION:

3-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known as the LIQUOR CONTROL ORDINANCE. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-
2018)
3-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise provides, words and phrases used in this chapter
shall be construed as hereinafter set forth, or used in the "Liquor Control
Act" of this State.
   ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes any alcohol, spirits, wine, beer, and other
vinous or malt products, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing
alcohol, spirits, wine, or beer, and capable of being consumed as a beverage by
a human being, containing more than one-half of one percent (0.5%) of alcohol
by volume; excepting those alcoholic beverages, however exempted by State laws.
   CLUB: A corporation organized under the laws of this State, not for
pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some lawful object other than the
sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used and maintained by its
members through the payment of annual dues, and owning, hiring, or leasing a
building or space in a building, of such extent and character as may be
suitable and adequate for the reasonable or comfortable use and accommodation
of its members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen
and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of
servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for
its members and their guests; provided that such club files with the Local
Liquor Control Commission at the time of the application for a license under
this chapter two (2) copies of a list of names and residences of its members,
and similarly files within ten (10) days of the election of any additional
member his name and address; and, provided further, that its affairs and
management are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or
similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting and that no member
or any officer, agent, or employee of the club is paid, or directly or
indirectly receives, in the form of a salary or other compensation any profits
from the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club, or the members
of the club or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such
salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting of the members or by its
board of directors or other governing body out of the general revenues of the
club.
   DISTRIBUTOR: Any person, other than a manufacturer, who is engaged in
purchasing, storing, possessing or warehousing any alcoholic liquor for resale
or reselling at wholesale.
   DRAMSHOP OR TAVERN: Any person who sells, or offers for sale, alcoholic
liquor for use or consumption, and not for resale.
   MOTEL-HOTEL LICENSE: Any building or buildings or other structures kept,
used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where
food is actually served and consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered
for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or
residential, in which thirty five (35) or more rooms are used for sleeping
accommodations of such guests and having one or more public dining rooms where
meals are served to such guests, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms
being conducted in the same building or buildings, in connection therewith, and
such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with
adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity. (Ord.
820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-3: LICENSES:
No person shall conduct an alcoholic liquor business, either as a dramshop or
tavern, or in any other manner in any stand, place, room, building, enclosure,
suite or rooms in the Village, unless such person shall have first secured a
license so to do, and has paid to the Local Liquor Commission the license fee
for such alcoholic liquor business, and provided further, that no such
alcoholic liquor business shall be conducted other than as provided in the
Illinois Liquor Control Act, as amended. All license fees are payable annually,
due prior to May 1st of every year and upon payment the license is good for a
calendar year. The fees for all licenses are established by the Board annually
and are on file with the Village Clerk. The following license classifications
shall be in effect:
