   (A)   Limitations On Class J And K Licenses:
      1.   The Village shall design and provide for all interested applicants
in the Office of the Village Clerk an application that describes the event's
hours, and expected attendance, the Village or library district owned property
to be used, the area where alcoholic beverages will be served, the type of
beverages to be served, who will serve the beverages, how the licensee will
prevent consumption of alcohol by minors, and proof of adequate dramshop
(liability) insurance coverage. The application shall be given to the Liquor
Commission or its designee who shall either approve or deny the application
within ten (10) working days.
      2.   The license is only valid for the specific Village or library
district owned property described in the license application and only for the
days and times as approved by the Liquor Commission or designee. Liquor may
only be served and consumed in a well-defined and designated area on Village or
library district owned property. The licensee must make sure that alcoholic
beverages do not leave the defined area.
      3.   The licensee must carry adequate dramshop liability insurance and
proof of purchase of insurance must be provided to the Village before the
event. If the licensee seeks to sell alcoholic beverages in a building or on
property owned or operated by the Village, as opposed to just serving alcohol
to attendees, the licensee must include the Village as an additional insured.
(If you are a private party, contact your homeowners' insurance provider to
determine how to obtain coverage for your event.)
      4.   A photocopy of the liquor license approval must be displayed on the
premises during any such function.
      5.   The service and consumption of alcoholic liquor shall only be
permitted on the premises and not outside of the premises. If the premises
where alcohol is to be served are out of doors (in a Village owned park), those
premises where alcohol is served must be clearly marked and alcohol may not be
removed from the clearly marked premises.
      6.   The service of alcoholic liquor must be by a person at least twenty
one (21) years of age who is an agent or employee of the licensee and the
licensee must implement measures to ensure that minors are not served alcoholic
liquors and do not consume alcoholic liquor on the premises.
      7.   No private event catered under this license shall exceed eight (8)
hours in duration and no alcoholic liquor shall be served earlier than ten
o'clock (10:00) A.M. and no later than one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
      8.   In the case of a K license for a public event, private security must
be employed by the licensee, unless the licensee is the Village itself or
library district itself, in proportion to the amount of people expected at the
event in consultation with the Creve Coeur Police Department. The cost of
security will be entirely paid for by the licensee. A K license will not be
granted without a security plan, approved by the CCPD and paid for by the
licensee.
      9.   In the case of a K license for a public event, after preliminary
approval from the Liquor Commission, the event is only given final approval
after a majority vote approving the same at a regularly scheduled and properly
noticed Village Board, or Library Board (only in the case that the library will
be used for the event) meeting.
      10.   The licensee shall comply with all applicable ordinances and State
law and obtain all applicable permits for the private catered event.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or permit the
consumption of alcoholic liquor outside of the principal building located on
the licensed premises unless the license granted by the Local Liquor Control
Commission grants such right with respect to specifically delineated outside
areas shown on the site plan provided with the licensee's application. Where
outdoor sales and/or consumption have been approved, the approved outdoor area
must be enclosed with some permanent fencing or temporary enclosure (such as
plastic snow fencing), and the licensee shall require all ingress to and egress
from the licensed premises to take place through the principal building on the
premises and not through any openings in the outdoor enclosure. (Ord. 820B, 7-
11-2018; amd. Ord. 820E, 8-28-2019)
3-1-4: ADMINISTRATION:
The Mayor shall be charged with the administration of all liquor laws. Pursuant
to 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-2, the Mayor, as Liquor Control
Commissioner, may appoint additional persons to assist him in the exercise of
the powers vested in him and in the performance of his duties as Local Liquor
Control Commissioner, and collectively the Mayor and such additional appointees
shall be referred to as Local Liquor Control Commission. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-5: POWERS OF LOCAL LIQUOR CONTROL COMMISSION:
The Local Liquor Control Commission shall also have the following powers:
   (A)   To grant and/or suspend for not more than thirty (30) days or revoke
for cause all local licenses issued to persons for premises within the Village.
   (B)   To enter or to authorize any law enforcing officer to enter at any
time upon any premises licensed hereunder to determine whether any of the
provisions of this chapter or any rules or regulations adopted by him or by the
State of Illinois or the State Commission have been or are being violated, and
at such time to examine said premises of said licensee in connection therewith.
   (C)   To receive complaint from any citizen that any of the provisions of
this chapter, or the rules or regulations adopted pursuant thereto, have been
or are being violated and to act upon such complaints.
   (D)   To receive local license fees provided for herein, and to pay the same
forthwith to the Village Treasurer.
   (E)   To hold hearing, take testimony, examine applicants and to do and
perform all acts necessary or incidental to such office.
   (F)   To levy fines in accordance with 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-5.
Whenever in this chapter the Local Liquor Control Commission is referred to,
this office shall include any committee or other person appointed by such Local
Liquor Control Commissioner acting for him. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-6: APPLICANT FOR LICENSES:
Any person desiring an alcoholic liquor license under the provisions of this
chapter shall submit to the Local Liquor Control Commission an application in
writing under oath setting forth the following information:
   (A)   The name and address of the applicant, and his age, in the case of an
individual; in the case of a co-partnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation, for profit, or a club,
the date of incorporation, the objects for which it was organized, the names
and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority in interest of
the stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name
and address of such person.
   (B)   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place (with proof) of his naturalization.
   (C)   The character of business of the applicant; and in the case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
   (D)   The length of time the applicant has been in business of that
character, or in the case of a corporation, the date on which it was chartered.
   (E)   The amount of goods and wares and merchandise on hand at the time
application was made.
   (F)   The location and description of the premises or place of business
which is to be operated under such license, together with a site plan showing
the property boundaries, the building improvements, and clearly identifying any
outdoor areas that the applicant intends to be used for outdoor sale and/or
consumption of alcoholic liquor.
   (G)   A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a
similar or other license on premises other than described in the application,
and the disposition of such application.
   (H)   A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this chapter or by State laws.
   (I)   Whether a previous license by a state or subdivision thereof has been
revoked, or by the Federal government has been revoked, and the reasons for the
same.
   (J)   That applicant will not violate any of the laws of the State of
Illinois, the provisions of this Code or the United States in the conduct of
such business.
   (K)   That the proposed location is not within one hundred feet (100') of
any church, school other than an institution of higher learning, hospital, home
for aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their spouses or children,
military or naval station, undertaking establishment, mortuary, or at any place
of business where the majority of customers are minors of school age or where
the principal business transacted consists of school books, school supplies,
food, or school lunches or drinks for such minors.
   (L)   Whether the application is for a dramshop, tavern or distributor's
license, club license or such other license as may by ordinance be provided.
   (M)   Fee for filing of said application shall be in the amount of fifty
dollars ($50.00), which is not applicable to license fee and is nonrefundable.
   (N)   All fees payable to the Clerk for said liquor license shall be applied
to such license. In the event a license is forfeited or revoked, said fee for
license is nonrefundable to said applicant and license holder. (Ord. 820D, 4-
24-2019; amd. Ord. 820E, 8-28-2019)
3-1-7: BOND:
Each person desiring a license hereunder shall be required to show that such
applicant is of good moral character and shall also execute a penal bond in the
form and with security satisfactory to the Local Liquor Control Commission,
conditioned upon the faithful observation of the provisions of the laws of the
State of Illinois, and of this chapter, relating to the alcoholic liquor
business. Such bond shall be in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and
shall, upon approval by the Local Liquor Control Commission, be filed in the
Office of the Clerk. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-8: LICENSES; HOW GRANTED:
All applications for licenses under this chapter shall be presented to the
Local Liquor Control Commission; said application shall be investigated by such
Local Liquor Control Commission to his own satisfaction, and he shall, within a
reasonable time, either approve or reject said application. Upon the approval
of such application and of the bond in amount heretofore provided, and the
payment of the license fee as heretofore specified, the Local Liquor Control
Commission shall designate in writing his order of approval and direct the
Clerk to issue a license to such applicant; such license shall also be signed
by said Local Liquor Control Commission. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-9: RENEWAL OF LICENSES:
All applications for renewal of licenses must be filed with the Local Liquor
Control Commission, in writing, containing substantially the same information
as may be deemed advisable by the Local Liquor Control Commission as in the
first application for license. All applications for renewal shall be made at
least fifteen (15) days prior to the date of expiration of said license, and
shall be accompanied by the license fee.
Any person, who shall fail to make application and pay the fee as herein
provided, shall be deemed to have forfeited and abandoned such license, and no
renewal thereof shall thereafter be permitted. Any such license so forfeited or
abandoned shall not be re-issued, and any person seeking thereafter to procure
a license shall be considered as a new applicant and shall be subject to the
limitation as to the number of licenses to be issued, as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-10: POSTING OF LICENSE:
Every person licensed in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall
immediately post and keep posted in some conspicuous place plainly readable by
the public within said premises, the said license so issued. Whenever any such
license shall be lost or destroyed, such licensee shall make application
stating the circumstances of the loss or destruction and a duplicate, so
designated, shall be issued by the Local Liquor Control Commission. (Ord. 820B,
7-11-2018)
3-1-11: PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR LICENSE:
No license of any kind shall be issued by the Local Liquor Control Commission
to:
   (A)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   (B)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (C)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the
State of Illinois.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame.
   (E)   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   (F)   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked for
cause.
   (G)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (H)   A co-partnership, unless all of the members of such co- partnership
shall be qualified to obtain a license.
   (I)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
political subdivision.
   (J)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   (K)   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or State
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the passage of the State Liquor Control Act, or shall have
forfeited his bond to appear in court to answer charges for any such violation.
   (L)   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a lease thereon for a full period for which the license is to
be issued.
   (M)   Any law enforcing public official, including members of the Local
Liquor Control Commission, any Mayor, any President of the Village Board of
Trustees, any member of the Village Board of Trustees, or other disqualified
official by reason of State law; and no such official shall have a direct
interest in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor, except
that a license may be granted to such official in relation to premises that are
not located within the territory subject to the jurisdiction of that official
if the issuance of such license is approved by the State Liquor Control
Commission and except that a license may be granted to any member of the
Village Board of Trustees in relation to premises that are located within the
territory subject to the jurisdiction of that official if: 1) the sale of
alcoholic liquor pursuant to the license is incidental to the selling of food,
2) the issuance of the license is approved by the State Commission, 3) the
issuance of the license is in accordance with all applicable local ordinances
in effect where the premises are located, and 4) the official granted a license
does not vote on alcoholic liquor issues pending before the Board to which the
license holder is elected. Notwithstanding any provision of this paragraph to
the contrary, a member of the Village Board of Trustees other than the
President of the Village Board of Trustees, may have a direct interest in the
manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor as long as he or she is
not a law enforcing public official or the Village Board President. To prevent
any conflict of interest, the elected official with the direct interest in the
manufacture, sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor shall not participate in
any meetings, hearings, or decisions on matters impacting the manufacture,
sale, or distribution of alcoholic liquor. Furthermore, the President of the
Village Board may have an interest in the manufacture, sale, or distribution of
alcoholic liquor as long as the Board over which he or she presides has made a
Local Liquor Control Commissioner appointment that complies with the
requirements of section 4-2 of the Illinois Liquor Control Act of 1934. (Ord.
820C, 11-28-2018)
3-1-12: LIMITATION ON LOCATION:
(Rep. by Ord. 303-A, 2-8-1995)
3-1-13: CLOSING HOURS:
The hours of business for such dramshop or tavern in the Village shall be as
follows:
   (A)   Class A, Class C, Class D, Class V, and Class G licenses: The closing
hour shall be at four o'clock (4:00) A.M. each morning. At the designated
closing hour, the bar or the dramshop, or in the case of a Class G licensee,
the area where alcohol is served shall be closed and all patrons or customers
shall be vacated from said place not later than fifteen (15) minutes after the
closing hour.
   (B)   Class B, Class L, Class M, Class J, Class K, and Class W licenses: The
closing hour shall be one o'clock (1:00) A.M. each morning.
   (C)   In all classes of license, the bar shall be closed at the designated
hour, herein set forth, and all customers or patrons shall be vacated from the
barroom within fifteen (15) minutes thereafter, whether their drinks have been
consumed or not. No drink shall be served after the closing hour.
No tavern holding any class of license issued hereunder shall open prior to six
o'clock (6:00) A.M., Monday through Saturday, nor before nine o'clock (9:00)
A.M. on Sundays; all times herein referred to shall be the prevailing time in
force in the Village.
For the purpose as herein used, the word "closed" shall be construed to apply
to the operation of the bar and the extinguishment of all signs. No drinks
shall be served after the closing time, above, and the whole of the licensed
premises shall be locked and vacated except for the owner, bartender and actual
employees, or a watchman.
The fact that food is being served on the licensed premises shall not affect
the closing requirements pertaining to the closing of the whole of the licensed
premises, and no intoxicating beverages may be served from the licensed
premises to any other part of those or any other premises. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-
2018)
3-1-14: SALE WITHOUT LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No person shall keep for sale, sell or offer to sell any alcoholic liquor in
the Village unless such person shall have first obtained an alcoholic liquor
license and the same is in full force and effect as by this chapter provided.
(Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-15: OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
In premises upon which a license is issued for the sale of alcoholic liquors,
other than a restaurant (principally licensed as such), hotel, club or veterans
organization, no screen, blind, curtain, partition, article or thing shall be
permitted in the windows or upon the doors, nor inside such premises, which
shall prevent a clear view into the interior of such premises from the street
or sidewalk at all times, and no booth, screen, partition, or other obstruction
nor any arrangements of lights or lighting shall be permitted in or about the
interior of such licensed premises which shall prevent a full view of the
entire interior of such premises from the street or sidewalk. All rooms where
liquor is sold for consumption upon the premises shall be continuously lighted
during business hours by natural or artificial white light so that all parts of
the interior of the premises shall be clearly visible. In the event that the
view of any licensed premises is wilfully obstructed, such license shall be
subject to revocation or suspension in the manner hereinafter provided. Windows
may be obstructed up to sixty inches (60") above ground level, outside
measurement or sidewalk level, in order to prevent small children from
observing the interior of any such dramshop or tavern. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-16: PLAN FOR PREMISES LICENSED:
The Liquor Control Commission is hereby authorized to require all persons to
whom liquor licenses are or have been issued to file plans or drawings of the
licensed premises to which such license is issued showing all of the premises
and appurtenances, rooms, basements and restrooms, necessary or advisable to
enable him to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-17: SALES TO MINORS, OTHERS:
No licensee nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of such licensee shall sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any
minor, unless that minor is a waiter or waitress who is serving the alcoholic
liquor under subsection
3-1-26(B) of this chapter, or to any intoxicated person or to any person known
to him to be a habitual drunkard, spendthrift, insane, mentally ill, mentally
deficient or in need of mental treatment. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-18: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF LICENSES:
There shall be no limit on the number of licenses of any class issued by the
Liquor Control Commission. (Ord. 830A, 7-11-2018)
3-1-19: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
The Local Liquor Control Commission may suspend or revoke any license issued
under the provisions of this chapter for any one or more of the following
reasons:
   (A)   Violations of the Federal laws, the laws of this State, including the
rules and regulations of the Illinois Liquor Control Act, or any of the
provisions of this chapter.
   (B)   The willful making of any false statement as to a material fact in the
application for a license or a renewal thereof.
   (C)   Permitting any disorderly conduct or immoral practices upon the
premises where the license is issued as herein provided.
   (D)   Permitting any person other than the licensee to operate a dramshop or
tavern under the license issued to the licensee. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-20: ADDRESS AND TRANSFER OF LICENSES:
All licenses shall be issued to a particular address and the consent in writing
of the Local Liquor Control Commission shall be required before any license is
transferable to any address other than that stated in the application for such
license. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-21: LICENSES REVOKED FOR NONUSER:
No person shall hold a license issued to an address unless such address is an
approved tavern or dramshop, and the location is approved by the Local Liquor
Control Commission as being in compliance herewith, and in addition, that such
licensee is actively engaged in such dramshop or tavern business. In the event
that a person to whom a license has been issued loses the lease to such
premises, or the same are destroyed by act of God, or by reason of condemnation
or similar proceedings, through no fault of such licensee, such licensee may
continue such class of license in effect for a period of time up to ninety (90)
days from the closing of the said business of alcoholic liquors, provided such
license fees are kept current. However, such license shall be automatically
cancelled if not placed in use by the person to whom it was issued and carried,
by consent of the Local Liquor Control Commission, within ninety (90) days from
its last use and is within such period of time actively used for the operation
of such tavern or dramshop. This provision is intended to require the licensee
to re-establish his business, closed for one of the reasons in this section
contained, and none other, within ninety (90) days or forfeit such license. Any
license so forfeited shall not be renewed or reissued, but in the event that
the number of outstanding licenses have been reduced below ten (10), then any
applicant can have such license upon application and approval by the Local
Liquor Control Commission, provided such applicant has a place of business to
actively engage in the operation of an approved tavern or dramshop. (Ord. 820B,
7-11-2018)
3-1-22: CLASS A, C, D AND G LICENSES:
Class A, C, D or G licenses shall be issued only to those locations outside of
the Residential District, and shall be issued only within the Industrial or
Business District of this Village. Applications for the Class A, C, D or G
privilege shall be submitted to the Local Liquor Control Commission and they
shall determine within a reasonable time which of the applicants should be
allowed the Class A, C, D or G privilege, taking into consideration the
character of the establishment, its location, and the interests of public
welfare; which of the four (4) of said classes of licenses is permitted to any
applicant, shall be final, and nothing shall grant any right to any licensee to
have another class of license. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-23: REVOCATION, HEARING, NOTICE:
The Local Liquor Control Commission may revoke or suspend any license issued by
him if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of
the Illinois Liquor Control Act, any State or Federal law, and/or any
provisions of this Code, or any lawful regulation established by such
commission. However, no such license shall be so revoked or suspended except
after a public hearing by the Local Liquor Control Commission with a three (3)
day written notice to the licensee affording such licensee an opportunity to
appear and defend; provided, however, that if the Local Liquor Control
Commission has reason to believe that any continued operation of a particular
licensed premises will immediately threaten the welfare of the community, he
may, upon the issuance of a written order stating the reason for such
conclusion and without notice of hearing, order the licensed premises closed
for not more than seven (7) days, giving the licensee an opportunity to be
heard during that period, except that if such licensee shall also be engaged in
the conduct of another business or businesses on the licensed premises such
order shall not be applicable to such other business or businesses.
The Local Liquor Control Commission shall within five (5) days after such
hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license shall be revoked
or suspended, state the reason or reasons in such determination in a written
order of revocation or suspension and shall serve a copy of such order within
the said five (5) days upon said licensee.
The licensee shall thereafter have such privilege of appeal to the State Liquor
Commission on the official record of the proceedings taken and prepared by a
certified reporter pursuant to 235 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/7-9 as provided
for him by law. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-24: LOCATION OR RELOCATION:
   (A)   No tavern, dramshop or place where alcoholic liquor is sold or kept
for sale shall locate (except those locations now established) or relocate
within one hundred feet (100') of any church, school other than an institution
of higher learning, hospital, home for aged or indigent persons or for
veterans, their spouses or children, military or naval station, mortuary, or
undertaking establishment. Nothing herein shall affect those locations now
established as or operated as a tavern or dramshop unless such locations are
abandoned in favor of another business.
   (B)   No tavern, dramshop or place where alcoholic liquor is sold or kept
for sale shall locate or relocate at any place of business where the majority
of customers are minors of school age or where the principal business
transacted consists of school books, school supplies, food, or school lunches
or drinks for such minors.
   (C)   Whenever in this chapter, a licensed premises is required to be
located a specific distance from a church, the distance shall be measured from
the lot line or property line of the licensed premises to the nearest part of
the exterior portion of the church used for worship or educational programs;
provided, however, that such measurement shall not apply to an exemption
granted by the Mayor as the Liquor Control Commissioner in accordance with this
section.
   (D)   Whenever in this chapter, a licensed premises is required to be
located a specific distance from school other than an institution of higher
learning, hospital, home for aged or indigent persons or for veterans, their
spouses or children, military or naval station, mortuary, or undertaking
establishment, the distance shall be measured from the lot line or property
line of the licensed premises to the lot line or property line of the
applicable use identified in this sentence.
   (E)   Notwithstanding any provision of this chapter or this section to the
contrary, the Mayor as the Local Liquor Control Commissioner may grant an
exemption for the location of a tavern or dramshop within one hundred feet
(100') of any church as authorized by section 6-11 of the Illinois Liquor
Control Act 1 , provided that no such tavern or dramshop may be located within
one hundred feet (100') of any church where such distance is measured from the
main or principal entrance of the licensed premises to the main or principal
entrance of the church, or in the case of a licensed premises located within a
building or structure that contains multiple units, measured from the main or
principal entrance of the unit in which the licensed premises is located to the
main or principal entrance of the church. In order to obtain said exemption,
the applicant must include a request for location exemption in the license
application as required under this chapter. (Ord. 820D, 4-24-2019)
 
Notes
1 1. 235 ILCS 5/6-11(a-5).
3-1-25: LIQUOR SERVICE PERMIT REQUIRED:
(Rep. by Ord. 366-B, 6-8-1994)
3-1-26: AGE OF EMPLOYEES:
The following conditions shall control the employment of persons twenty one
(21) years of age and under in establishments licensed to sell alcoholic liquor
under this chapter:
   (A)   Subject to the exceptions in subsection (B) of this section, it shall
be unlawful for any licensee to suffer or permit the employment of any person
under the age of twenty one (21) whether such person is paid or not to draw,
pour, or mix any alcoholic liquor or to serve as a cashier or check-out clerk
for the sale of any alcoholic liquor.
   (B)   Persons aged eighteen (18) through twenty one (21) may be employed as
waiters, waitresses or busboys or girls in any restaurant licensed under this
chapter. Persons aged eighteen (18) through twenty one (21) may serve beverages
containing alcoholic liquor to patrons if that beverage was poured or mixed by
an employee over twenty one (21).
   (C)   Persons aged sixteen (16) and seventeen (17) may also be employed as
waiters, waitresses or busboys or girls in any restaurant licensed under this
chapter, but sixteen (16) and seventeen (17) year olds may not serve beverages
containing alcoholic liquor to patrons under any circumstances.
   (D)   Any underage employee, aged sixteen (16) through twenty one (21) may
be employed as stock boys or girls in any grocery store or package liquor store
licensed under this chapter. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-27: FINGERPRINTING AND RECORDING OF LICENSEES:
All licensees including all applicants for licenses, shall, in addition to
furnishing a complete personal history, be fingerprinted and be subjected to a
police record check to be included as a part of their licensee's record. (Ord.
820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-28: ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR IN UNSEALED OR OPENED CONTAINERS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to possess any alcoholic liquors
in an unsealed or open container in any public place within the Village except
on the premises where the alcoholic liquor was purchased.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to carry any alcoholic liquor in
an unsealed or opened container from the licensed premises where such alcoholic
liquor was purchased.
   (C)   No licensee or person as proprietor, agent, servant or employee of
such licensee shall knowingly permit any patron to violate this section or
continue to sell alcoholic liquors to such person knowing that such person
intends to carry the alcoholic liquor from the premises in an open or unsealed
container. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
3-1-29: IMMEDIATE REPORT OF UNLAWFUL OR DISORDERLY CONDUCT REQUIRED:
   (A)   Any person licensed under this chapter shall report to the Creve Coeur
Police Department any and all of the following conduct which occurs on or near
the premises from which the licensee operates his dramshop or tavern:
      1.   Fights, disturbances, arguments or other disorderly conduct; or
      2.   Violations of any provision of this Code, State law or Federal law.
It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to report any such conduct which
comes to the attention of the licensee or any employee or agent of the
licensee.
   (B)   The report required by subsection (A) of this section shall be made
immediately after the unlawful or disorderly conduct comes to the attention of
the licensee or any employee or agent of the licensee. It shall be unlawful for
any licensee to delay reporting any such unlawful or disorderly conduct which
comes to the attention of the licensee or any employee or agent of the
licensee. (Ord. 820B, 7-11-2018)
CHAPTER 2
BILLIARDS 1
SECTION:
3-2-1: License Required
3-2-2: License Fees

1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-42-2.
3-2-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall keep any billiard table, pool table, bagatelle table,
pigeonhole table, or pool or tenpin alley, or any other kind of alley, table or
ground to be used or played upon by others for hire or gain without having
first procured a license therefor. (Ord. 15, 8-1-1921)
3-2-2: LICENSE FEES:
There shall be taxed and collected for license fees to keep such table, alleys
or grounds mentioned in the preceding section hereof, rates established by the
village board annually and published in the office of the village clerk.
Provided all applications for license under this and preceding sections of this
chapter shall be made to the trustees of the village, who may grant or reject
such applications at their discretion. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-2-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring a license under the provisions of sections
3-2-1 and
3-2-2 of this chapter shall make application, in writing, to the board of
trustees, stating therein the kind and number of tables, alleys or grounds upon
which he desires to take out such licenses, also describing the building in
which the same are to be located and the lot and block on which the building is
situated. The applicant shall also file with such application the treasurer's
receipt for the license fee as provided in section
3-2-2 of this chapter. Such license, if granted, shall be signed by the
president of the board of trustees and the clerk, and shall not be transferable
to any person without the consent of the village board; provided, the village
board may grant such licenses for a less than one year period. (Ord. 15, 8-1-
1921)
CHAPTER 3
TAXICABS 1

Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-42-6.
3-3-1: LICENSE REQUIRED-TAXICAB BUSINESS; TAXICAB VEHICLES:
   (A)   Business License: It shall be unlawful to engage in the business of
operating a taxicab in the village without first having secured a license
therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the clerk,
and shall state thereon the name of the applicant, the intended place of
business and the number of cabs to be operated. If the applicant is a
corporation, the names and addresses of the president and secretary thereof
shall be given.
   (B)   Vehicle License: No person, whether acting as owner, principal, agent,
employees, lessee or licensee, shall operate a taxicab or motor vehicle as
defined in section
3-3-2 of this code, for the carriage of persons, for hire in the village,
without first making application, in writing, for a license to do so to the
village clerk. A copy of the certificate of compliance issues pursuant to
section
3-3-3 of this Code shall be carried in the taxicab at all times while the same
is for hire. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-2: DEFINITION:
 
PERSON:       An individual, corporation, partnership, unincorporated
              association, joint venture or other legal entity.
              Any vehicle used to pick up, carry and discharge passengers for
              hire within the village, but not operating on a fixed route.
              Vehicles operated from points outside the village limits and
              entering such limits solely for the purpose of discharging a
              passenger or for picking up a passenger for transportation beyond
              such limits shall not be held to be taxicabs hereunder; provided,
TAXICAB:      however, that this term shall not include motor vehicles rented
              by special contract to be operated by the customer, or any
              vehicle operating under authority by special ordinance or
              franchise or, licensed under an ordinance licensing motor
              vehicles for the transportation of passengers or freight over a
              specific route, or railroad cars and motorbuses operating under
              the authority and jurisdiction of the Illinois Commerce
              Commission.
              Any meter instrument or device which is designed to measure
TAXIMETER:    distance driven and the waiting time and which indicates in
              dollars and cents the fare to be charged.
WAITING TIME: The period of time consumed while standing at the direction of a
              passenger. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
 
3-3-3: BUSINESS LICENSE QUALIFICATIONS:
No license to engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the village
shall be issued to or held by:
   (A)   A person who is not of good character and reputation, in the village.
   (B)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   (C)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of the
state of Illinois or of the United States.
   (D)   A person who has been convicted of other crimes or misdemeanors
opposed to decency or morality.
   (E)   A co-partnership unless all of the members of such co-partnership
shall be qualified to obtain a license.
   (F)   A corporation or other business entity, if any officer, manager or
director thereof or any stockholder(s) or member(s) owning in the aggregate
more than five percent (5%) of the stock or membership interests of such
business would not be eligible to receive a license hereunder for any reason
other than citizenship and residence within the county.
   (G)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent,
unless such manager or agent possess the same qualifications required of the
licensee.
   (H)   The president or any member of the board of trustees of the village,
and no such official shall be interested in any way, either directly or
indirectly, in the ownership or the operation of a taxicab. (Ord. 925, 2-24-
2021)
3-3-4: VEHICLE LICENSE APPLICATION; CONTENTS:
   (A)   Application: Applications for licenses for taxicabs shall be made by
the owner upon forms provided for by Village Clerk, and such applications shall
contain the full name and address of the owner, the length of time the vehicle
has been in use, the number of persons it is capable of carrying, a description
thereof, including the make, model, VIN number, and vehicle registration number
of each vehicle, as well as the principal place of business and office address
of and the names of the officers, or the person, firm or corporation owning and
operating the same, and, if a partnership, the names and addresses of each
partner, and such other information as the Chief of Police may require.
   (B)   Certificate of Compliance: A certificate of compliance shall be issued
by the Village to any taxicab passing an inspection by an authorized company
approved by the Chief of Police. Such compliance shall take place at such place
or places as may be designated by, or agreed upon, by the Chief of Police. The
certificate of compliance shall be issued upon a determination by the Chief of
Police that the taxicab and the taximeter therein, meet all the requirements of
this chapter, and said certificate shall be valid until January of the next
year following the date of issuance. At the end of that period and annually
thereafter on or prior to January 1, a new certificate can be issued upon
satisfactory re-inspection.
   (C)   Transferability: No taxicab license issued under this division may be
sold, assigned, mortgaged or otherwise transferred, without the consent of the
village.
   (D)   Suspension Or Revocation:
      1.   The Chief of Police is hereby given authority to suspend or revoke
the certificate of compliance issued under this chapter for any taxicab that
does not comply with any of the provisions of this chapter, or other ordinances
of the Village, or laws of the state. However, a certificate of compliance may
not be revoked or suspended without notice to the owner and an opportunity to
present evidence on his behalf.
      2.   No person or entity owning or operating taxicabs not licensed and
equipped in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or a taxicab, the
license of which has been revoked, or whose license is at the time suspended,
shall operate a taxicab within the Village during any such period of revocation
or suspension.
      3.   Any aggrieved person or entity may appeal any decision of the Chief
of Police made pursuant to the provisions under this chapter. An appeal may be
taken to the Chief of Police within thirty (30) days from the date of the
decision appealed from, by filing with the Village Clerk a notice. of appeal
specifying the grounds on which the appeal is based. The Village Board shall
hold a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days of its filing. At the
hearing the person or entity appealing the decision, may present witnesses and
relevant proof in support of its position. Every decision of the Village Board
pursuant to this section shall be entered and filed in the records of the
office of the Village Clerk. If a decision of the Village Board reverses or
modifies the decision of the Chief of Police, the Chief shall take immediate
action in accordance with the council's decision.
   (E)   Qualifications Of Applicant: No such license or certificate of
compliance shall be issued to or held by any person or business entity that
does not qualify for a license pursuant to Section
3-3-3 of this code.
   (F)   Fees: The annual fee payable in advance for such licenses shall be
established by the Village Board annually and published at the office of the
Village Clerk. Whenever the number of cabs so operated shall be increased
during the license year, the licensee shall notify the clerk of such change and
shall pay the additional fee within ten (10) days of such increase in number of
cabs.
   Such fee shall be in lieu of any other vehicle fee required by the
provisions of this code, and the clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers
for the number of cabs covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be
displayed in a prominent place on each taxicab while it is in use and may be
transferred to any taxicab put into service to replace one withdrawn from
service. The licensee shall notify the Village Clerk of the VIN and
registration number of each cab operated and of the corresponding municipal tag
or sticker number. A licensing fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per taxi
vehicle is required annually with a maximum amount of two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) per taxi company if the company is based in the village, and if not
based in the village, then a maximum amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
per company is required for issuance of a certificate under this chapter.
   (G)   No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a state license duly
issued; and no such cab shall be operated unless it is equipped with proper
brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror, and windshield wiper
in good condition. It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to inspect every
taxicab so often as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the
provisions of this section. Each taxicab, while operated, shall have on each
side, in letters readable from a distance of twenty feet (20'), the name of the
licensee operating it. If more than one cab is operated by a licensee, each cab
shall be designated by a different number, and such number also shall so appear
on each side of such cab.
   (H)   Inspection By The Police Department: In addition to any other
inspections that may be required it shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to
inspect taxicabs when there is a complaint from the public, or from another
police officer, or at any time the Chief determines an inspection may be
necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter. Such
inspections may be conducted by the police department at reasonable times and
places and without notice when, in the opinion of the police department, public
safety would be benefited by such an inspection.
   (I)   Standards: It shall be unlawful for anyone to operate or cause to be
operated, a taxicab for hire in this village unless such taxicab:
      1.   Bears a duly issued livery license issued by the Illinois Secretary
of State;
      2.   Is in safe operating condition;
      3.   Is equipped with properly operating brakes, lights, tires, rear
vision mirror, horn, muffler, turn signals, and windshield wipers in good
condition;
      4.   Has a clean interior of good appearance;
      5.   Has no protruding parts which could create a hazard to any person,
vehicle or thing;
      6.   Is in compliance with all laws and regulations of the state
pertaining to such vehicles and with all provisions of this chapter;
      7.   Every taxicab licensed under the provisions of this chapter shall
have plainly the name of the owner or the operating company and the number of
the cab painted or affixed in the center of the main panel of each door of each
taxicab. If more than one cab is operated by a licensee, then each cab shall be
designated by a different number, and such number shall also appear on each
side of such cab;
      8.   While in operation, the interior of each cab shall have:
         a.   The taxi driver's picture,
         b.   The taxi driver's license or registration number,
         c.   The exterior identification number, and
         d.   A telephone number for a passenger to call if the taxi driver is
operating the taxicab in a reckless manner. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-5: DRIVERS:
   (A)   No person shall drive a taxicab, or be hired or permitted to do so,
unless he has a valid Illinois Driver's License, and has a good driving record,
as determined by the Chief of Police. It shall be unlawful for any driver of a
taxicab while on duty to drink any intoxicating liquor, or to use any profane
or obscene language, to shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb
the peace in any way. A driver will be disqualified if they have, in the last
five (5) years, had:
      1.   A conviction or court-assigned supervision for driving under the
influence (DUI), or a similar provision of a local ordinance; or
      2.   A conviction in any other state for DUI or a similar offense where
the cause of action is the same or substantially similar to the Illinois
Vehicle Code; or
      3.   A driver's license suspension/revocation for violating Section 11-
501.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, except in cases where you submitted to a
chemical test(s) disclosing an alcohol concentration of .08 or more or any
amount of a drug, substance or intoxicating compound resulting from the
unlawful use or consumption of cannabis as listed in the Cannabis Control Act;
a controlled substance as listed in the Illinois Controlled Substances Act; an
intoxicating compound as listed in the Use of Intoxicating Compounds Act' or
methamphetamine Control and Community Protection Act, and were subsequently
found not guilty of the associated DUI charge; or
      4.   A conviction or court-assigned supervision for reckless driving; or
      5.   A conviction or court-assigned supervision for fleeing & eluding
police.
   (B)   The licensee shall provide a list of authorized drivers to the Chief
of Police at the time of application and will update the list when drivers are
added. The Chief of Police shall examine the driver's license status and
driving record of the driver to determine the competency of the applicant.
   (C)   The Board of Trustees may revoke the license of any taxicab business
for repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances by such business's
drivers, or for a violation of any ordinance provision regulating the conduct
of such drivers. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-6: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
   (A)   Before any certificate of compliance for a taxicab shall be issued,
the owner shall file with the chief of police a certificate of insurance issued
by an insurance company licensed to do business in the state, providing
insurance coverage for each and every taxicab owned, operated or leased by the
applicant with a minimum liability providing against public liability in the
amount of two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000.00) for the injury or
death of any person, five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000.00) for injury or
death per accident, and a minimum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for
property damage, growing out of any accident regardless of whether such taxicab
was being driven by the owner, his agent, employee, licensee or lessee. Such
policy shall further provide that insolvency or bankruptcy of the insured shall
not release the insurance company from any payment due under such policy, and
if by reason of such insolvency or bankruptcy, an execution or a judgment
against the insured is returned unsatisfied, the judgment creditor shall have a
right of action against the insurance company to recover the amount of such
judgment to the same extent that the insured could have had to recover against
the company had the insured paid the judgment such policy shall further provide
that it cannot be cancelled until thirty (30) days' notice of such cancellation
shall have been given to the chief of police.
   (B)   Unless the licensee provides another policy of insurance complying
with this section within thirty (30) days after receipt by the Chief of Police
of notice of cancellation, the certificate of compliance for each taxicab
operated by the licensed taxicab business shall automatically become null and
void, and the license to operate shall be suspended until such time as the
Chief of Police receives another policy of insurance.
   (C)   Licensees must comply with any Illinois statute requiring additional
coverage limits. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-7: FINANCIAL RESPONSIBILITY; FAILURE TO DISCHARGE:
Any certificate of compliance issued hereunder may be cancelled by the Chief of
Police at any time when for a period of forty (40) days there has not been full
satisfaction of a final judgment, of any court, against any persons for damages
sustained by third parties and arising out of the operation of the taxicab;
provided, however, that such person against whom judgment is taken is the owner
or his agent, employee, licensee or lessee. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-8: TRAFFIC RULES:
It shall be the duty of every driver of a taxicab to obey all traffic rules and
regulations established by statute or the provisions of this code. (Ord. 925,
2-24-2021)
3-3-9: UNLAWFUL USE:
It shall be unlawful to knowingly permit any taxicab to be used in the
perpetration of a crime or misdemeanor. (Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-10: DRUG AND ALCOHOL TESTING:
If a taxi driver collides with a pedestrian while operating a taxicab,
resulting in bodily injury, then any responding law enforcement officers must
test the taxi driver for drug and alcohol use.(Ord. 925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-11: PASSENGERS:
It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any
person who seeks to so use the taxicab, provided such person is not intoxicated
and conducts himself in an orderly manner. No person shall be admitted to a
taxicab occupied by a passenger without the consent of the passenger. (Ord.
925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-12: ROUTE:
The driver shall take his passenger to his destination by the most direct
available route from the place where the passenger enters the taxicab. (Ord.
925, 2-24-2021)
3-3-13: RATES OF FARE:
   (A)   No taxicab shall be operated and no license shall be issued to any
applicant pursuant to this chapter until such time as the applicant has
submitted to the Chief of Police a fee schedule which shows all fees and rates
associated with transportation of passengers for hire. The fee schedule should
be submitted annually thereafter on or prior to January 1.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any licensed operator to operate a taxicab
within the village without a proper functioning taximeter. Upon complaints by
any person that a taximeter is out of working order or does not accurately
register the lawful rates of charge, it shall be inspected and tested by been
inspected by an authorized company approved by the Chief of Police, and if
found to be in improper working condition or inaccurate, it shall be unlawful
to operate the taxicab to which it is attached until such taxicab is equipped
with a taximeter which had been inspected by an authorized company approved by
the Chief of Police and found to be in proper working condition and accurate
and a new certificate of compliance for the taxicab is issued. In the event an
operator is found to be operating taxicabs within the village with inoperable
or inaccurate taximeters on two (2) or more occasions in any twelve (12) month
period, the village may revoke the operator's license to operate taxicabs
within the village following a hearing before the village board. (Ord. 925, 2-
24-2021)
CHAPTER 4
TOBACCO PRODUCTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Definitions
3-4-2: License Required
3-4-3: Fees
3-4-4: Ownership; Display
3-4-5: Location Restrictions
3-4-6: Prohibited Sales And Delivery; Signs
3-4-7: Minimum Age To Sell
3-4-8: Certain Free Distributions Prohibited
3-4-9: Vending Machines; Locking Devices
3-4-10: Acts And Omissions
3-4-11: Suspension; Revocation Of License; Fines; Costs
3-4-12: Use Of Premises After Revocation
3-4-13: Purchase By Minors; Fines
3-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them:
   TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping
tobacco.
   VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic self-service device
which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
tobacco products. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give
away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away
or delivering, tobacco products within the village without having first
obtained a tobacco dealer's license therefor pursuant to this chapter.
   (B)   Application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the
village clerk. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-3: FEES:
The annual license fee for a tobacco dealer's license shall be for each vending
machine or for each location where tobacco products are sold and dispensed. The
fee shall be established by the village board annually and published in the
office of the village clerk.
   (A)   However, one license only shall be required where tobacco products are
dispensed in a place of business having more than one checkout counter in that
individual business.
   (B)   Also, where tobacco products are sold and dispensed at a checkout
counter or counters and by vending machine, said machine shall be required to
pay an annual fee and an annual fee will be required for the sale of tobacco
products over checkout counter or counters even though located within the same
business operation. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-4-4: OWNERSHIP; DISPLAY:
   (A)   Ownership: The license shall be issued to the owner or proprietor of
the place or building in which the tobacco products are sold or dispensed.
   (B)   Display: The license or a copy thereof shall be displayed upon each
machine from which tobacco products are dispensed, and a valid license for the
sale of tobacco products shall be displayed at the place where the same are
sold over the counter. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-5: LOCATION RESTRICTIONS:
No license shall be issued for the sale at retail of any tobacco products
within one hundred feet (100') of any school, childcare facility or other
building used for educational or recreational programs for persons under the
age of eighteen (18). This prohibition shall not apply to the renewal of any
existing license. The distance of one hundred feet (100') shall be measured
from the main or principal entrance of the licensed premises to the main or
principal entrance of the school, childcare facility or other building used for
educational or recreational programs for persons under the age of eighteen
(18). (Ord. 874, 4-24-2019)
3-4-6: PROHIBITED SALES AND DELIVERY; SIGNS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person, including any licensee, to sell,
offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products to any person under the
age of eighteen (18) years.
   (B)   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein
shall be posted by every licensee at or near every display of tobacco products
and on or upon every vending machine which offers tobacco products for sale.
Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state:
THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE IS
PROHIBITED BY LAW.
The text of such signs shall be in red letters on a white background, said
letters to be at least one inch (1") high. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-7: MINIMUM AGE TO SELL:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any officer, associate, member,
representative, agent or employee of such licensee, to engage, employ or permit
any person under eighteen (18) years of age to sell tobacco products in any
licensed premises. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-8: CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling
or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, or any
employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such
licensee's or person's business, or any other person, to distribute, give away
or deliver tobacco products free of charge to any person in any right-of-way,
park, playground or other property owned by the Village, or any property owned
by any school district, park district or public library. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-9: VENDING MACHINES; LOCKING DEVICES:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give
away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or
delivering tobacco products by the use of a vending machine, unless such
vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking
device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons
under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   (B)   Any premises where access by persons under the age of eighteen (18)
years is prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of
the business located at such premises shall be exempt from the requirements of
subsection (A) of this section. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-10: ACTS AND OMISSIONS:
Every act or omission of whatever nature, constituting a violation of any of
the provisions of this chapter by any officer, director, manager or other agent
or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such
licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such
act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. (Ord. 89A,
1-13-1999)
3-4-11: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FINES; COSTS:
   (A)   The Mayor shall be charged with the administration of this chapter.
The Mayor may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provisions of this
chapter, if the Mayor determines that the licensee has violated any of the
provisions of this chapter. In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license,
the Mayor may instead levy a fine on the licensee of not less than fifty
dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   (B)   However, no license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee
shall be fined except after a hearing with the Mayor with a seven (7) day
written notice to the licensee affording the licensee an opportunity to appear
and defend against the charges contained in such notice. The seven (7) day
notice provision shall begin the day following delivery by certified mail or by
personal service.
   (C)   The mayor shall, within seven (7) days after such hearing, if the
mayor determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or
suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such
determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period
of suspension or that the license has been revoked and serve a copy of such
order upon the licensee within fourteen (14) days after such hearing.
   (D)   Any licensee determined by the mayor to have violated any of the
provisions of this chapter shall pay to the village the costs of the hearing
before the mayor on such violation. The mayor shall determine the costs
incurred by the village for said hearing, including, but not limited to: court
reporter fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorney fees, the cost of
preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses
incurred by the village or such lesser sum as the mayor may allow.
   (E)   The licensee shall pay said fine and/or costs to the village within
thirty (30) days of notification of the costs by the mayor. Failure to pay said
costs within thirty (30) days of notification is a violation of this chapter
and may be cause for license suspension, revocation, levy of a fine or other
civil remedy. (Ord. 575-A, 1-23-2002)
3-4-12: USE OF PREMISES AFTER REVOCATION:
When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be
granted to said licensee for the period of six (6) months thereafter for the
conduct of the business of selling "tobacco products" as defined in section
3-4-1 of this chapter. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
3-4-13: PURCHASE BY MINORS; FINES:
   (A)   False Identification: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of eighteen (18) years to purchase tobacco products, or to misrepresent his
or her identity or age, or to use any false or altered identification for the
purpose of purchasing tobacco products.
   (B)   Possession By A Minor: It shall be unlawful for any person under the
age of eighteen (18) years to possess any tobacco products; provided that the
possession by a person under the age of eighteen (18) years under the direct
supervision of the parent or legal guardian of such person in the privacy and
confines of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited.
   (C)   Fine: Any person who violates any provision of this section shall be
subject to the following fines:
      1.   Twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense;
      2.   Fifty dollars ($50.00) for a second offense and subsequent offenses
within a twelve (12) month period.
The twelve (12) month period shall be measured from the date of conviction of
any offense. (Ord. 89A, 1-13-1999)
CHAPTER 5
PAWNBROKERS, SECONDHAND DEALERS, JUNK DEALERS, AND GARAGE SALES
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definitions
3-5-2: License Required
3-5-3: Exemptions
3-5-4: Application
3-5-5: Investigation
3-5-6: Issuance
3-5-7: License Fee; Transferability And Posting
3-5-8: License Revocation
3-5-9: Bond
3-5-10: Records Required
3-5-11: Records Inspections
3-5-12: Memorandum To Be Given By Pawnbroker And Secondhand Dealers
3-5-13: Report To Police
3-5-14: Removal Or Redemption Of Pledged Property
3-5-15: Hours Of Business
3-5-16: Minors, Taking Pledges From
3-5-17: Minors, Employing
3-5-18: Taking Pledges From Thieves, Etc.
3-5-19: Display Of Certain Weapons
3-5-20: Garage Sales
3-5-20-1: Garage Sale Signs
3-5-20-2: Limitation Of Garage Sales
3-5-20-3: Penalty
3-5-20-4: Exception
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
   JUNK DEALER: Any person who shall keep a junk shop or store or junkyard or
place for the purchase, sale or exchange of junk, wire or sheet material; old
iron, brass, copper, tin, or lead; junk motor vehicles (wrecked, damaged,
disabled or inoperable motor vehicles) or parts thereof, old appliances, glass,
plastic, plastic or paper bags, bottles or any articles or things composed of
or consisting of any combination of any one or more of the materials or
articles listed in this section.
   PAWNBROKER: Any person who loans money on deposit or pledge of personal
property, or who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition of
selling the same back at a stipulated price, or who publicly exhibits a sign of
"Money To Loan On Personal Property, Or Deposit Or Pledge", is hereby declared
to be a pawnbroker. A pawnbroker may also be a secondhand dealer, but does not
have to be a secondhand dealer if they do not also meet the definition herein.
   SECONDHAND DEALER: Any person which operates a business for profit which
buys, sells, possesses on a consignment for sale or trades jewelry, stamps,
electronic equipment or any precious metals or stones which have been
previously owned by a consumer, or which derives more than thirty five percent
(35%) of its gross receipts from the sale, consignment for sale, pledge or
trade of any goods, wares or merchandise which have previously been owned by a
consumer, including, but not limited to, cellular phones, appliances,
televisions, automobile parts and accessories, metals, whether in bulk or
manufactured state, computers, computer parts or equipment, video/camera/stereo
parts or equipment, electronic video consoles and games, videos, music, musical
instruments, collectibles and memorabilia, sporting goods, bicycles, motorized
tools/vehicles, collectible artwork, firearms, including their accessories and
ammunition.
The term "secondhand dealer" also includes "junk dealer" as defined herein, but
shall not include pawnbrokers (who are not also selling secondhand goods within
the village), coin dealers, providers of commercial mobile services, as defined
in 47 USC 33d(d), retail merchants that do not purchase previously owned items
directly from the public at the retail location, or any of the exemptions
listed in section
3-5-3 of this chapter. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall exercise or carry on the business of pawnbroker or secondhand
dealer without being duly licensed by the village clerk after completing the
application process as explained in section
3-5-4 of this chapter. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-3: EXEMPTIONS:
The following are exempt from the requirements of this chapter and are
specifically not secondhand dealers:
   (A)   Garage sales, which are bound by the requirements listed in section
3-5-20 of this chapter;
   (B)   Sales conducted by governmental, civic, patriotic, fraternal,
educational, religious, or benevolent organizations which have been in active
and continuous existence for at least one year prior to holding a sale, or
which are incorporated as a not for profit corporation by the state;
   (C)   Antique dealers who derive seventy five percent (75%) of their gross
sales each year from the sale of "antiques" and/or "primitives" which are
defined as an old and valuable art object or article no longer in production
which is at least fifty (50) years old. The term "sale" as used herein does not
include an exchange, trade or swap of items;
   (D)   Sales of furniture, clothing, homemade crafts and/or books and
magazines;
   (E)   Consumer shows or exhibitions of collectibles, other than a show or
convention that offers to buy secondhand jewelry from attendees;
   (F)   Auctioneers;
   (G)   Coin dealers who are primarily engaged in the business of buying and
selling coins because of their numismatic value; and
   (H)   Providers of commercial mobile services or their authorized dealers.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-4: APPLICATION:
An application for license as required by section
3-5-2 of this chapter shall be made in writing to the village of Creve Coeur's
clerk which shall set forth the following:
   (A)   The name of the individual, partnership, corporation or association
applying for a license.
   (B)   The residence, phone number, date of birth and driver's license number
of the applicant or partners; or, if a corporation or association, the
residence, phone number and driver's license number of the officers and all
shareholders owning more than five percent (5%) of the outstanding shares of
stock.
   (C)   The location for which the license is required.
   (D)   Whether the applicant, its partners, officers, or listed shareholders
have been convicted of any criminal offense or ordinance violation (other than
traffic or parking offenses) in any jurisdiction, and, if so, a list of such
convictions with date and prosecuting jurisdiction.
   (E)   Whether the applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders
have held a license or had an interest in a license issued by the village or
any other jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property
revoked for cause, and, if so, list the date of revocation and the
jurisdiction.
   (F)   Whether the applicant desires to deal in, or buy or sell or otherwise
display firearms, derringers, bowie knives, dirks or other deadly weapons (and
if so, if the applicant possesses a valid and current license or permit
pursuant to federal and/or state law pertaining to the buying or selling of
such items, and if so, the applicant shall furnish a copy of the same to the
village). (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-5: INVESTIGATION:
Upon receipt of an application for license and the fee for such license paid in
full (fee is explained in section
3-5-7 of this chapter) which will be paid in full whether or not the license is
issued under section
3-5-6 of this chapter, the village shall cause a copy of the license to be sent
to the police department, the village board and the building inspector. The
police department and building inspector shall report back to the village clerk
in fifteen (15) days whether or not the applicant meets the requirements for
issuance listed under section
3-5-6 of this chapter. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-6: ISSUANCE:
Upon receipt of the report from the police department and the building
inspector, and any comments from the members of the village board, the clerk
shall issue the license requested unless:
   (A)   The applicant is under the age of eighteen (18) years.
   (B)   The location requested is not in a permanent structure.
   (C)   The location requested is not zoned properly for use in accordance
with this section.
   (D)   The location requested is not in compliance with basic building codes
and the life safety codes of the village.
   (E)   The applicant, its partners, officers, or listed shareholders have
been convicted of or have plead guilty to any offense related to theft,
burglary, or purchasing or receiving stolen items under the laws of this state,
village or any other jurisdiction within the past ten (10) years, or have
forfeited a bond to appear in court to answer for charges for such offenses
during the past ten (10) years.
   (F)   The applicant, its partners, officers or listed shareholders have held
a license or had an interest in a license issued by the village or any other
jurisdiction regulating the purchase or sale of secondhand property that was
revoked for cause.
   (G)   The applicant, its partners, officers, or listed shareholders have
knowingly furnished false or misleading information or withheld relevant
information on any application for a license required by this chapter or any
investigation into any application, or
   (H)   In the case of an applicant who desires to deal in or buy or sell or
display firearms, derringers, bowie knives, dirks or other deadly weapons, the
applicant, its partners, officers, or listed shareholders have been convicted
of or had pled guilty to any offense related to the unlawful possession, sale
or delivery of firearms or other deadly weapons. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-7: LICENSE FEE; TRANSFERABILITY AND POSTING:
Every applicant for a license to be a pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall,
before the same is issued, pay to the village treasurer the current license fee
amount as is established annually by the village board and published at the
office of the village clerk. Payment of the license fee is good for the term or
period of one year and such license shall not be transferable to any person or
persons, except upon the written consent of the village clerk endorsed
specifically on the license.
The license issued shall, at all times during the period for which it is
effective, be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the principal entrance
to the premises for which the license is issued. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-8: LICENSE REVOCATION:
It shall be the duty of all members of the police force to report to the
village clerk any failure of a license holder under this section to comply with
provisions of this chapter, or any convictions of any offense related to theft,
burglary, or purchasing or receiving stolen items under the laws of this state,
or any convictions of any offense related to the unlawful possession, sale or
delivery of firearms or other deadly weapons. Upon such report, the village
board may revoke the license of any person who shall be convicted of a
violation of any provision of this chapter, whether such judgment of conviction
shall have been appealed from or not. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-9: BOND:
Every person so licensed as required by this chapter shall, at the time of
receiving such license, give bond with two (2) or more sureties, to be approved
by the village attorney, in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00),
conditioned for the due observance of all ordinances of the village, or that
may be passed during the term for which such license is granted. (Ord. 807, 3-
9-2016)
3-5-10: RECORDS REQUIRED:
Every pawnbroker shall keep a book in which shall be plainly written in ink, at
the time of each loan, an accurate account and description, in the English
language, of the goods, articles or things pawned or pledged, the amount of
money loaned thereon, the time and date of pledging the same, the rate of
interest to be paid on such loan, and the name and residence of the person
pawning or pledging such goods, articles or things. No such entry made in the
book shall be erased, obliterated or defaced. Every secondhand dealer shall
keep a similar book showing the description of the goods, articles or things
purchased, the time and date of purchase, the amount paid and the name and
residence of the person from whom the goods, articles or things were purchased.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-11: RECORDS INSPECTIONS:
The book required by this chapter as well as every article, or other thing of
value pawned, pledged or purchased shall, at all reasonable times, be open to
the inspection of the village president or any member of the police force.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-12: MEMORANDUM TO BE GIVEN BY PAWNBROKER AND SECONDHAND DEALERS:
Every pawnbroker and secondhand dealer shall, at the time of each loan or
purchase, deliver to the person pawning, pledging or selling of any goods,
articles or thing, a memorandum or note signed by him containing the substance
of the entry required to be made in his book by the preceding section; also
giving the location of his place of business in the village. No charge shall be
made or received by any pawnbroker or secondhand dealer or keeper of a loan
office for any such entry, memorandum or note. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-13: REPORT TO POLICE:
It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this chapter, to make out
and deliver to the chief of police every day, before the hour of twelve o'clock
(12:00) noon, a legible and correct copy from the record book required in
section
3-5-10 of this chapter, of all personal property and other valuable things
received during the preceding day, together with the time, meaning the hour,
when received and a description of the person who pledged or from whom the same
were purchased. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-14: REMOVAL OR REDEMPTION OF PLEDGED PROPERTY:
No personal property received on deposit, pledged or purchased by any
pawnbroker or secondhand dealer, shall be sold or permitted to be redeemed or
removed from the place of business of such licensed person for the space of
forty eight (48) hours after the copy of the statement required to be delivered
to the chief of police shall have been delivered as required by the preceding
section. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-15: HOURS OF BUSINESS:
No person licensed under this chapter shall receive, deposit, pledge or
purchase any personal property, or other valuable thing, before the hour of six
o'clock (6:00) A.M., nor after the hour of eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. during the
months of January, February, March, April, October, November and December of
each year; nor before the hour of five o'clock (5:00) A.M. nor after the hour
of nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. during the months of May, June, July, August and
September of each year. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-16: MINORS, TAKING PLEDGES FROM:
No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall take or receive in pawn or pledge, for
money loaned or purchase, any property, bonds, notes, securities, article or
valuable thing from any minor, or the ownership of which is claimed by any
minor, or which may be in the possession or under the control of any minor.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-17: MINORS, EMPLOYING:
No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall employ any person under sixteen (16)
years of age, to take pledges in pawn or purchase junk or secondhand items.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-18: TAKING PLEDGES FROM THIEVES, ETC.:
No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall take any article in pawn or purchase
any article from any person appearing to be intoxicated, nor from any person
known to be a notorious thief, or to have been convicted of theft or burglary.
(Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-19: DISPLAY OF CERTAIN WEAPONS:
No pawnbroker or secondhand dealer shall show, display or exhibit any pistol,
revolver, derringer, bowie knife, dirk or other weapon of like character which
can be concealed on the person, in any show window or in or on any premises
immediately abutting upon any public way in the village in such a way that the
same may be seen from such public way. (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016)
3-5-20: GARAGE SALES:
3-5-20-1: GARAGE SALE SIGNS:
Garage Sale signs shall not be located on private property without the consent
of the property owner. Signs posted away from the sale location can be placed
up to (three) 3 days prior to the sale and must be removed within twenty-four
(24) hours of the conclusion of the sale. Signs must not impair the view of
motorists in regard to traffic safety or otherwise create a hazardous or unsafe
condition. (Ord. 957, 6-22-2022)
3-5-20-2: LIMITATION OF GARAGE SALES:
No person shall be permitted to conduct a house or garage sale from his or her
premises or participate in a garage or house sale conducted on another
residence more than three (3) times during any calendar year.
Under no circumstances shall the duration of any single house or garage sale
permitted under this section 3-5-20 last for more than three (3) full days.
