(Ord. 957, 6-22-2022)
3-5-20-3: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any provision of this section
3-5-20, shall, upon conviction, be fined a minimum of two hundred dollars
($200.00) and a maximum of five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord. 807, 3-9-2016;
amd. Ord. 957, 6-22-2022)
3-5-20-4: EXCEPTION:
The entirety of this section
3-5-20 shall not apply to bankruptcy, estate, auctioneer or other sales under
judicial process and temporary sales conducted at church, school or municipal
buildings by nonprofit religious, civic or charitable organizations. (Ord. 807,
3-9-2016; amd. Ord. 957, 6-22-2022)
CHAPTER 6
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE COMPANIES
SECTION:
3-6-1: Tax Imposed
3-6-2: Accounting
3-6-3: Failure to Pay
3-6-4: Violation
3-6-1: TAX IMPOSED:
Any corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of the
State, which is engaged in the Village in effective fire insurance, shall pay
to the Treasurer, for the maintenance, use and benefit of the Fire Department
of the Village, a sum of money equal in amount to two percent (2%) of the gross
receipts received for premiums by any and all agents of any such corporation,
company or association during the year ending on every July 1, for any
insurance affected or agreed to be effected in said Village by or with any such
corporation, company or association during such year 1 .
 
Notes
1 1. For statute authority see S.H.A. 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1.
3-6-2: ACCOUNTING:
Every person who shall act in the Village as agent or otherwise for or on
behalf of any such corporation, company or association shall on or before July
15 of each and every year, render to the Treasurer a full, true and just
account verified by his oath, of all premiums which during the year ending on
July 1 preceding such report, shall have been received by him, or by any other
person for him in behalf of any such corporation, company or association, and
shall specify in said report the amounts received for fire insurance. Such
agent shall also at the time of rendering the aforesaid report, pay to the
Treasurer the sum of money for which such corporation, company or association
represented by him is chargeable by virtue of the provisions of this Chapter.
3-6-3: FAILURE TO PAY:
The sum or sums of money for which such corporation, company or association is
so chargeable may be recovered of it, or its agent or agents, by an action in
the name of and for the use of the Village, as for money had and received.
Nothing in this Section shall be held to exempt any corporation, company or
association, or agent of the same, from indictment and conviction under the
provisions of an Act entitled: "An Act to Enable Cities, Towns, Villages and
Fire Protection Districts, organized under any General or Special Law, to Levy
and Collect a Tax or License Fee from Foreign Fire Insurance Companies for the
Benefit of Organized Fire Departments", as amended by Act approved July 13,
1939.
No insurance broker or agent in the Village shall place any insurance with any
corporation, company or association not incorporated under the laws of this
State, which shall be in default for not reporting or making payment of fees as
hereinbefore provided, until it shall have complied with all the requirements
of this Chapter.
3-6-4: VIOLATION:
It shall hereafter be unlawful for any corporation, company or association to
engage in or transact any business of fire insurance in said Village while in
default by not complying with any of the requirements of this Chapter, and
until such requirements shall have been fully complied with; but this provision
shall not relieve any corporation, company or association from the payment of
any risk that may be undertaken in violation of this Chapter. (Ord. 110, 1-17-
40)
CHAPTER 7
AMUSEMENTS; ENTERTAINMENTS
SECTION:
3-7-1: License Required
3-7-2: Types Of Amusements Needing Licensure And Requiring Fee Payment To
Village Clerk
3-7-3: Applications For Licenses
3-7-4: Clerk's Duties
3-7-5: Revocation Of Licenses
3-7-6: Assignment Of Licenses
3-7-7: Record Of Licenses
3-7-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to be engaged in, or carry on, any business
occupation or pursuit hereinafter mentioned, within the corporate limits of the
village without having first obtained a license therefor in the manner
hereinafter provided. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
3-7-2: TYPES OF AMUSEMENTS NEEDING LICENSURE AND REQUIRING FEE PAYMENT TO
VILLAGE CLERK:
Auctioneer licenses are available per day, per week or annually.
Carnivals require a license for each day in operation.
Circuses require a license for each day in operation.
Huckster stands require a license for each day in operation.
Menageries require a daily license whether or not the show is part of a circus
(although menageries as part of a circus pay a lesser fee amount).
Shooting galleries require a license for either daily or annual operation.
Sideshows require a license for each day in operation whether or not the show
is part of a circus (although sideshow performances as part of a circus pay a
lesser fee amount).
All license fees as necessary herein are established annually by the village
board and published in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-7-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
Any person desiring a license for any purpose under the provisions hereof shall
make application therefor in writing to the clerk, stating therein the purpose
for which the license is desired, and for what length of time, and the place
where the business is to be carried on. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
3-7-4: CLERK'S DUTIES:
The clerk shall receive all applications for licenses, and when properly made,
may grant the same, but he may refer any application for license to the
president and board of trustees for action thereon; provided, no license shall
be granted for a longer period than the end of the municipal year in which it
is granted. All licenses shall be signed by the president and attested to by
the clerk, who shall attach the corporate seal thereto. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
3-7-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
All licenses granted shall be subject to all the provisions of this code
relating thereto, which may be in force at the time, or which may be enacted
thereafter, and any person violating any of the provisions of this code
relating to the business so licensed, may be not only prosecuted for such
violation, but his license shall, on conviction under such prosecution be
revoked, and forfeited, in the discretion of the president and board of
trustees of the village. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
3-7-6: ASSIGNMENT OF LICENSES:
No license shall be assignable or transferable, nor shall any person be
authorized to do business, or act under such license, but the person to whom it
is issued, nor shall such business be carried on under such license at any
other place than the one named in such license, without the consent of the
president and board of trustees of the village. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
3-7-7: RECORD OF LICENSES:
The clerk shall keep a license register in which he shall enter the date,
number, purpose for which license is issued, to whom issued, amount paid and
date of expiration of license. (Ord. 9, 9-2-1924)
CHAPTER 8
PEDDLERS 1
SECTION:
3-8-1: Definitions
3-8-2: Peddler's License Required
3-8-3: License Requirements
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5.
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
The village defines "peddlers" as "solicitors" and "transit merchants". Every
person who shall sell, peddle or offer to sell or for sale, or solicit, barter,
or exchange any services, goods, foodstuffs, wares, magazines, materials, or
merchandise, traveling from place to place in, along or upon any street, alley
or public place of this village, or who shall sell or deliver from any vehicle,
shall be known as a solicitor/peddler. A person who sells, peddles or offers to
sell or for sale or solicits, barters, or exchanges any services, goods,
foodstuffs, wares, magazines, materials or merchandise from a temporary stand
or stall in the village, whether to regular customers or not, shall be deemed a
"transit merchant". Both "solicitors" and "transit merchants" are known as a
"peddler".
Girl Scouts, Boy Scouts and schoolchildren who attend local district schools
who are raising funds for extracurricular or other school and local activities
and/or charities are specifically not defined as peddlers and are exempt from
these requirements. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-8-2: PEDDLER'S LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of a peddler
without a license. Licenses for peddlers are available in the following
categories and for the following terms:
   (A)   Solicitor's license: Available for a daily or annual fee.
   (B)   Transit merchant's license: Available for a daily, monthly or annual
fee.
   (C)   Pushcart/food vendor's license: Available for a daily, monthly or
annual fee. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-8-3: LICENSE REQUIREMENTS:
The clerk shall grant licenses as required in section
3-8-2 of this chapter, either on a daily or annual basis upon application. The
license fee is established annually by the village board and published in the
office of the village clerk.
Pushcart/food vendors, specifically, must meet all requirements of the Tazewell
County health department. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
Said license shall not be transferable. License fees may be waived for
charitable organizations with the approval of the mayor and village board.
(Ord. 242B, 4-28-1999)
CHAPTER 9
THEATERS
SECTION:
3-9-1: License Required
3-9-2: Applications
3-9-3: Fees
3-9-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall hereafter be unlawful to conduct or present any theatrical show,
motion picture, exhibition or other public shows, without first having obtained
a license therefor, as in this chapter provided; provided, however, that this
chapter shall not apply to local talent or school shows or theatricals. (Ord.
150, 3-20-1946)
3-9-2: APPLICATIONS:
Applications for such license shall be made to the clerk in writing and shall
state thereon the name of the applicant and the intended place of business. If
the applicant is a corporation, names and addresses of the president and
secretary thereof shall be given. Such application shall also designate the
nature and type of the theatrical or show, and each application shall be
accompanied by the payment of the fee required, and no license shall be issued
until the fee is paid. (Ord. 150, 3-20-1946)
3-9-3: FEES:
The fee for such license per day shall be established annually by the village
board and published at the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
CHAPTER 10
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
3-10-1: Terms Defined
3-10-2: License Required
3-10-3: License Fee
3-10-4: Minors
3-10-5: View
3-10-6: Application For License
3-10-7: Inspection
3-10-8: Revocation Of License
3-10-9: Coin Operated Musical Instruments
3-10-1: TERMS DEFINED:
   (A)   The term "mechanical amusement device" is hereby defined to be any
machine which upon the insertion of a coin or slug operates or may be operated
as a game or contest of skill or amusement of any description, and which
contains no automatic payoff device for the return of money, coins, checks,
tokens or merchandise, or which provides for no such payoff by any other manner
or means, or which awards free plays according to an indicator on said device,
and which said device in itself does not constitute a gambling device. The term
"mechanical amusement device" shall also include any machine or apparatus which
is used or may be used as a game of skill or amusement and in which the player
propels any ball or other device by any force exerted by himself or in which
the player uses or directs any force generated by the device itself.
Shuffleboards are excepted from the provisions of this chapter.
"Mechanical amusement devices" also means "noncoin operated amusement devices"
operated in the manner of a slot machine, but without a slot for the insertion
of coins to operate said machine and without receptacle in said machine for
making payment by reason of certain arrangements on the wheels on said machine,
and which said device is commonly referred to as a "slotless slot machine".
(Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-10-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall maintain, use or operate any device as defined in section
3-10-1 of this chapter, without first having obtained the license therefor in
the manner hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 186, 1-17-1951)
3-10-3: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee required in the preceding sections for a mechanical amusement
device shall be required to be paid annually for each such device operated or
set up for operation, and which said fee shall be paid in advance; and in no
case shall any portion of said license fee be repaid to the licensee. The
amount of the fee for the license for operation of such devices is established
annually by the village board and published at the office of the village clerk.
(Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-10-4: MINORS:
No license shall issue hereunder for the operation of any such device hereunder
licensed to be operated in any place of business within the village, patronized
customarily by minors or children, and no person under the age of twenty one
(21) years shall be allowed to play, use or operate any device licensed under
this chapter. (Ord. 186, 1-17-1951)
3-10-5: VIEW:
All such devices licensed hereunder shall at all times be kept and placed in
plain view of all persons who may frequent or be in any place of business or
other place where such devices are kept or used. Nothing in this chapter shall
be construed to authorize, permit or license any gambling device of any nature
whatsoever which is prohibited by the provisions of this code or by the laws of
the state of Illinois. (Ord. 186, 1-17-1951)
3-10-6: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Any person desiring to procure a license for any such device hereinabove
mentioned and defined shall file with the clerk an application in writing
setting forth the name and address of the applicant and the location at which
it is proposed to operate such device. So, application shall be signed by the
applicant. It shall be referred to the president of the board of trustees and
the chief of police for investigation of the character of the applicant, the
premises on which it is proposed to carry on the business of the applicant and
the type of machine to be used. If the president and the chief of police
approve such application, the clerk shall thereupon issue a license to said
applicant. All licenses shall be placed in a conspicuous place in the
establishment of the licensee. Such license shall be nonassignable and
nontransferable, and shall apply only to the premises for which the license is
issued. The clerk shall also issue a tag or seal for each device licensed
hereunder, which said tag or seal shall at all times be firmly affixed to such
machine in a conspicuous place, and no such tag or seal shall be transferred
from one device to another. No machine shall be installed for operation, taken
out of the location thereof or changed from one location to another without
making a proper application in writing to the clerk, as hereinabove set forth.
(Ord. 91, 4-20-1938)
3-10-7: INSPECTION:
The village through its officers, agents or employees shall have the right to
enter at all times, any establishment, place or building in which any of such
devices are operated or set up for operation, and to inspect, investigate and
test such device. (Ord. 91, 4-20-1938)
3-10-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any license issued hereunder may be revoked by the president whenever in his
judgment the public welfare required such revocation. The acceptance of any
license under this chapter shall constitute an agreement between the parties to
such license that the same may be so revoked by said president in his judgment.
(Ord. 186, 1-17-1951)
3-10-9: COIN OPERATED MUSICAL INSTRUMENTS:
It is hereby declared to be unlawful for any person to install or operate any
coin operated musical instrument or musical device in any public place or place
of business in the village without first obtaining a license so to do.
Application for such license shall be made in writing to the clerk. The annual
fee for a license to operate a coin operated musical instrument or device in
any public place or place of business shall be the sum of ten dollars ($10.00)
for each such machine. (Ord. 91, 4-20-1938; amd. Ord. 632, 11-30-2005)
CHAPTER 11
MOBILE HOMES, MOBILE HOME PARKS, AND CAMPGROUNDS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Definitions
3-11-2: Restrictions With Respect To Mobile Homes
3-11-3: Requirements For Mobile Homes Not Within Mobile Home Parks
3-11-4: Mobile Home Parks
3-11-5: Campgrounds
3-11-6: Recreational Vehicles And Trailers As Mobile Homes
3-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
   CAMPGROUND: An area or place that is used for camping, a place where people
can put up a tent or park a recreational vehicle.
   MOBILE HOME: Any vehicle or similar portable structure of any floor area
under nine hundred (900) square feet, so constructed as to permit its being
used as a conveyance upon public streets or highways and designed to permit the
occupancy thereof as a dwelling place of one or more persons for year round
living without a permanent foundation; excepting, however, those structures
considered to be recreational vehicles and trailers as hereinafter defined.
Dependent Mobile Home: Any mobile home that does not contain a toilet and bath
or shower facilities.
Independent Mobile Home: Any mobile home with self- contained toilet and bath
or shower facilities.
   MOBILE HOME PARK: Any premises upon which five (5) or more occupied mobile
homes are harbored, either free of charge or for revenue, and shall include any
buildings, structures, tents, vehicles or enclosures used or intended for use
as part of the equipment of such mobile home park.
   RECREATIONAL VEHICLE: Any vehicular portable structure built on a chassis
designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreation and vacation
uses and having a body width not exceeding eight feet (8'), being of any
length, provided its gross weight does not exceed four thousand five hundred
(4,500) pounds, or being of any weight provided its body length does not exceed
twenty nine feet (29'). Recreational vehicle types include the motor home
(class A, B, B+, and C), travel trailer, fifth wheel trailer, toy hauler, pop
up trailer, and slide in camper (which fits in the bed of a pickup truck).
   TRAILER: An unpowered vehicle designed to be pulled by a powered vehicle. A
trailer can be covered, open, fully or partially enclosed, is available in all
shapes and sizes and is typically used to pull equipment, cars, snowmobiles,
all- terrain vehicles, or goods. (Ord. 812, 6-22-2016)
3-11-2: RESTRICTIONS WITH RESPECT TO MOBILE HOMES:
It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain a mobile home in the village
outside of a mobile home park which is duly licensed hereunder and by the state
pursuant to the Illinois mobile home park act, except as herein specifically
permitted.
No mobile home may be placed in an O-1, B-1 or B-2 zoning classification unless
that mobile home is a temporary structure to be utilized during construction
only pursuant to the permitting process below. (Ord. 812, 6-22-2016)
3-11-3: REQUIREMENTS FOR MOBILE HOMES NOT WITHIN MOBILE HOME PARKS:
   (A)   Permit Process Required For Mobile Homes: No person shall park or
place any mobile home upon any private lot within the village other than in a
mobile home park without first obtaining a license to do so by the village of
Creve Coeur.
   (B)   Mobile Homes Not Within Mobile Home Parks: All mobile homes not within
mobile home parks in the village of Creve Coeur must be independent mobile
homes (in that they must have self-contained toilet and bath/shower
facilities).
   (C)   License Application Process: To obtain a license, the owner of the
home, or the lot, must fill out an application with the village clerk and pay
the application fee (which will be set by the village board and published on a
fee schedule in the office of the village clerk). The application will consist
of:
      1.   The proposed location of the placement of the mobile home and proof
of ownership of the property where the mobile home will be placed and/or
written consent of the owner of the property.
      2.   The written consent of at least three-fourths (3/4) of the residents
and three-fourths (3/4) of the property owners within a one thousand foot
(1,000') radius of the property of the proposed mobile home placement.
      3.   Completion of a site plan that details not only the placement of the
mobile home, but also details the sewer, water, electric, and gas service
connections to be used (so that the village can ensure compliance with the
provisions below).
      4.   A description of the purpose of the mobile home structure and if it
is to be permanent or a temporary structure to be used during construction
alone.
   (D)   Public Hearing Required: Once the application is complete, the Creve
Coeur zoning board of appeals will hold a public hearing at a regularly
scheduled meeting and either recommend approval of the mobile home or not after
reviewing the site plan, ensuring compliance with zoning regulations, and
considering the effect mobile home usage will have on the property values of
neighboring parcels. Upon recommendation of the zoning board of appeals, the
village board will either grant approval or not at its next regularly scheduled
meeting. In the event that the zoning board of appeals denies approval, or the
village board declines to approve on the zoning board of appeals'
recommendation, the decision may be appealed pursuant to the Illinois
administrative review act.
   (E)   Village Board Approval, Annual Fee And Village License Required: Once
approval is granted by the village board, the clerk shall issue an annual
license to the mobile home. The license shall be renewed by the owner of the
mobile home annually once the annual fee is paid in the amount listed on the
fee schedule published at the office of the village clerk.
   (F)   Placement Restrictions: No mobile home shall be parked upon a private
lot closer than fifty feet (50') from a public street or thoroughfare, nor
within less than twenty five feet (25') of any other building or dwelling of
another.
   (G)   Sewer Connections: Each mobile home placed upon a private lot shall be
connected with the sanitary sewer, whenever the same is conveniently available,
or when such sewer is not conveniently accessible, then the same shall be
connected with a proper septic tank or cesspool.
   (H)   License To Be Displayed: Each mobile home shall have conspicuously
displayed the current license issued by the clerk, and the same shall be
readable from the outside of such mobile home. The owner of the lot upon which
the mobile home is to be set is liable for the license fees heretofore
provided.
   (I)   Additional Regulations:
      1.   Each mobile home shall be connected with electricity, and each shall
have a fuse block concealed from the weather.
      2.   Each mobile home shall have a metal covered garbage container and
such container shall be covered and flytight.
      3.   No mobile home upon a private lot shall have any structure or lean
to nor attached room, not a part of the mobile home proper. (Ord. 812, 6-22-
2016)
3-11-4: MOBILE HOME PARKS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to establish any mobile home park
unless such person shall first have obtained a license therefor pursuant to the
Illinois mobile home park act, 210 Illinois Compiled Statutes 115/1 et seq.
   (B)   Only one mobile home park shall be allowed in the village, and the
license having been granted, no additional licenses shall be granted nor
authority given to operate such a park, home or subdivision, so long as there
is one such installation in the village. This section shall apply to additional
annexations as well as those already in the village. In the event that another
or a new mobile home park is specially allowed in the village of Creve Coeur,
through later ordinance no mobile home park hereafter created shall be
permitted in any residential area, where the majority of the property within a
radius of one thousand feet (1,000') is used or designed for residence
purposes.
   (C)   Any mobile home park in the village of Creve Coeur must have an
annually renewed village license to operate. The license shall be granted by
the village clerk, annually, upon proof of active state licensure under the
mobile home park act and payment of the maximum fee allowed by statute to be
charged by a municipality for such license as found at 210 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 115/18. The current annual fee for a village mobile home park license
is published on the fee schedule in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 812,
6-22-2016)
3-11-5: CAMPGROUNDS:
All campgrounds within the village shall be licensed by the state under the
campground licensing and recreational area act and shall follow all
requirements of the law and the regulations of the Illinois department of
public health. Campgrounds may allow tent camping and camping in recreational
vehicles and trailers. There is no requirement that campgrounds be licensed by
the village.
The manager of the campground shall keep a registry, available to police
inspection at all times, of each camper, the time and date of arrival and
departure, the full name of the owner or occupants, the license number of the
trailer or recreational vehicle if applicable, and the address of the owner or
occupants. (Ord. 812, 6-22-2016)
3-11-6: RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND TRAILERS AS MOBILE HOMES:
Within the village of Creve Coeur, recreational vehicles and/or trailers cannot
be used as residences or places of business in the style of a mobile home.
(Ord. 812, 6-22-2016)
CHAPTER 12
DANCE HALLS
SECTION:
3-12-1: License Required
3-12-2: License Prohibited
3-12-3: Alcoholic Liquors Prohibited
3-12-4: Police To Supervise
3-12-5: Building Regulations
3-12-6: License Fee
3-12-7: Exceptions
3-12-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or establish a public dance hall,
club or association where dancing is permitted, authorized, encouraged or
presumed as a consequence of the business there being conducted, first
obtaining a license thereof, at the address licensed for such purpose. (Ord.
309, 1-18-1967)
3-12-2: LICENSE PROHIBITED:
No license shall be issued for a dance hall within one hundred feet (100') of a
tavern. (Ord. 309, 1-18-1967)
3-12-3: ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for the manager, operator or person in charge of any dance
hall to suffer or permit the sale, gift, serving or use of "setups" for
intoxicating liquor, wines, malt products or spirits of liquor, and it shall be
unlawful for any person to possess, drink or furnish any intoxicating liquor,
wines, malt products or spirits of liquor in any dance hall. (Ord. 309, 1-18-
1967)
3-12-4: POLICE TO SUPERVISE:
Every dance hall, during the hours of music or dancing, shall have an approved
police officer, authorized by the chief of this village to act as such, in
attendance and such additional number as may be deemed by the chief as required
to preserve order and assure compliance with the provisions of this code. (Ord.
309, 1-18-1967)
3-12-5: BUILDING REGULATIONS:
   (A)   Every public dance hall shall be well lighted and shall be so arranged
as to permit clear vision of the dance floor from the exterior of the building.
   (B)   No premises shall be licensed as a dance hall unless there is at least
one parking place for average sized automobiles for every five (5) persons that
may be accommodated at any dance; such parking places shall be on the premises
where the dance hall is located and shall be of the "off street" type, arranged
so that no vehicles will block other vehicles in the parking lot.
   (C)   Each dance hall shall be equipped with two (2) restrooms, one for
ladies and one for gentlemen, with lavatories, soap and paper towels at all
times. The lavatories shall be so located as to require patrons leaving the
restroom to pass the lavatories. (Ord. 309, 1-18-1967)
3-12-6: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee shall be required annually. If a license is requested midyear,
the fee may be prorated by quarter for the first year of operation. The amount
of such fee for the license for operation is established annually by the
village board and published in the office of the village clerk. All licenses
shall issue only after approval by the village board, and shall be signed by
the president and clerk. Each application for a license shall set forth the
name and address of the applicant and all persons interested in the business or
the dance hall enterprise, together with such pertinent facts as may be
required. No license shall be used at a location other than that for which it
is issued without the approval of the village board. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-12-7: EXCEPTIONS:
This chapter shall not apply to taverns, dramshops for which licenses have been
issued by the village, nor to functions of recognized religious organizations
nor to functions sponsored by public institutions, nationally recognized
veterans' organizations owning their own premises, nor to schools or
municipalities or their departments. (Ord. 309, 1-18-1967)
CHAPTER 13
MUNICIPAL RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX
SECTION:
3-13-1: Tax Imposed
3-13-2: File Report; Payment
3-13-1: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling
tangible personal property at retail in this Village at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business
while this Chapter is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1. (Ord. 349, 8-20-69)
3-13-2: FILE REPORT; PAYMENT:
Every such person engaged in such business in the Village shall file on or
before the last day of each calendar month the report to the State Department
of Revenue required by section three of "An Act in Relation to a Tax upon
Persons Engaged in the Business of Selling Tangible Personal Property to
Purchasers for Use or Consumption", approved June 28, 1933, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department
of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from
sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month. (Ord. 349, 8-
20-69)
CHAPTER 14
MUNICIPAL SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX
SECTION:
3-14-1: Tax Imposed
3-14-2: File Report; Payment
3-14-1: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in this Village in the
business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost
price of all tangible personal property transferred by said serviceman either
in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an
incident to a sale of service in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5. (Ord. 348, 8-20-69)
3-14-2: FILE REPORT; PAYMENT:
Every supplier or serviceman required to account for Municipal Service
Occupation Tax for the benefit of this Village shall file, on or before the
last day of each calendar month, the report to the State Department of Revenue
required by section nine of the "Service Occupation Tax Act", approved July 10,
1961, as amended.
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the State Department
of Revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed. (Ord. 348, 8-20-69)
CHAPTER 15
FORTUNE TELLING
SECTION:
3-15-1: Compliance
3-15-2: License To Be Obtained
3-15-3: License Fee
3-15-4: Penalty
3-15-1: COMPLIANCE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the occupation or advertise or
solicit patronage under the representation that such person is engaged or
gifted in the matters of clairvoyance, fortune telling, palmistry, mystics or
occultism, as an occupation of possessing such powers or to receive or accept
any money, gift, charge or other thing of value, unless such person complies
with this chapter. (Ord. 376, 5-19-1971)
3-15-2: LICENSE TO BE OBTAINED:
Any person seeking to follow any of the pursuits or occupations above mentioned
in the preceding section shall first apply to the village clerk for a license,
listing previous addresses, time and place of residences, arrest records and
the like, giving a personal history statement to be supplied by the village
clerk. Thereafter, such information shall be furnished to the chief of police
for a police check and he shall within six (6) days thereafter, report back his
findings with recommendations for or against the issuance of any such license.
Appeals from his determination shall be to the village board at their next
regular public meeting and action of the village board shall be final. (Ord.
376, 5-19-1971)
3-15-3: LICENSE FEE:
The license fee for the above license is established annually by the village
board and is published in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-15-4: PENALTY:
Any person who violates this chapter, shall, upon conviction, be fined not less
than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00), and each day the offense occurs shall be a separate fine. (Ord. 575,
11-14-2001)
CHAPTER 16
MUNICIPAL USE TAX
SECTION:
3-16-1: Tax Imposed
3-16-2: Collection of Tax
3-16-1: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 upon the privilege of using in the Municipality any
item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at
retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with an agency of
Illinois government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%) of the
selling price of such tangible property with selling price to have the meaning
as defined in the Use Tax Act, approved July 14, 1955. (Ord. 414A, 10-2-75)
3-16-2: COLLECTION OF TAX:
Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois Department of Revenue for all
municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or
certificate of registration for the personal property is issued. (Ord. 414A,
10-2-75)
CHAPTER 17
WRECKERS AND TOWING SERVICES
SECTION:
3-17-1: Definitions
3-17-2: Policy
3-17-3: Application for Contract
3-17-4: Licensing
3-17-5: Insurance
3-17-6: Duties and Requirements of Wrecker Owners Licensed by the Village of
Creve Coeur
3-17-7: Cost and Inspections
3-17-8: Wreckers Called by the Police
3-17-9: Termination of License
3-17-10: Fees
3-17-11: Other Regulations
3-17-12: Solicitation of Business
3-17-13: Penalty for Violation
3-17-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Ordinance:
   WRECKER: A person engaged in the business of, or offering the services of, a
vehicle wrecker or towing service, whereby motor vehicles are or may be towed
or otherwise removed from one place to another by the use of a motor vehicle
adapted to and designed for that purpose.
   CHIEF OF POLICE: The executive head of the Police Department of the Village
of Creve Coeur, Illinois, or any one designated by him.
   TOWING LIST: A list maintained by the Police Department containing the names
of those "wreckers" licensed by the Village of Creve Coeur to respond to
requests for the towing of vehicles made by the Police Department.
   VILLAGE: The Village of Creve Coeur, Illinois.
3-17-2: POLICY:
In order to protect persons who operate motor vehicles inside the Village, it
is desirable and necessary to adopt this Chapter to insure proper licensing,
storage, availability and other controls over persons and firms licensed to
provide wrecker service.
3-17-3: APPLICATION FOR CONTRACT:
Any person desiring to perform towing work at police request shall submit an
"Application for Wrecker Service License" in duplicate to the Chief of Police.
Application forms shall be obtained from the office of the Chief of Police.
These forms shall include the name of the owner, home and business address,
home phone and name under which the person does or will trade, the location,
size and security features of the storage lot on which towed vehicles will be
stored, the location to which the public must come to claim stored vehicles, a
statement of willingness to provide wrecker service on a continuous twenty four
(24) hour a day basis each day of the year, a list of the towing equipment, its
size and capacity, a complete listing of the insurance policies, carriers and
agents the owner should place into effect upon license approval, a statement
that the wrecker owner will accept responsibility for any and all personal
property left in towed and stored vehicles along with a description of the
place he would use to adequately protect the property left in towed or stored
vehicles, a description of the two (2) way mobile communications and base
station to be used on each wrecker and at the office where calls are received.
No applicant shall be eligible for licensing under this Chapter unless the
business address and storage lot of applicant shall be located within the
corporate limits of the Village.
3-17-4: LICENSING:
Within thirty (30) days after receiving an "Application for Wrecker Service
License", the Chief of Police shall conduct an investigation to determine the
truth and accuracy of the information contained in said "Application for
Wrecker Service License". Upon completion of his investigation, the Chief of
Police shall forward a copy of the "Application for Wrecker Service License" to
the Mayor along with a recommendation for approval or disapproval of a license
and the reasons, if any, for disapproval. Upon receiving the "Application for
Wrecker Service License", the President on behalf of the Village shall
determine whether or not the applicant has complied with the necessary
standards and criteria. If he finds the applicant qualified, then a license
shall be issued to the applicant and the applicant's name placed at the end of
the towing list.
3-17-5: INSURANCE:
No wrecker license shall be issued until the applicant has deposited with the
Chief of Police the following insurance policies:
   (A)   Garage Keeper's Policy: A garage keeper's legal liability policy
covering fire, theft, windstorm, vandalism and explosion in the amount of ten
thousand dollars ($10,000.00) with each vehicle suffering damage being deemed a
separate claim.
   (B)   Garage Liability Policy: A garage liability policy covering the
operation of the owner's business, equipment or other vehicles for any bodily
injury or property damage. This policy shall be in the minimum amount of twenty
five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for any one person injured or killed and a
minimum of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for more than one person killed
or injured in any accident and an additional ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00)
for property damage.
   (C)   Each policy required under this Section must contain an endorsement by
the carrier providing ninety (90) days' notice to both the Village and the
insured in the event of any change in coverage under the policy.
3-17-6: DUTIES AND REQUIREMENTS OF WRECKER OWNERS LICENSED BY THE VILLAGE OF
CREVE COEUR:
The owner shall provide a wrecker vehicle of sufficient size and weight to
remove and tow tractor trailer rigs. All wreckers shall be equipped with
warning lights required under State law and have working two (2) way
communications radio equipment on the same frequency as a base station located
at the point where calls are received. The owner shall provide continuous
twenty four (24) hour per day service each day of the year, and there shall be
an attendant on duty at all times for the purpose of receiving calls and
receiving and releasing stored vehicles. The owner shall assume all liability
and shall indemnify and save the Village harmless from such liability for
damages sustained by vehicles while being towed or stored and for all personal
injuries occurring to any of the firm's employees or other persons and shall
maintain the required insurance policies. The wrecker owner shall not release
any vehicle directly impounded by the Village without authorization by the
Police Department.
3-17-7: COST AND INSPECTIONS:
All costs incident to towing and storage shall be paid by the owner or person
in charge or possession of the towed and stored vehicle to the owner of the
wrecker company and a receipt for payment shall be issued to the said person.
The Village shall assume no liability or responsibility for any vehicle removed
from any place without the authority of the Chief of Police. The wrecker owner
shall maintain approved records and claim check system to assure release of
vehicles to the rightful owner or authorized person. Such records shall be open
to the Police Department for investigation of specific complaints and for
compiling surveys under this Chapter. The owner of any wrecker service shall
permit any person appointed by the Chief of Police to inspect his wreckers,
vault, security room or storage area at such times as the Chief of Police shall
deem appropriate.
3-17-8: WRECKERS CALLED BY THE POLICE:
The Chief of Police shall insure that wreckers are called to the scene of an
accident or to impound vehicles on a rotation basis, distributing the calls on
an equitable basis from the towing list. The Chief of Police shall not call or
cause to be called any wrecker not licensed with the Village unless all such
wreckers are unavailable. It is specifically permitted for the Chief of Police
to call a wrecker out of sequence where proximity to the wreck and estimated
response time make it more practical to do so.
3-17-9: TERMINATION OF LICENSE:
The President may terminate any license when he finds:
   (A)   That the license was secured by fraud or by the concealment of a
material fact by the wrecker owner and such fact, if known, would have caused
the refusal to issue a license.
   (B)   That the wrecker owner has violated any of the requirements or
regulations established by the Chief of Police under this Chapter.
   (C)   That the Village is not satisfied with the general services of the
owner and/or employees or with the cooperation it has received while rendering
service or other justifiable cause.
3-17-10: FEES:
The chief of police after consultation with wrecker service operators shall
recommend to the village board a table of maximum fees that may be charged by
wrecker owners licensed under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 436, 2-2-
1977)
3-17-11: OTHER REGULATIONS:
The chief of police shall establish and cause the enforcement of reasonable
rules and regulations for wreckers as from time to time he deems appropriate
for the safety, well being, and protection of citizens within his jurisdiction
and their property. (Ord. 436, 2-2-1977)
3-17-12: SOLICITATION OF BUSINESS:
No wrecker shall respond to the scene of an accident or emergency for the
purpose of towing vehicles unless specifically called there by the police or
person involved in the accident or emergency. This section is intended to
prohibit wrecker owners from soliciting business at the scenes of accidents and
emergencies and shall not be construed to prohibit any wrecker from contracting
with any person, firm or corporation providing the wrecker owner, his agents
and employees do not solicit towing contracts at the scenes of accidents or
emergencies. (Ord. 436, 2-2-1977)
3-17-13: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter, upon conviction,
shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 575, 11-14-2001)
CHAPTER 18
REGULATION OF ADULT BUSINESSES
SECTION:
3-18-1: Definitions
3-18-2: Adult Uses Enumerated
3-18-3: Limitations On Adult Uses
3-18-4: Measurement Of Distances
3-18-5: License Required; Filing Of Application; Filing Fee
3-18-6: Contents Of Application For License
3-18-7: Issuance Of Adult Use License
3-18-8: Suspension, Revocation Of License For Adult Use, And Fines
3-18-9: Automatic Suspension
3-18-10: Exterior Display
3-18-11: Display Of License And Permit
3-18-12: Employment Of Persons Under Eighteen Years Of Age Prohibited
3-18-13: Existing Adult Uses
3-18-14: Adult Use Employee Permit
3-18-15: Revocation Or Suspension Of Adult Use Employee Permit
3-18-16: Employment Of Employees Without Permits
3-18-17: Illegal Activities On Premises
3-18-18: Severability Clause
3-18-19: Violation And Penalty
3-18-20: Repeal Of Conflicting Ordinances
3-18-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively prescribed to them by this section:
   ADULT BOOKSTORES: An establishment having as a substantial portion of its
stock in trade, books, magazines, films for sale or viewing on the premises by
use of motion picture devices or any other coin operated means, and other
periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on
matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities", or
"specified anatomical areas" or an establishment with a segment or section
devoted to the sale or display of such material.
   ADULT ENTERTAINMENT CABARET: A public or private establishment which is
licensed to serve food and/or alcoholic beverages, which features topless
dancers and/or waitresses, strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar
entertainers who display "specified anatomical areas", or engage in, depict, or
display specified sexual activities.
   ADULT MERCHANDISE: Magazines, books, other periodicals, videotapes, films,
motion pictures, photographs, slides, CD-ROMs, DVD-ROMs, virtual reality
devices, or other similar media that are characterized by their emphasis on
matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or
specified anatomical areas; instruments, devices, toys or paraphernalia either
designed as representations of human genital organs or female breasts, or
designed or marketed primarily for use to stimulate human genital organs;
lubricants, oils, gels, creams or lotions designed for or marketed or presented
in a context to suggest their use upon specified anatomical areas or for
specified sexual activities; or lingerie or leather goods marketed or presented
in a context to suggest their use for sadomasochistic practices or specified
sexual activities.
   ADULT MINI-MOTION PICTURE THEATER: An enclosed building with a capacity for
less than fifty (50) persons used for presenting material distinguished or
characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to
"specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" for observation
by patrons thereon.
   ADULT MOTION PICTURE THEATER: An enclosed building with a capacity of fifty
(50) or more persons used for presenting motion pictures having as a dominant
theme material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter
depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or
"specified anatomical areas" for observation by patrons therein.
   ADULT STORE: An establishment having adult merchandise as a substantial or
significant portion of its stock-in-trade.
   BODY SHOP OR MODEL STUDIO: Any public or private establishment which
describes itself as a body shop or model studio, or where for any form of
consideration or gratuity figure models who display "specified anatomical
areas" are provided to be observed, sketched, drawn, painted, sculptured,
photographed, or similarly depicted by persons paying such consideration or
gratuity, or where for any form of consideration or gratuity, nude and seminude
dancing, readings, counseling sessions, body painting, and other activities
that present materials distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter
depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual activities" or
"specified anatomical areas" are provided for observation by or communication
to persons paying such consideration or gratuity.
   BUILDING STRUCTURE: Any structure or group of structures housing two (2) or
more businesses which share a common entry, exit, wall, or frontage wall,
including, but not limited to, shopping centers, shopping malls, shopping
plazas, or shopping squares.
   MASSAGE: Any method of pressure on or friction against or stroking,
kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating of the external
soft parts of the body with the hands or other parts of the human body or with
the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance with or without
such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, liniments, antiseptics, oils,
powder, creams, lotions, ointments or other similar preparations commonly used
in this practice.
   MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT: Any establishment having a fixed place of business
where any person, firm, association, or corporation engages in, or carries on,
or permits to be engaged in or carried on any of the activities mentioned in
the definition "massage" in this section except for hospitals, nursing homes,
sanitariums, or persons holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the
healing arts under the laws of the state, or persons working under the
direction of any such persons or in any such establishments, and further
excepting barbers or cosmetologists lawfully carrying out their particular
profession or business and holding a valid, unrevoked license or certificate of
registration issued by the state, and further excepting health and recreational
facilities and clubs which contain ten thousand (10,000) square feet of
enclosed and finished space equipped for exercise rooms, gymnasiums, tennis
courts, racquetball courts, swimming pools or similar uses directly related to
and used in exercising the human body and which establishment does not derive
more than five percent (5%) of its yearly income from the massage services.
   SPECIFIED ANATOMICAL AREAS: Are any of the following conditions:
   (A)   Less than completely and opaquely covered:
      1.   Human genitals, pubic region, or pubic hair; and
      2.   Buttock; and
      3.   Female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola.
   (B)   Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if completely
covered.
   SPECIFIED SEXUAL ACTIVITIES: Are any of the following conditions:
   (A)   Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal.
   (B)   Acts or representations of acts of human masturbation, sexual
intercourse or sodomy, bestiality, oral copulation, or flagellation.
   (C)   Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region, buttock,
or female breast.
   (D)   Excretory functions as part of or in connection with any activities
set forth in subsections (A) through (C) of this definition. (Ord. 478, 8-19-
1981; amd. Ord. 537, 2-22-1989; Ord. 945, 7-30-2021)
3-18-2: ADULT USES ENUMERATED:
The following shall be considered adult uses for the purpose of this chapter:
   (A)   Adult bookstore;
   (B)   Adult motion picture theater;
   (C)   Adult mini-motion picture theater;
   (D)   Adult entertainment cabaret;
   (E)   Massage establishment;
   (F)   Body shop or model studio;
   (G)   Adult Store. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981; Ord. 945, 7-30-2021)
3-18-3: LIMITATIONS ON ADULT USES:
   (A)   Adult uses are conditionally permitted in any I-2 district northwest
of Wesley Road and U.S. Route 29, provided no adult use shall be located within
one thousand feet (1,000') of the property boundaries of any school, daycare
center, cemetery, public park, forest preserve, public housing, and place of
religious worship. Additionally, no adult use shall be located within two
hundred fifty feet (250') of any property which is zoned or used for
residences.
   (B)   Persons under the age of twenty one (21) years are prohibited from
being on the premises of an establishment operating as an adult use under this
chapter unless said persons are employees or independent contractors of the
establishment. (Ord. 753, 7-24-2013)
3-18-4: MEASUREMENT OF DISTANCES:
For the purposes of this chapter, measurements shall be made in a straight
line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the property
line of the adult use to the nearest property line of any school, daycare
center, cemetery, public park, forest preserve, public housing and/or place of
religious worship as well as any residences. (Ord. 758, 12-11-2013)
3-18-5: LICENSE REQUIRED; FILING OF APPLICATION; FILING FEE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in, conduct, or carry on, or to
permit to be engaged in, conducted, or carried on, in or upon any premises in
the village the operation of an adult use as herein defined, without first
having obtained a separate license for such adult use from the president of the
village.
Every applicant for a license to maintain, operate, or conduct an adult use
shall file an application in duplicate under oath with the president upon a
form provided by the village clerk and pay a nonrefundable filing fee, the
amount of which is established annually by the village board and published in
the office of the village clerk. The filing fee must be paid to the village
clerk, who shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application
filed with the president.
The village president shall within five (5) days refer the copies of such
application to the building and electrical inspectors, the fire department, and
police department. These persons and departments shall within thirty (30) days
inspect the premises proposed to be operated as an adult business establishment
or in case of the police department, conduct background investigation of the
applicant and all such persons and departments shall make written
recommendations to the village president concerning the premises and the
applicant's compliance with the matters coming within the jurisdiction of such
persons and departments.
Within ten (10) days after receiving the recommendation of the aforesaid
persons and departments, the president shall notify the applicant that his
application is granted, denied, or held for further investigation. Such
additional investigation shall not exceed an additional thirty (30) days unless
otherwise agreed to by the applicant. Upon the conclusion of such additional
investigation, the president shall advise the applicant in writing whether the
application is granted or denied.
Whenever an application is denied or held for further investigation, the
president shall advise the applicant in writing of the reasons for such action.
Failure or refusal of the applicant to give any information relevant to the
investigation of the application or his or her refusal or failure to appear at
any reasonable time or place for examination under oath regarding said
application or his or her refusal to submit to or cooperate with any inspection
or investigation required by this chapter shall constitute an admission by the
applicant that he or she is ineligible for such permit and shall be grounds for
denial thereof by the president.
Once a license is granted, the license fee for the business shall be annually
paid to the village clerk. The amount of the annual license fee is the same as
the initial filing fee and shall be established annually by the village board
and published in the office of the village clerk. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-18-6: CONTENTS OF APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An applicant for a license including any partner or limited partner of the
partnership applicant and any officer or director of the corporate applicant
and any stockholder holding more than ten percent (10%) of the stock of a
corporate applicant, or any other person who is interested directly in the
ownership or operation of the business shall furnish the following information
under oath:
   (A)   Name and address, including all aliases. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
   (B)   Written proof that the individual is at least twenty one (21) years of
age. (Ord. 478-B, 11-10-1993)
   (C)   All residential addresses for the past three (3) years.
   (D)   The applicant's height, weight, color of eyes and hair.
   (E)   The business, occupation or employment of the applicant for three (3)
years immediately preceding the date of the application.
   (F)   The adult use or similar business license history of the applicant;
whether such person, in previously operating in this or any other city or state
under license, has had such license revoked or suspended, the reason therefor,
and the business activity or occupation subject to such action of suspension or
revocation.
   (G)   All criminal or city ordinance violation convictions, forfeiture of
bond and pleadings of nolos contendere on all charges, except minor traffic
violations.
   (H)   Fingerprints and photograph of the applicant.
   (I)   The exact nature of the adult use to be conducted and the proposed
place of business and facilities thereto.
   (J)   The names and addresses of all persons holding any beneficial interest
in the real estate upon which such adult use is to be operated, including, but
not limited to, contract purchasers or sellers, beneficiaries of land trust or
lessees subletting to applicant.
   (K)   If the premises are leased or being purchased under contract, a copy
of such lease or contract shall accompany the application.
   (L)   A statement by the applicant that he or she is familiar with the
provisions of this chapter and is in compliance with them. (Ord. 478, 8-19-
1981)
3-18-7: ISSUANCE OF ADULT USE LICENSE:
Upon receipt of the recommendations of the persons and departments referred to
in section
3-18-5 of this chapter, the president shall issue a license to maintain,
operate or conduct an adult use unless he finds: (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
   (A)   That the applicant is under the age of twenty one (21) years of age or
under any legal disability. (Ord. 478-B, 11-10-1993)
   (B)   The applicant is a person who is not of good moral character and
reputation in the community in which he or she resides.
   (C)   The applicant has been convicted of any of the following offenses,
unless upon investigation the village president finds that such convictions
occurred at least four (4) years prior to the date of the application, that the
applicant has had no subsequent convictions and has shown evidence of
rehabilitation sufficient to warrant public trust:
      1.   A felony under federal laws or the laws of this or any other state.
      2.   Prostitution, soliciting for a prostitute, pandering, keeping a
place of prostitution, patronizing a prostitute, pimping, obscenity, selling
harmful material or having a tie in a sale of obscene publications to
distributors, under the laws of this state or equivalent laws or ordinances of
the United States or any other state or city, or any other crime or misdemeanor
opposed to decency and morality.
   (D)   The applicant has held an interest in a license either under this
chapter or chapter 1 of this title which regulates alcoholic liquor and has
been revoked for cause.
   (E)   The applicant, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued under this chapter would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application.
   (F)   The operation as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not
have complied with all applicable laws, including, but not limited to,
building, health, planning, housing, zoning and fire codes of the village.
Every adult use license issued pursuant to this chapter will terminate at the
expiration of one year from the date of its issuance, unless sooner revoked.
(Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-8: SUSPENSION, REVOCATION OF LICENSE FOR ADULT USE, AND FINES:
Any license issued for an adult use may be revoked or suspended by the Village
President if the Village President shall find:
   (A)   That the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter
regulating adult uses.
   (B)   The licensee has committed any of the offenses listed in subsection
3-18-7(C) of this chapter.
   (C)   The licensee has knowingly furnished false or misleading information
or withheld relevant information on any application for any license or permit
required by this chapter or knowingly caused or suffered another to furnish or
withhold such information on his or her behalf.
   (D)   The licensee has violated chapter 1 of this title regulating alcoholic
liquor.
   (E)   That a person under the age of twenty one (21) years, who is not an
employee or independent contractor of the establishment, is on the premises of
an establishment operating as an adult use under this chapter, and views any
"specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas" as described in
section
3-18-1 of this chapter.
The licensee shall be responsible for the acts of his agents, servants and
employees, provided, however, that in the case of first offense by a licensee
where the conduct was solely that of an employee, the penalty shall not exceed
a suspension of thirty (30) days if the Village President shall find that the
licensee has no actual or constructive knowledge of such violation and could
not, by the exercise of due diligence, have had such actual or constructive
knowledge.
The Village President before revoking or suspending any license shall give the
licensee at least ten (10) days' written notice of the charges against him or
her and the opportunity for a public hearing before the Village President at
which time the licensee may present evidence bearing upon the question. In such
cases, the charges shall be specific and in writing.
In addition to the suspension or revocation of licensure for adult use for the
violations listed in this chapter, the Village President (or designee) shall
also issue an ordinance violation for each and every offense in an amount not
to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each and every offense.
(Ord. 753A, 10-24-2018)
3-18-9: AUTOMATIC SUSPENSION:
   (A)   In the event a licensee is convicted of violating any of the
provisions of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20 as now in force or as may
be amended, from time to time, or any of the provisions of section
 6-2-50 of this Code as now in force or as may be amended, from time to time,
then the license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be suspended for a
period of three (3) months.
   (B)   The President, before suspending any license, shall give at least ten
(10) days' written notice of the charge. The licensee may, within five (5) days
of receipt of said notice, request a public hearing before the President, at
which time the licensee may present evidence bearing upon the question. The
notice required hereunder may be delivered personally to the licensee or be
posted on the premises of the establishment being used as an adult use. (Ord.
753A, 10-24-2018)
3-18-10: EXTERIOR DISPLAY:
No adult use shall be conducted in any manner that permits the observation of
any material depicting, describing, or relating to "specified sexual
activities" or "specified anatomical areas" by display, decoration, sign, show
window, or other opening from any public way or from any property not licensed
as an adult use. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-11: DISPLAY OF LICENSE AND PERMIT:
Every licensee shall display a valid license in a conspicuous place within the
adult use business so that same may be readily seen by persons entering the
premises. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-12: EMPLOYMENT OF PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any adult use licensee or his manager or employee to
employ any person actually engaged in the provision of goods or services to the
public in connection with the adult use who is not at least eighteen (18) years
of age. (Ord. 753, 7-24-2013)
3-18-13: EXISTING ADULT USES:
All existing adult uses at the time of the passage of this chapter must submit
an application for an adult use license within thirty (30) days of the passage
and approval of this chapter. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-14: ADULT USE EMPLOYEE PERMIT:
Any person, including a licensee, who actually engages in the providing of
goods or services to the public in connection with the adult use shall file an
application for an adult use employee permit with the Village Clerk upon a form
provided by the Village Clerk and shall pay the following fees to the Village
Clerk who shall issue a receipt which shall be attached to the application
filed with the Village Clerk. There are fees required to be paid both for the
original application, as well as an annual renewal fee. Those fees are
established annually by the Village Board and are published in the Office of
the Village Clerk. If an annual renewal is not received timely, the Village
will charge an additional fee for failing to return to the Village to renew
timely. That additional charge is also established annually by the Village
Board and is published in the Office of the Village Clerk. In the event that an
adult use employee's last valid license is over one calendar year old, that
person will be considered a new applicant and will be charged an original
application fee as opposed to a failure to return timely fee.
The application for an adult use employee permit shall contain substantially
the same information as the application for adult use license, except for the
names and addresses of the owners of the real estate and any leases or
contracts concerning real estate.
The Village President may issue an adult use employee permit within twenty one
(21) days following the application, unless he finds that the applicant would
not have been eligible for an adult use license under the terms of section
3-18-7 of this chapter.
Every adult use employee permit issued pursuant to this chapter will terminate
at the expiration of one year from the date of its issuance, unless sooner
revoked. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-18-15: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF ADULT USE EMPLOYEE PERMIT:
Any adult use employee permit may be revoked or suspended by the Village
President if the Village President shall find:
   (A)   That the permittee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter
regulating adult uses.
   (B)   The permittee has knowingly furnished false or misleading information
or withheld relevant information on any application for any license or permit
required by this chapter or knowingly caused or suffered another to furnish or
withhold such information on his or her behalf.
Any adult use employee permit shall be revoked by the Village President if the
Village President shall find that the permittee has committed any of the
offenses listed in subsection
3-18-7(C) of this chapter.
The Village President in revoking or suspending an adult use employee permit
shall give the permit holder written notice specifying the grounds therefor.
Such person may within ten (10) days of such revocation or suspension file a
written request with the Village President for a public hearing before the
Village President at which time the permittee may present evidence bearing upon
the question.
The Village President may in his discretion conduct such hearing concurrently
with a hearing pursuant to section
3-18-8 of this chapter for the adult use license, unless it shall appear that
such a joint hearing would prejudice the rights of the licensee or the
permittee involved.
All persons required under this chapter to obtain an adult use employee permit
pursuant to this chapter must display on request during the hours of operation
of said business an identification card provided by the Village Police
Department containing the legal name, and date of birth of the employee. (Ord.
478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-16: EMPLOYMENT OF EMPLOYEES WITHOUT PERMITS:
It shall be the responsibility of the licensee for the adult use or the
employer of any persons purporting to engage in the providing of goods or
services to the public in connection with the adult use to ensure that each
such person shall first have obtained a valid adult use employee permit
pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-17: ILLEGAL ACTIVITIES ON PREMISES:
No licensee or any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of such licensee shall engage in any activity or conduct or permit any
other person to engage in any activity or conduct in or about the licensed
premises which is prohibited by any ordinance of the Village or law of the
State or of the United States. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-18: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase
of this chapter, or any part thereof, or application thereof to any person,
firm, corporation, public agency, or circumstance, is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this chapter or any part thereof. It is hereby
declared to be the legislative intent of the Board of Trustees that this
chapter would have been adopted had such unconstitutional or invalid provision,
clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part thereof not then been included.
(Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
3-18-19: VIOLATION AND PENALTY:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor. A person who is convicted shall be punished by a fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) or more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) or by imprisonment for a period not to exceed six (6) months
or by both such fine and imprisonment. (Ord. 575-A, 1-23-2002)
3-18-20: REPEAL OF CONFLICTING ORDINANCES:
Any other ordinances or resolutions of the Village which may contain provisions
contrary to those in this chapter are hereby expressly revoked and shall be
considered to be superseded by this chapter. (Ord. 478, 8-19-1981)
CHAPTER 19
RAFFLES
SECTION:
3-19-1: Authority
3-19-2: Definitions
3-19-3: Raffles Prohibited Without License
3-19-4: Application For Raffle License
3-19-5: Decision On Application
3-19-6: Eligibility For License
3-19-7: Duration Of License
3-19-8: License Fees
3-19-9: Conduct Of Raffles
3-19-10: Raffles Manager
3-19-11: Records
3-19-12: Sentence
3-19-13: Limitation Of Authority
3-19-1: AUTHORITY:
The licensing provisions in this chapter were passed by the president and board
of trustees of the village of Creve Coeur pursuant to the raffles act, 230
Illinois Compiled Statutes 15. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms have the following
meanings:
   BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses
who have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial and
civic interests of a community.
   CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and
operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to
those eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
   EDUCATIONAL ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and
operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by
methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably
in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in tax
supported schools.
   FRATERNAL ORGANIZATION: An organization of persons having a common interest,
the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and
to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the
burdens of government by caring for those who otherwise would be cared for by
the government. A college fraternity shall satisfy this definition if these
missions are set forth in its organizational documents.
   LABOR ORGANIZATION: An organization composed of workers organized with the
objective of the betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit
and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective
occupations.
   NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less
reasonable sums expended for prizes, local license fees, and other reasonable
operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
   NONPROFIT ORGANIZATION: An organization or institution organized and
conducted on a not for profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone
as a result of the operation.
   RAFFLE: A form of lottery, as defined in section 28-2(b) of the "criminal
code of 1961", conducted by an organization licensed under this chapter, in
which:
   (A)   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance;
   (B)   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
The term "raffle" excludes a game using a card or board containing the word
"free" marked in the center space of the central row of four (4) figures, where
said card or board contains five (5) horizontal rows of spaces, with each row
except the central row containing five (5) figures.
   RELIGIOUS ORGANIZATION: Any church, congregation, society, or organization
founded for the purpose of religious worship.
   VETERANS' ORGANIZATION: An organization or association comprised of members
of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows
or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare
of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as
to confer a public benefit.
   VOLUNTEER: A person performing work for a licensee, who is not compensated
by the licensee. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007; amd. Ord. 651, 11-14-2007)
3-19-3: RAFFLES PROHIBITED WITHOUT LICENSE:
No person, firm or corporation shall conduct raffles or chances in the village
of Creve Coeur without having first obtained a license therefor pursuant to
this chapter. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-4: APPLICATION FOR RAFFLE LICENSE:
   (A)   The license and application for license must specify the area or areas
within the village of Creve Coeur in which raffle chances will be sold or
issued, the time period during which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the
time of determination of winning chances and the location or locations at which
winning chances will be determined.
   (B)   The license application must contain a sworn statement attesting to
the not for profit character of the prospective licensee organization, signed
by the presiding officer and the secretary of that organization.
   (C)   A license only authorizes the licensee to conduct raffles as defined
in this chapter.
   (D)   Applications must include the following information:
      1.   The aggregate retail value of all prizes or merchandise reasonably
expected to be awarded by a licensee in a single raffle,
      2.   The retail value of each prize reasonably expected to be awarded by
a licensee in a single raffle,
      3.   The price which is reasonably expected to be charged for each raffle
chance issued or sold,
      4.   The day or days during which chances may be issued or sold, and
      5.   The maximum number of raffles to be conducted during the period of
one year following the issuance of the license.
   (E)   Application forms shall be available to the public at the office of
the clerk of the village of Creve Coeur and completed applications are to be
submitted at the same location. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-5: DECISION ON APPLICATION:
The village clerk shall review all license applications within ten (10) days
from the date of application and shall, within thirty (30) days from the date
of application, approve or deny a raffle license application. If an application
is approved, the village clerk shall forthwith issue a raffle license to the
applicant. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-6: ELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
   (A)   Licenses shall be issued only to:
      1.   Bona fide religious, charitable, labor, business, fraternal,
educational or veterans' organizations that operate without profit to their
members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five (5)
years immediately before making application for a license and which have had
during that entire five (5) year period a bona fide membership engaged in
carrying out their objects; however, the five (5) year period may be reduced to
two (2) years as applied to a local organization which is affiliated with and
chartered by a national organization which meets the five (5) year requirement,
or
      2.   To a nonprofit fundraising organization that the licensing authority
determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance
to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial
hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster.
   (B)   As required by the raffles act, the following are ineligible for any
license under this chapter:
      1.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony;
      2.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter;
      3.   Any person who is not of good moral character;
      4.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsection
(B)1, (B)2 or (B)3 of this section has a proprietary, equitable or credit
interest, or in which such a person is active or employed;
      5.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (B)1, (B)2
or (B)3 of this section is an officer, director, or employee, whether
compensated or not;
      6.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsection (B)1, (B)2
or (B)3 of this section is to participate in the management or operation of a
"raffle" as defined herein. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-7: DURATION OF LICENSE:
A license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid for a specific number
of raffles to be conducted during a specified period not to exceed one year and
may be suspended or revoked for any violation of this chapter or the raffles
act. (Ord. 544-G, 11-14-2007)
3-19-8: LICENSE FEES:
   (A)   Application Fee: At the time of application for a raffle license made
to the village clerk of the village, there shall be paid an application fee in
an amount established annually by the village board and published in the office
of the village clerk. Said application fee is nonrefundable even should the
application be denied by the village clerk. Bingo is considered a raffle, and
an annual license fee for bingo is required under this provision of this code.
   (B)   License Fees For Raffle Machines: Freestanding (not handheld) raffle
machines shall require a separate annual license fee for each such machine,
which shall be paid by the eligible organization licensed to conduct raffles on
the premises where the machine is located. If more than one organization is
licensed to conduct raffles on such premises, the licensed organizations may
each pay a share of such license fee for the machine, provided that no license
shall be issued for such machine unless and until the total license fee is
received by the village of Creve Coeur for such machine. The amount of the fee
is established annually by the village board and is published in the office of
the village clerk. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
3-19-9: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES:
   (A)   The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
      2.   No person except a bona fide member or volunteer of the licensee may
participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
