to the sewer line, discharging to the septic tank. Grease traps, if used, shall
likewise be discharged into the septic tank.
All sewer pipes from the house to the septic tank, from the septic tank to the
distribution box and from the distribution box to the individual tile lines in
the seepage beds or field, shall be of cast iron, vitrified clay or concrete
pipe with bell and spigot (slip seal or Amvit type) joints, and no such line
shall be built, laid or constructed closer than twenty five feet (25') of a
well, and shall be laid on a slope of not less than one- eighth inch (1/8") per
foot. All pipes inside the house or under any flooring, shall be of cast iron
with leaded joints. No downspout nor surface drainage shall be permitted to be
connected into this system. Copper piping may be used inside the house, where
such piping is exposed. (Ord. 267, 9-27-1961)
4-1-34: SEWER JOINTS:
On all outside the house installations, cement may be used for making joints,
if the joint is caulked with oakum or jute, and the joint completely filled and
covered with mortar all around. The mortar shall be composed of two (2) parts
of clean sand and one part of portland cement, or joints may be made by using
asphaltic or bituminous compounds, provided the joint is first caulked with dry
oakum or jute, tight enough to prevent such jointing material from leaking into
the pipe. (Ord. 267, 9-27-1961)
4-1-35: SEPTIC TANKS:
Septic tanks shall not be located within fifty feet (50') of a well, cistern or
pump suction line, nor within twenty five feet (25') of any lake, stream, or
open ditch, nor within less than a foot above the high water line of any river,
stream or lake.
All septic tanks shall be of at least five hundred (500) gallon capacity, and
if serving any more than a four (4) bedroom unit, the minimum size shall be at
least seven hundred fifty (750) gallons.
Metal tanks may be used if properly protected both inside and outside with a
suitable protective coating. Such tanks shall be at least of 14-gauge metal, if
a metal tank is used.
No septic tank shall be placed within less than ten feet (10') of any house
dwelling or public building. (Ord. 267, 9-27-1961)
4-1-36: DISTRIBUTION BOX:
A distribution box shall be connected to the septic tank on a short tight sewer
line, located on the upper end of the subsurface disposal field. The inlet pipe
shall enter the end of the box approximately six inches (6") above the bottom,
and sides of the box shall extend at least six inches (6") above the inlet
pipe. A removable cover shall be provided for each box. The bottom of the
drainage lines, shall be placed four inches (4") above the bottom of the box,
and all lines shall be of the same elevation. (Ord. 267, 9-27-1961)
4-1-37: LAYOUT OF SEEPAGE FIELDS:
The lines of the tile field shall be constructed so as to fall more than one
inch (1") in fifty feet (50') of tile, and no single line shall exceed one
hundred feet (100') in length. A minimum spacing of six feet (6') between
seepage lines should be provided. Trenches shall be not less than two feet (2')
nor more than three feet (3') wide, and of sufficient depth to accommodate the
purpose for which they are designed. Tile shall be laid on at least a six inch
(6") bed of gravel or crushed rock, from which material smaller than one-half
inch (1/2") has been screened out. From type tile, at least four inches (4"),
laid with the ends between one-eighth inch (1/8") to one-fourth inch (1/4")
apart, shall be used. Tarred paper or roofing cut in strips shall be placed
over the top half of the tile, and gravel of the same consistency previously
described, shall be filled until at least two inches (2") level above the top
of the tile is maintained. (Ord. 267, 9-27-1961)
4-1-38: OFFICE OF BUILDING INSPECTOR:
(Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-1-39: BOCA NATIONAL BUILDING CODE ADOPTED:
(Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-1-40: PENALTIES:
Any person who shall violate any provision of this chapter or fail to comply
therewith, or who shall violate or fail to comply with any lawful order or
regulation made thereunder, or who shall proceed to build in violation of any
detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approved
thereunder, shall, upon conviction therefor, be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and
costs, and each day such violation continues shall be a separate offense and
fined accordingly.
The imposition of a fine for any violation of this chapter shall not excuse the
violation, nor shall it permit it to continue. Any such person so violating
this chapter shall be required to correct or remedy such violation within a
reasonable time, and where not otherwise specified in this chapter, each five
(5) days or major infraction thereof that prohibited conditions are maintained,
shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
CHAPTER 2
ELECTRICAL CODE
SECTION:
4-2-1: Title; National Electrical Code Adopted
4-2-2: Electrical Inspector
4-2-3: Other Work By Electrical Inspector
4-2-4: Permit Required
4-2-5: Inspection Of Work
4-2-6: Compliance With The Electrical Codes On File With The Village Clerk
4-2-7: Right To Inspect; Disconnect
4-2-8: Registration Required; Certificate
4-2-9: Registration Fee
4-2-10: Definitions
4-2-11: Plans To Be Submitted
4-2-12: Final Inspection; Certificate Of Approval
4-2-13: National Electrical Code Adopted (Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-14: Violation
4-2-15: Exceptions
4-2-1: TITLE; NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
   (A)   This chapter shall be known and cited as the CREVE COEUR ELECTRICAL
CODE.
   (B)   The NFPA 70, National Electrical Code, 2020 Edition, (“electrical
code”) as prepared by the National Fire Protection Association, is hereby
adopted and made a part of this chapter by reference thereto. The electrical
code is available for inspection in the office of the village clerk upon
request. The electrical code is incorporated as fully as if set out at length
herein, and the provisions thereof shall be controlling. In the event of any
conflict between the provisions as otherwise contained in this chapter and
those contained in the electrical code on file at the office of the village
clerk, the provisions contained in the electrical code shall apply.
   (C)   The following sections of the electrical code are hereby revised,
completed, or deleted as follows:
Whenever the word “municipality” is used in the electrical code, it shall be
held to refer to the Village of Creve Coeur.
Whenever the words “electrical official” or “administrative authority” are used
in the electrical code, they shall be held to refer to the Electrical Inspector
or his or her authorized representative. (Ord. 955, 2-23-2022)
4-2-2: ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
The person chosen to fill this office of electrical inspector shall be a
competent electrician of good moral character; shall be a resident of the
village and a citizen of the United States. The inspector shall be a licensed
electrician by the state of Illinois. The electrical inspector shall be well
versed in approved methods of electrical construction for safety to life and
property, the statutes of the state relating to electrical work and the rules
and regulations issued by the fire marshal of the state under authority of the
safety rules and standards approved by the American engineering standards
committee. The electrical inspector shall deliver all fees collected to the
treasurer and the treasurer shall pay the electrical inspector the agreed upon
rate for services.
The electrical inspector shall be paid compensation as set by the village
board. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011; Ord. 941, 6-23-2021)
4-2-3: OTHER WORK BY ELECTRICAL INSPECTOR:
It shall be lawful for the electrical inspector to engage in business of
electrical contracting while holding the position of electrical inspector.
However, with respect to any electrical contracting performed by the electrical
inspector constituting contracting with respect to which it is the duty of the
electrical inspector to inspect or to perform other duties in his official
capacity, the electrical inspector shall immediately notify the president of
the board of trustees of said work being performed by the electrical inspector.
Upon such notification, it shall be the duty of the president, by and with the
advice and consent of the board of trustees, to appoint a temporary,
independent electrical inspector with respect to said contracting work. The
temporary, independent electrical inspector shall have all qualifications as
required of the electrical inspector and shall have all duties and
responsibilities with respect to said contracting work performed by the
electrical inspector.
Any violations of the provisions of this code by the electrical inspector or
temporary, independent electrical inspector shall be deemed sufficient cause
for his removal from office, but he may be removed for other just cause. (Ord.
707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-4: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Upon the adoption under this chapter of such standards and specifications for
the installation, alteration and use of electrical equipment, rules,
regulations and fees, the same shall at once become operative, and thereafter
no electrical equipment shall be installed or altered except upon a permit
issued by the electrical inspector. The electrical inspector shall inspect and
shall require that all methods and materials conform to the standards and
specifications applicable thereto which have been recommended and adopted as
herein provided.
Permits required under this electrical code shall be issued pursuant to section
4-2-8 of this chapter except as hereinafter provided. Any permit required by
this code may be issued to a person not so registered to do any work regulated
by this code provided that the applicant is the bona fide owner of the dwelling
structure or accessory building in which the work is to be performed, that he
shall personally be responsible for all work performed in connection therewith,
and that all material, workmanship and methods of installation or repair shall
meet the requirements of this electrical code; and provided further that the
owner shall not take out permits for dwelling structures containing more than
four (4) dwelling units, regardless of whether such dwelling units are occupied
or unoccupied.
All permits issued for any property shall be copied and filed at village hall.
The permit should state the date when a follow up inspection will occur if a
follow up inspection is necessary. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-5: INSPECTION OF WORK:
Upon the completion of the installation or alteration of electrical equipment,
it shall be the duty of the person installing or altering the same to notify
the electrical inspector, who shall inspect the work within twenty four (24)
hours, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, after such notice is given,
and if such electrical equipment is found to be in full accordance with the
provisions of this chapter and does not constitute a hazard to life and
property, he shall make a record of such inspection and issue a certificate of
approval if and as required elsewhere herein. All wiring not exposed to view or
that is to become hidden, shall be inspected within twenty four (24) hours
after notice is received, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, before
such wiring is concealed. (Ord. 310, 2-1-1967; amd. Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-6: COMPLIANCE WITH THE ELECTRICAL CODES ON FILE WITH THE VILLAGE CLERK:
No certificate of approval shall be issued unless the electrical equipment is
in strict compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the statutes of
the state of Illinois; provided, however, that compliance with the regulations
as laid down from time to time by the electrical code (on file in the office of
the village clerk) shall be prima facie evidence of proper installation or
alteration. In the event of a conflict between this chapter and the above
referenced code, the code shall govern. The electrical inspection department
shall keep complete records of all permits issued and inspections made and
other official work performed under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 701B,
4-23-2014)
4-2-7: RIGHT TO INSPECT; DISCONNECT:
The provisions for inspection of work authorized by the permits issued in
accordance herewith shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any
electrical equipment now or hereafter installed whenever the electrical
inspector shall determine that public safety requires it. The electrical
inspector shall have the right during reasonable times or hours to enter any
building in the discharge of his official duties, for the purpose of making any
inspections or tests of the installation or alteration of electrical equipment
contained therein, and shall have the authority to cause the turning off of all
electrical currents and to cut or disconnect any wire where such electrical
currents are dangerous to life or property, or may interfere with the work of
the fire department. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-8: REGISTRATION REQUIRED; CERTIFICATE:
Any person desiring to engage in the business of electrical contracting shall
apply for registration to the electrical inspector. Upon the filing of such
application in proper form, satisfactory completion of the test required and
the payment of the registration fee fixed herein, the electrical inspector
shall issue to the applicant a certificate of registration which shall
authorize the applicant to engage in such business for the year for which it is
issued. The electrical inspector shall keep a suitable record of such
registrations. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-9: REGISTRATION FEE:
The fee for registration as an electrical contractor shall be established
annually by the village board and published in the office of the village clerk.
The fee shall be paid by the applicant to the treasurer in advance upon filing
the application. The certificate of registration issued hereunder shall expire
on December 31 of the year for which it is issued 1 . (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-33-1.
4-2-10: DEFINITIONS:
The term “electrical contractor” as used in this chapter means any person in
the business of installing or altering by contract, electrical equipment for
the utilization of electricity for light, heat or power, not including radio
apparatus or equipment for wireless reception of sounds and signals, and not
including apparatus, conductors and other equipment installed for or by public
utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the
Illinois commerce commission for use in their operation as public utilities.
The term “electrical contractor” does not include employees employed by such
contractors to do or supervise such work. (Ord. 310, 2-1-1967; amd. Ord. 514,
12-10-1986; Ord. 701B, 4-23-2014; Ord. 955, 2-23-2022)
4-2-11: PLANS TO BE SUBMITTED:
Plans shall be submitted by architects, engineers or the owner and approval
obtained from the electrical inspection department before any work is started
pertaining to the electrical installation in or on any new building or project
covered by these rules. Residences, or remodeling work within or on existing
buildings or projects would not be covered by this section except where the
work is of such extent as to require plans to be drafted. Approval under this
section will not constitute a permit, which must be obtained by the contractor
making the installation. (Ord. 310, 2-1-1967)
4-2-12: FINAL INSPECTION; CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
Final inspection and certificate of approval by the electrical inspector shall
be required on wiring in or on all buildings or projects before the same are to
be connected to the supply lines of the public utility, excepting approval may
be given on a completed service and certain stipulated branch circuits where
required for heat and for construction purposes. Such temporary connections are
subject to cutoff without notice for any violation of this chapter. The meter
department of the public utility shall be notified in writing of the
certificate of approval, and a copy shall be furnished to the contractor or
owner, upon request. (Ord. 310, 2-1-1967)
In the absence of the electrical inspector, an approval may issue when signed
by the president and a member of the electrical commission, and shall be as
valid as when otherwise issued. (Ord. 310, 2-1-1967; amd. Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-13: NATIONAL ELECTRICAL CODE ADOPTED:
(Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-14: VIOLATION:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or who
shall engage in the electric contracting business, whether limited or
generally, without first having obtained a certificate of registration from
this village or some other municipality in the state, having a registration and
licensing ordinance with tests, shall be fined not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) for each offense, nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00), and each day that the offense continues or remains uncorrected,
shall be deemed a separate offense and upon conviction, shall be fined
accordingly. However, the conviction and fining of any violator shall not be
deemed a permit to continue the violation or condition or practice complained
of as being contrary to this chapter. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-2-15: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing herein shall prevent an application for injunctive relief, nor shall
the selection of one method in any way preclude the use of the other remedy.
(Ord. 310, 2-1-1967; amd. Ord. 310C, 1-28-1998)
CHAPTER 3
PLUMBING CONTRACTORS
SECTION:
4-3-1: Office Of Plumbing Inspector
4-3-2: Permit Required
4-3-3: Inspection Of Work
4-3-4: Compliance With Illinois Plumbing Code
4-3-5: Records And Reports To Village (Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-3-6: Right Of Inspector To Inspect; Disconnect
4-3-7: Plans To Be Submitted
4-3-8: Final Inspection; Certificate Of Approval
4-3-9: Permit; Fees
4-3-10: Illinois Plumbing Code Adopted
4-3-11: Violation
4-3-12: Exceptions
4-3-1: OFFICE OF PLUMBING INSPECTOR:
   (A)   Office Created: There is hereby created the office of plumbing
inspector. The person chosen to fill this office shall be a competent licensed
plumber of good moral character and a citizen of the United States. He shall
have at least five (5) years' experience as a plumber and should be well versed
in approved methods of construction for safety to life and property and the
statutes and regulations of the federal government and the state of Illinois.
The plumbing inspector shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the village trustees as allowed under the Illinois municipal code,
65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-30-5. The board of trustees may, as needed,
prescribe the duties, and define the powers of the plumbing inspector.
   (B)   Term Of Office: The plumbing inspector shall be appointed for a term
of one year. The initial term shall be from the officer's date of appointment
until April 30, 1995; thereafter, the plumbing inspector's term shall expire on
April 30 of each calendar year.
   (C)   Compensation: The plumbing inspector shall be paid compensation as set
by the village board.
   (D)   Alternative: In the alternative, the mayor, with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, may contract with an independent plumbing
inspection service that will conduct inspections as required by this chapter.
   (E)   Duties:
      1.   The plumbing inspector is charged with ensuring the safety of the
public through the enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, to use
standards outlined in the plumbing code, and to recommend to the board
reasonable rules and regulations pertaining to the issuance of permits.
      2.   The plumbing inspector shall inspect premises for code violations
(or direct a plumber otherwise employed by the village to so inspect) to ensure
the continued safety of the residents of the village of Creve Coeur and direct
the police to issue tickets if plumbing fails to comply with the codes.
      3.   The plumbing inspector shall keep records in the village hall so
that the records are accessible to village officials and the public, if
requested.
         (a)   Records to be kept are permits issued, and inspection reports,
including pictures if applicable.
      4.   The plumbing inspector shall produce quarterly reports which must:
         (a)   List all permits issued, inspections and reasons why a
particular property was inspected.
         (b)   List hours worked, and requests for reimbursement.
         (c)   Be given to the chairman of the buildings and grounds committee
and the village clerk who will maintain a copy of the quarterly reports for the
village trustees. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011; Ord. 941, 6-23-2021; Ord. 955, 2-23-
2022)
4-3-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Upon the adoption under this chapter of such standards and specifications for
the installation, alteration and use of plumbing equipment, rules, regulations
and fees, the same shall at once become operative, and thereafter no plumbing
shall be installed or altered except upon a permit issued by the plumbing
inspector. The plumbing inspector shall inspect and shall require that all
methods and materials conform to the standards and specifications applicable
thereto which have been recommended and adopted as herein provided. All fees
given to the plumbing inspector shall be promptly transferred to the treasurer.
The village treasurer will pay the plumbing inspector the agreed upon rate for
services. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-3-3: INSPECTION OF WORK:
Upon the completion of the installation or alteration of plumbing equipment, it
shall be the duty of the person installing or altering the same to notify the
plumbing inspector, who shall inspect the work within forty eight (48) hours,
exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, after such notice is given, and if
such plumbing equipment is found to be in full accordance with the provisions
of this chapter and does not constitute a hazard to life and property, he shall
make a record of such inspection and issue a certificate of approval if and as
required elsewhere herein. All plumbing not exposed to view or that is to
become hidden, shall be inspected within forty eight (48) hours after notice is
received, exclusive of Saturdays, Sundays or holidays, before such plumbing is
concealed. (Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
4-3-4: COMPLIANCE WITH ILLINOIS PLUMBING CODE:
No certificate of approval shall be issued unless the plumbing equipment is in
strict compliance with the provisions of this chapter and the statutes of the
state, specifically the Illinois plumbing code. (Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-3-5: RECORDS AND REPORTS TO VILLAGE:
(Rep. by Ord. 707, 12-14-2011)
4-3-6: RIGHT OF INSPECTOR TO INSPECT; DISCONNECT:
The provisions for inspection of work authorized by the permits issued in
accordance herewith shall not be construed as prohibiting the inspection of any
plumbing equipment now or hereafter installed whenever the plumbing inspector
shall determine that public safety requires it. The plumbing inspector shall
have the right during reasonable times or hours to enter any building in the
discharge of his official duties, for the purpose of making any inspections or
tests of the installation or alteration of plumbing equipment contained
therein, and shall have the authority to cause the turning off of all water and
to cut or disconnect any plumbing or sanitary sewer connections where such are
dangerous to life or property, or may interfere with the work of the fire
department. (Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
4-3-7: PLANS TO BE SUBMITTED:
Plans shall be submitted by architects, engineers or the owner and approval
obtained from the plumbing inspector before any work is started pertaining to
the plumbing installation in or on any new building or project covered by these
rules. Residences, or remodeling work within or on existing buildings or
projects is not covered by this section except where the work is of such extent
as to require plans to be drafted. Approval under this section will not
constitute a permit, which must be obtained by the contractor making the
installation. (Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
4-3-8: FINAL INSPECTION; CERTIFICATE OF APPROVAL:
Final inspection and certificate of approval by the plumbing inspector shall be
required on plumbing in or on all buildings or projects before the same are to
be connected to the supply lines of the public utility, excepting approval may
be given on a completed service and certain stipulated temporary or part time
services where required for heat and for construction purposes. Such temporary
connections are subject to cutoff without notice for any violation of this
chapter. (Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
4-3-9: PERMIT; FEES:
Before any plumbing work is started in or on any building or project, a permit
must be secured from the plumbing inspector. The fee for such permit and
subsequent inspection shall be in accordance with the fee schedule on file with
the village clerk. (Ord. 701B, 4-23-2014)
4-3-10: ILLINOIS PLUMBING CODE ADOPTED:
There is hereby adopted for the village, for the purpose of prescribing
regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property due to health
hazards that certain code known as the Illinois plumbing code promulgated by
the Illinois department of public health. (Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
4-3-11: VIOLATION:
Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each offense nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each day that the offense
continues or remains uncorrected, shall be deemed a separate offense and upon
conviction, shall be fined accordingly. However, the conviction and fining of
any violator shall not be deemed a permit to continue the violation or
condition or practice complained of as being contrary to this chapter. (Ord.
575-A, 1-23-2002)
4-3-12: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing herein shall prevent an application for injunctive relief, nor shall
the selection of one method in any way preclude the use of the other remedy.
(Ord. 545, 10-26-1994)
CHAPTER 4
FAIR HOUSING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
4-4-1: Definitions
4-4-2: Prohibited Acts
4-4-3: Fair Housing Board
4-4-4: Duties of the Fair Housing Board
4-4-5: Procedures
4-4-6: Penalty
4-4-7: Remedies
4-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the
context, the following terms shall have the meaning ascribed:
   DISCRIMINATE: The term "discriminate" includes difference in treatment in
the sale, lease, rental, or financing of housing accommodations because of the
race, color, creed, religion, religious beliefs or national origin.
   HOUSING ACCOMMODATION: The term "housing accommodation" shall mean and
include any building, structure, or portion thereof which is used or occupied,
or is maintained, arranged, or designated or designed to be used or occupied as
a home, residence or sleeping place of one or more human beings.
   DWELLING: The word "dwelling" shall mean any building or structure, or
portion thereof, within this Village, which is arranged, designed or used as a
home, residence or living quarters, or sleeping place of one or more human
beings.
   HOUSING: The word "housing" shall mean any building or structure, or portion
thereof designed, intended, arranged or designed to be used as or occupied as a
home, residence, living quarters or sleeping place of one or more human beings.
   REAL ESTATE BROKER: The term "real estate broker" shall mean any real estate
broker or agent thereof or who exercises any function of a real estate broker
within the Village.
   LENDING INSTITUTION: The term "lending institution" shall mean any bank,
insurance company, savings and loan association or person in the business of
lending money or guaranteeing loans, or any person in the business of
obtaining, arranging or negotiating loans or guarantees as an agent or broker,
or any person in the business of buying or selling of loans or instruments for
the payment of money which is secured by title to or a security interest in
real estate.
   OWNER: The word "owner" shall mean any person who holds legal or equitable
title to, or an beneficial interest in, any dwelling or housing, or to any
legal or equitable title to shares of, or any beneficial interest in, any real
estate cooperative which owns any dwelling or housing. (Ord. 328, 7-17-68)
4-4-2: PROHIBITED ACTS:
It shall be an unfair housing practice and unlawful for any real estate broker,
lending institution, owner, or person as herein defined to commit any of the
following act or acts prohibited because of or due to race, color, creed,
religion, religious beliefs or national origin:
   (A)   Refuse to show, sell, lease or rent any dwelling or housing solely
because of race, color, creed, religion, religious beliefs or national origin.
   (B)   Make any discriminations distinction or restriction against any
purchaser lessee in the showing, price, terms, conditions or privileges
relating to the sale, rental, lease or occupancy of any dwelling or housing, or
in the furnishing of any facilities or services in connection therewith.
   (C)   Cause any written or oral inquiry or record to be made concerning such
prohibited acts, or a person seeking to purchase, rent or lease any dwelling or
housing.
   (D)   Publish, circulate, issue or display, or cause to be published,
circulated, issued or displayed, any communication, notice, advertisement,
sign, or other writing of any kind relating to the sale, rental or leasing of
any housing accommodation within the Village, which will indicate or express
any limitation or discrimination in the sale, rental or leasing of such housing
accommodation, of any prospective buyer, leasee or renter of such property.
   (E)   To solicit for sale, lease, or listing for sale or lease, of any
housing accommodations within this Village on the loss of value due to the
present or prospective entry into the neighborhood of any person or persons of
any particular race, color, creed, religion, religious beliefs or national
origin.
   (F)   Distribute or cause to be distributed, written material or statements
designed to induce any owner of any housing accommodation to sell or lease his
property.
   (G)   Discriminate or to participate in discrimination in connection with
borrowing or lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting mortgages or
otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, acquisition,
construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any housing
accommodation in the Village.
   (H)   To exploit or overcharge any person for housing accommodations within
this Village.
   (I)   To deliberately refuse examination of copies of listing of a
residential property or real estate within this Village, or to accept and enter
into any limitation in such listing for causes above mentioned. (Ord. 328, 7-
17-68)
4-4-3: FAIR HOUSING BOARD:
There is hereby created a Fair Housing Board which shall be appointed by the
President, and shall consist of five (5) members to be approved by the Board of
Trustees. The President shall designate one of its members to be Chairman. Any
three (3) members of said Board shall constitute a quorum. The term of office
of each member shall be for three (3) years, or until his successor is
appointed and qualified. The President shall designate which of the two (2)
first appointed shall serve for two (2) year terms, and the remaining members,
including the Chairman, shall be appointed for three (3) year terms.
Thereafter, appointments shall be for the full three (3) year terms or for
unexpired terms in event of vacancy. (Ord. 328, 7-17-68)
4-4-4: DUTIES OF THE FAIR HOUSING BOARD:
It shall be the duty of the Fair Housing Board to:
   (A)   Act to eliminate discriminatory practices as specified in Section
4-4-2 of this Chapter, and to initiate or receive and investigate complaints
charging unlawful housing practices;
   (B)   Seek conciliation of such complaints, hold public hearings, make
findings of fact, issue orders and publish its findings of fact and orders in
accordance with the provisions of this Chapter;
   (C)   Render, from time to time, but not less than every three (3) months, a
written report of its activities and recommendations with respect to fair
housing practices, to the President and Village Board, and
   (D)   Adopt such rules and regulations as may be necessary to carryout the
purposes of this Chapter and the orderly handling of its business and duties.
(Ord. 328, 7-17-68)
4-4-5: PROCEDURES:
Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of the provisions of this
Chapter shall file a written complaint setting forth his grievance. Complaints
may be filed with the Fair Housing Board by leaving the same with the Clerk.
Each complaint shall set forth the name and address of the complainant,
together with his telephone number; the name and address of the person against
whom the complaint is brought and it shall state in detail the alleged facts
surrounding the alleged violation of this Chapter. The Fair Housing Board shall
provide a printed form of complaint for use by any aggrieved citizen, and such
forms shall be made conveniently available at the office of the Clerk. Any
complaint shall be filed, as aforesaid, within ninety (90) days after the
alleged unfair housing practice occurred, or it shall be barred.
After the filing of any complaint, the Chairman of the Fair Housing Board shall
designate two (2) members of said Board to make a prompt investigation in
connection therewith; and if such members shall determine after such
investigation, that probable cause exists for crediting the allegations of the
complaint, they shall immediately endeavor to eliminate the unlawful
discriminatory practice complained of by conference, conciliation and
persuasion. In case of a determination that probable cause does not exist, the
fair housing board shall make written findings of fact and shall send copies
thereof to the complainant and the accused within twenty (20) days from the
date of such finding. If attempts at conciliation are not successful within
thirty (30) days after filing of the complaint, the board shall then proceed
promptly to a full hearing of the complaint.
In case of the failure to so eliminate such unfair practice, or in advance
thereof, if in the judgment of the fair housing board the circumstances so
warrant, they may cause to be issued and served in the name of the fair housing
board, a written notice together with a copy of such complaint, to all parties,
of a full hearing on the complaint at a time and place to be specified in such
notice. The notice shall be served on all parties not less than seven (7) days
before the time set for public hearing. The public hearing shall be held not
later than forty five (45) days from the date of the filing of the complaint. A
copy of the notice of public hearing shall be furnished the local press.
The accused shall have the right to file an answer to the complaint, to appear
at the hearing in person and/or to be represented by counsel, and to examine
witnesses and submit testimony. The complainant shall present testimony in
person and such evidence as he deems or is pertinent. He too, may be
represented by counsel.
The fair housing board shall conduct all hearings, but shall not be bound by
the strict rules of evidence prevailing in courts of law or equity. The fair
housing board shall have full power to subpoena witnesses and pertinent
documents, which power may be enforced by said board by proper petition to the
circuit court of the tenth judicial circuit at Tazewell County, Illinois. The
board, aforesaid, shall have power to administer oaths and to take sworn
testimony. At the conclusion of the hearing, the board shall render a written
report and recommendations, within ten (10) days, which shall be served by mail
upon the parties. Hearings may be continued from time to time, but shall be
heard and concluded within sixty (60) days from the date of the first hearing.
(Ord. 328, 7-17-1968)
4-4-6: PENALTY:
If upon the due consideration of all evidence produced at the hearing, the fair
housing board finds that the person against whom the complaint has been filed,
has engaged in or is engaging in an unfair housing practice, as defined in this
chapter, the board shall state its finding of fact and shall issue and cause to
be served upon such person an order requiring such person or the accused to
cease and desist from such unfair housing practice and it shall take such
affirmative or other action as in the judgment of said fair housing board, will
effectuate the purposes of this chapter, including the requirement of a report
of the manner of compliance. Said board shall retain jurisdiction of the case
until it is satisfied that the accused has complied with the order. In the
event that said board determines that the accused has not complied with its
orders, it shall be empowered to recommend to the village board for authority
to have the village attorney do any one of the following:
   (A)   Institute and prosecute proceedings to enforce against the accused
found guilty of the violation of this chapter a fine as hereinafter provided.
   (B)   To apply to any court of competent jurisdiction:
      1.   For an order restraining such person from violating any provision of
this chapter.
      2.   For such other or further relief as may seem to the court
appropriate for the enforcement of this chapter and the elimination of
violation hereof.
   (C)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter may, upon
conviction thereof be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) plus costs and each day the
violation continues shall be a separate offense and subject to fine for each
said violation, separately. However, such fine shall not be a limitation upon
nor a consent or prevention to also use one or more of the other remedies
available hereunder. (Ord. 575-A, 1-23-2002)
4-4-7: REMEDIES:
Any person aggrieved by the violation of any provision of this chapter who has
exhausted the remedies provided for in this chapter may apply to any court of
competent jurisdiction for appropriate relief from such violation, including:
   (A)   An order compelling compliance with this chapter;
   (B)   An order to prohibit any person found by the court to have violated
any provision of this chapter for the sale, lease, exchange, transfer,
conveyance or assignment of any dwelling or housing which is subject to such
violation;
   (C)   An order requiring specific performance of any contract for the sale,
lease, exchange, transfer, conveyance or assignment of any dwelling or housing
by any person who is violating this chapter or has violated this chapter or
refuses to perform for one of the reasons herein prohibited as an unfair
practice;
   (D)   Compensatory damages; and
   (E)   Such other and further relief as may seem to the court appropriate for
the enforcement of this chapter and the elimination of the violation hereof.
(Ord. 328, 7-17-1968)
CHAPTER 5
UNSAFE OR DANGEROUS BUILDINGS
SECTION:
4-5-1: Dangerous Buildings Generally
4-5-2: Definition Of Dangerous Buildings
4-5-3: Enforcement Power
4-5-4: Notice Of Unsafe Condition Of Buildings; Means Of Service
4-5-5: Lis Pendens
4-5-6: Placarding Of Building Or Structure
4-5-7: Demolition Lien; Personal Judgment
4-5-8: Nuisance Structures
4-5-9: Pests And Unsanitary Conditions
4-5-1: DANGEROUS BUILDINGS GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent thereof to keep or maintain any
building or structure or part thereof in any unsafe or dangerous condition. The
word "building", as used in this section, shall describe any walled or roofed
structure including mobile homes, commercial establishments, dwellings and any
accessory structures. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-2: DEFINITION OF DANGEROUS BUILDINGS:
For the purpose of this chapter, any building or structure which has any of the
following defects or is in any of the conditions hereinafter described shall be
deemed a "dangerous building" and any conditions hereinafter described shall be
deemed unsafe:
   (A)   Whenever any door, aisle, passageway, stairway or other means of exit
is not of sufficient width or size, or is not so arranged as to provide safe
and adequate means of exit in case of fire or panic for all persons housed or
assembled therein who would be required to or might use such door, aisle,
passageway, stairway or other means of exit.
   (B)   Whenever any portion thereof has been damaged by wind, flood, fire or
by any other cause in such a manner that the structural strength or stability
thereof is appreciably less than it was before the catastrophe and is less than
the minimum requirements of this chapter.
   (C)   Whenever any portion or member or appurtenance thereof is likely to
fail or to become detached or dislodged, or to collapse and thereby injure
persons or damage property.
   (D)   Whenever any portion thereof has settled to such an extent that walls
or other structural portions have materially less resistance to winds than is
required in the case of new construction.
   (E)   Whenever any building or structure or any part thereof, because of
dilapidation, deterioration, decay, faulty construction, or because of the
removal or movement of some portion of the ground necessary for the purpose of
supporting such building or portion thereof, or for other reason, is likely to
partially or completely collapse; or some portion of the foundation or
underpinning is likely to fall or give away.
   (F)   Whenever for any reason whatsoever, the building or structure or any
portion thereof is manifestly unsafe for the purpose for which it is used.
   (G)   Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind
or flood, or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to become an
attractive nuisance to children who might play in or about the building
structure to their danger.
   (H)   Whenever the building or structure has been so damaged by fire, wind
or flood, or has become so dilapidated or deteriorated as to afford a harbor
for trespassers, or as to enable persons to resort thereto for the purpose of
committing a nuisance or unlawful acts.
   (I)   Whenever a building or structure used or intended to be used for
dwelling purposes, because of dilapidation, decay, damage or faulty
construction or arrangement is unsanitary or unfit for human habitation and is
likely to cause injury to the health, safety or general welfare of those living
within.
   (J)   Whenever a building or structure is infested with rodents, insects,
pests or other vermin; or is likely to cause sickness or disease when so
determined by the building inspector or code enforcement officer of the
village.
   (K)   Whenever any building shall become vacant, dilapidated or open at door
or window, leaving the interior of the building exposed to the elements or
accessible to entrance by trespassers.
   (L)   Whenever a building or structure is deemed a nuisance by Section
4-5-8 of this Chapter and the structure or building has been secured by the
owner or his agents by covering up the windows and exits with lumber or
materials other than glazing materials for a period of thirty (30) days or
more, thereby causing a blighting influence on a neighborhood. (Ord. 554, 10-9-
1996)
4-5-3: ENFORCEMENT POWER:
   (A)   The Building Inspector or code official or his designate shall have
full power to pass any question arising under the provisions of this Section,
subject to the conditions, modifications and limitations contained in this
Chapter.
   (B)   The Building Inspector or code official or his designate is hereby
authorized to demolish or repair or cause the demolition or repair of dangerous
buildings or uncompleted buildings or abandoned buildings within the
territorial limits of the Village.
   (C)   The Building Inspector or code official is further authorized, when
removing or causing the demolition of a dangerous building, uncompleted
building or abandoned building from a lot, to remove all private sidewalks,
fences, concrete foundations and driveways located on the lot with such
building. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-4: NOTICE OF UNSAFE CONDITION OF BUILDINGS; MEANS OF SERVICE:
   (A)   When a building or structure within the Village is found to be a
"dangerous building" or contains an unsafe condition, the Building Inspector
shall issue and serve a notice thereof upon all owners of record or persons
having an interest therein as shown by documents recorded in the office of the
County Recorder of Deeds and upon persons in apparent possession of the
premises.
   (B)   The notice shall briefly and concisely specify the conditions and
factors of the building or structure which render it dangerous or unsafe. The
notice shall further specify that the owners make the building safe (by
complete elimination of any unsafe conditions) or commence demolition at
owner's costs within fifteen (15) days of such notice. The notice shall further
specify that:
      1.   Demolition shall commence no later than fifteen (15) days of such
notice, and
      2.   A date of completion of demolition.
The date for completion shall be reasonably set in light of the nature of the
building, weather conditions, and other related factors. The fifteen (15) day
time period shall commence upon receipt of the notice.
   (C)   The notice authorized by this Section shall be served by either
personal service or by certified mail with return receipt. Personal service may
be made by either the Building Inspector or a police officer of the Village.
   (D)   Where, upon diligent search, the identity or whereabouts of the owner
or owners of any such building, including the lienholders of record, is not
ascertainable, notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real
estate was last assessed for general real estate taxes is sufficient notice
under this Section.
   (E)   In the event the owner fails to comply with any time period set forth
in the notice, the Corporation Counsel is authorized to commence a civil action
in the Circuit Court of the County seeking a court order authorizing demolition
or repair of the building or structure subject to the notice provided by this
Section and to create the lien described in Section
4-5-7 of this Chapter. It shall not be a defense to this cause of action that
the building is boarded up or otherwise enclosed. It further shall not be a
defense that the building is put in a safe condition during the pendency of the
civil action.
   (F)   Joined as defendants in such cause shall be the owner of record and
other parties having an interest in the property as shown by documents recorded
in the office of the County Recorder of Deeds on the date of the filing of the
complaint for demolition. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-5: LIS PENDENS:
Upon the commencement of the civil action set forth in Section
4-5-4 of this Chapter, a lis pendens designating the property upon which the
subject building is located shall be filed with the Recorder of Deeds. Failure
to file or the improper filing of the lis pendens does not, however, affect the
civil action for demolition. Any person obtaining or recording in such office
an interest in the property after such filing may become party to the civil
action only if he intervenes by order of the court. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-6: PLACARDING OF BUILDING OR STRUCTURE:
   (A)   Whenever any dwelling or building has been designated a dangerous
building or contains unsafe conditions, the building inspector shall placard
the building indicating that the condition is dangerous and unsafe. It shall be
unlawful for any person to rent, cause to rent, to occupy or allow another to
occupy premises, knowing that such premises has been designated a dangerous
building.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to remove, cause to remove or
cover up in any way any placard designating a building or structure a
"dangerous building". A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine
of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00), and each day such violation continues shall be a
separate offense. (Ord. 575-A, 1-23-2002)
4-5-7: DEMOLITION LIEN; PERSONAL JUDGMENT:
   (A)   The cost of demolition or repair incurred by the village, including
court costs, attorney fees and other costs related to the enforcement of this
chapter is recoverable from the owner or owners of the real estate and is a
lien thereon, which lien shall be superior to all prior existing liens and
encumbrances, except taxes; provided, however, that within sixty (60) days
after completion of the demolition or repair, the corporation counsel shall
file a notice of lien for the cost and expense incurred by the village, in the
office of the recorder of deeds of the county. Upon payment of such cost of
demolition by the owner or any person who has an interest in the property, the
lien shall be released by the corporation counsel.
   (B)   The lien may be enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in cases of
mortgages or mechanic's liens. Suit to foreclose this lien shall be commenced
by the corporation counsel within three (3) years after the date of filing of
notice of lien.
   (C)   If payment of the village's cost of demolition is not paid to the
village within fifteen (15) days of the filing of the notice of lien, the
village attorney may commence proceedings in the circuit court seeking a
personal judgment from the owner of the subject property at the time the
complaint for demolition was filed with the circuit clerk in the amount of such
costs. The action authorized by this subsection shall be in addition to, and
without waive of, any other remedies. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-8: NUISANCE STRUCTURES:
   (A)   Any unsafe, dilapidated or abandoned building, house, barn or other
structure situated within the limits of the village is, and the same is hereby
declared to be, a nuisance.
   (B)   If any such building or other structure is being constructed, altered,
enlarged or repaired and the building permit issued for such building or
structure expires or is revoked by the building inspector then that building or
structure shall remain a declared nuisance. (Ord. 554, 10-9-1996)
4-5-9: PESTS AND UNSANITARY CONDITIONS:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any owner or agent to keep or maintain any
building or structure, including, without limitation, every rooming house,
sleeping room facility, dormitory, hotel, motel, single-family resident,
commercial property or otherwise, in a condition exhibiting an unsanitary
nature, and it shall be the responsibility of each such owner or operator to
dispose of all rubbish in a clean and sanitary manner by placing it in proper
secure facilities for disposal which are safe and sanitary.
   (B)   Every occupant of a single-family dwelling or other structure within
the village shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects, rodents,
or other pests within the structure or in the yard. In a two-family dwelling or
multi-family dwelling, the occupant shall be responsible for such extermination
whenever his dwelling unit is the only one infested. When, however, infestation
is caused by failure of the owner or operator to maintain a dwelling in a
rodentproof condition, extermination shall be the responsibility of the owner
or operator.
   (C)   Every owner or operator shall be responsible for extermination of any
insects, rodents or other pests whenever infestation exists in two (2) or more
of the dwelling units in any dwelling or in the shared or public areas of any
two-family dwelling or any multi-family dwelling.
   (D)   Every owner or operator of a rooming house, sleeping room facility,
dormitory, or motel shall be responsible for the extermination of any insects,
rodents or other pests in it or in the yard.
   (E)   Any owner of any dog, cat or other domesticated animal shall maintain
any outside kennels and/or feeding areas in a neat and sanitary manner. No
person shall maintain their property in such a condition so as to draw rats,
rodents, insects or other pests to the location of any such dog kennel or
feeding area, and all such food supplies for such animals shall be maintained
in such a manner as to be protected from access of such rodents and other
pests. (Ord. 624, 10-13-2004)
CHAPTER 6
VACANT AND NEGLECTED STRUCTURES AND PROPERTIES
SECTION:
4-6-1: Scope
4-6-2: Intent
4-6-3: Other Laws, Codes, Ordinances, And Regulations
4-6-4: Definitions
4-6-5: Obligation To Submit A Plan To Avoid Demolition Action
4-6-6: Fifteen Day Notice
4-6-7: Vacant Building Plan
4-6-8: Violations And Penalties
4-6-1: SCOPE:
This chapter shall apply to all vacant buildings and properties in the village
of Creve Coeur now existing or hereafter becoming vacant. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-
2015)
4-6-2: INTENT:
It is the intent of this chapter to protect the public health, safety, and
welfare by requiring responsible parties to implement a maintenance plan for
such vacant structures and properties to remedy any public nuisance, prevent
deterioration, unsightly blight and consequent adverse impact on the value of
nearby property. This chapter shall be construed liberally and justly to affect
its purposes. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-3: OTHER LAWS, CODES, ORDINANCES, AND REGULATIONS:
This chapter shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other laws,
codes, ordinances, and regulations which prescribe standards other than are
provided herein, and in the event of conflict, the most restrictive shall
apply. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-4: DEFINITIONS:
   EXTERIOR PROPERTY AREAS: The open space on the premises and on adjoining
property under the control of owners or operators of such premises.
   GARBAGE AND RUBBISH: Combustible and noncombustible waste materials, and the
term shall include the residue from the burning of wood, coal and other
combustible materials, paper, rags, cartons, boxes, wood, rubber, leather, tree
branches, yard trimmings, tin cans, metals, mineral matter, glass crockery, and
dust and other similar materials.
   MAINTENANCE: Acts of repair and other acts to prevent a decline in the
condition of grounds, structures, and equipment; such that the condition does
not fall below the standards established by this code and other applicable
statutes, codes and ordinances.
   OCCUPANT: Any persons living and/or sleeping in a structure or having
possession of a space within a building.
   OPERATOR: Any person who has charge, care, or control of a structure or
premises which is let or offered for occupancy.
   OWNER: Any person, agent, operator, firm, or corporation having a legal or
equitable interest in the property; or recorded in the official records of the
state, county, or municipality as holding title to the property; or otherwise
having control of the property, including the guardian of the estate of any
such person, and the executor or administrator of the estate of such person if
ordered to take possession of real property by a court.
   PERSON: Includes a corporation or copartnership as well as an individual.
   PREMISES: A lot, plot, or parcel of land including the buildings or
structures thereon.
   PUBLIC NUISANCES: Include the following:
   (A)   The physical condition, or uses of any premises, regarded as a public
nuisance at common law;
   (B)   Any physical condition, use or occupancy of any premises or its
appurtenances considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not
limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, and unsafe fences
or structures;
   (C)   Any premises which has unsanitary sewage or plumbing facilities;
   (D)   Any premises designated as unsafe for human habitation or use;
   (E)   Any premises which is manifestly capable of being a fire hazard, or
manifestly unsafe or insecure as to endanger life, limb, or property;
   (F)   Any premises which is unsanitary, or which is littered with rubbish or
garbage or which has an uncontrolled growth of weeds; or
   (G)   Any structure or building that is in a state of dilapidation,
deterioration or decay; faulty construction; open or vacant and the doors,
windows, or other openings are boarded up or secured, by any means other than
conventional methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new
construction of similar type; damaged by fire to the extent as not to provide
shelter, in danger of collapse or failure and dangerous to anyone on or near
the premises.
   RENOVATION: A building and its facilities made to conform to present day
minimum standards of sanitation, fire and life safety.
   STRUCTURE: Any building built for the support, shelter or enclosure of a
person's animals, chattels, or movable property of any kind and which is
permanently affixed to the ground.
   VACANT AND NEGLECTED: Empty or not occupied on a regular basis by an
occupant or not used by a person on a regular basis for the usual and customary
purposes for which a building is designated and lawfully permitted, or not
maintained in a safe and livable condition. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-5: OBLIGATION TO SUBMIT A PLAN TO AVOID DEMOLITION ACTION:
Whenever any structure or property in the village is vacant and such structure
or property contains one or more of the public nuisances described in this
chapter, then the owner of such building shall, within fifteen (15) days of
notification, contact the village's building inspector to develop a vacant
structure/property plan.
If the property owner does not contact the village's building inspector, the
village will proceed with a demolition action pursuant to the Illinois
municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5-11-31-1. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-6: FIFTEEN DAY NOTICE:
The building inspector or other officer of the village shall direct the
village's legal counsel to prepare a fifteen (15) day notice to the owners of
the property of record and all lienholders of the offender property. The
fifteen (15) day notice shall be sent via certified mail, return receipt
requested and shall detail the nuisances complained of, violations of the
building codes that are apparent as well as that the owners of the property may
avoid substantial fees and court costs if they meet with the village's building
inspector and shall, together, develop a vacant structure/property plan. If a
plan cannot be agreed upon, the village will continue with a demolition action.
The development of a vacant building plan with the building inspector will stay
the prosecution of the demolition action as long as the vacant building plan is
adhered to by the parties. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-7: VACANT BUILDING PLAN:
A vacant building plan, when submitted shall contain the following:
   (A)   A plan of action to repair any doors, windows, or other openings which
are boarded up or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional
methods used in the design of the building or permitted for new construction of
similar type. The proposed repair shall result in openings secured by
conventional methods used in the design of the building or by methods permitted
for new construction of similar type.
   (B)   For buildings and premises thereof which are identified as being or
containing public nuisances, the vacant building plan shall contain a plan of
action to remedy such public nuisance(s).
   (C)   For each required plan, a time schedule shall be submitted identifying
a date of commencement of repair and date of completion of repair for each
improperly secured opening and identified nuisance.
   (D)   When the owner proposes to demolish the vacant building, then the
owner shall submit a plan and time schedule for such demolition.
   (E)   A plan of action to maintain the building and premises thereof in
conformance with this chapter.
   (F)   All plans will comply with the following maintenance requirements in
addition to all other village code provisions:
      1.   Motor Vehicles: An owner of a vacant building and premises thereof
shall not permit an inoperable, partially dismantled, wrecked, junked,
discarded, abandoned or unlicensed motor vehicle to remain on the premises,
unless such vehicle is in an enclosed building or unless permitted as part of
an approved vacant building plan.
      2.   Boarding Up: No window, door, or other opening shall be boarded up
or otherwise secured by any means other than conventional methods used in the
design of the building or otherwise permitted for new construction of similar
type for a period in excess of thirty (30) days unless authorized pursuant to
an approved vacant building plan.
      3.   Weather Coating: Any exterior surface which has previously been
treated with a weather coating material such as paint or stain shall be
maintained in good condition free from faded or peeling paint or other coating
material.
      4.   Lighting: All exterior lighting fixtures shall be maintained in good
repair, and illumination shall be provided to the building and all walkways in
the same manner as provided at the time the building was last occupied or as
otherwise provided in the approved vacant building plan. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
4-6-8: VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
Any person who violates their own vacant building plan, who refuses to or
neglects to submit a vacant building plan, or who refuses to agree to a
schedule that will bring a building fully code compliant in a timely manner
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation is
permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense and fines will increase
daily until the seven hundred fifty dollar ($750.00) per day maximum is
reached. The village's building inspector is specifically permitted (in
addition to the Creve Coeur police department or code enforcement officer) to
issue ordinance violations of this chapter. (Ord. 759A, 12-9-2015)
CHAPTER 7
SWIMMING POOLS AND SPAS
SECTION:
4-7-1: Permits And Inspections Required For Swimming Pools Or Spas
4-7-2: Requirements Of Construction Of Pools/Spas
4-7-1: PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS REQUIRED FOR SWIMMING POOLS OR SPAS:
   (A)   Inspections Of Pools/Spas With Over Twenty Four Inches Performed At
Least Once Every Five Years: Inspections of existing swimming pools (above
ground or in-ground) or spas that contain more than twenty four inches (24")
(2') of water are required in the Village of Creve Coeur to make sure that all
safety requirements, cover and fencing requirements (as found at subsection
10-4-6(F) of this Code), electrical and plumbing requirements and Building Code
requirements are met.
      1.   Cost of inspection is twenty dollars ($20.00).
      2.   Village will notify property owner via first class mail of an annual
inspection date at least two (2) weeks prior to the inspection.
      3.   For a pool/spa to meet inspection requirements it must:
         (a)   Contain water suitable for swimming/bathing that is not
stagnant.
         (b)   Contain proper fencing or enclosures and required at subsection
10-4-6(F) of this Code.
         (c)   All electrical work must meet Code requirements.
         (d)   The pool/spa must hold water and not leak as to create a run off
hazard.
      4.   Property owners who do not allow or avoid inspection are assumed to
have failed and will be cited pursuant to subsection (A)5 of this section.
      5.   Swimming pools or spas that do not pass inspection are determined to
be a nuisance per se, and will be cited as such as detailed in section
7-3-1 et seq., of this Code.
   (B)   Pool/Spa Building Permits Required Prior To Construction Of Pools/Spas
With Over Thirty Six Inches (3 Feet) Of Water: A building permit is required
prior to the construction of a swimming pool (above ground or in ground) or spa
that contains water over thirty six inches (36") (3') deep.
      1.   An application for a permit shall be filed with the building
inspector which shall contain:
         (a)   The contractor's name, address, and phone number and license
number if a contractor is being used.
         (b)   One set of drawing showing the construction details of the
swimming pool/spa that details:
            (1)   Filter and heating equipment.
            (2)   Diving boards and slides.
            (3)   Any other applicable equipment.
            (4)   Electric plan.
            (5)   Location, height and type of fence or enclosure to be used to
comply with the fencing requirements of subsection
10-4-6(F) of this Code.
         (c)   One up to date copy of the plat of survey showing everything
currently on the property and the location of the swimming pool/spa drawn to
scale and indicate the location of:
            (1)   The pool or spa.
            (2)   Path of electric service to the house.
            (3)   No pool or spa shall be placed closer than five feet (5')
from the lot line or be located in an easement.
      2.   The building inspector will review and approve or deny the permit
within ten (10) working days and will call you when the permit is ready to be
picked up.
   (C)   Permit Fees:
      1.   Twenty dollars ($20.00) paid when the permit is picked up.
      2.   Twenty dollars ($20.00) to be paid prior to re-inspection if any
portion of the pool/spa fails the first inspection.
      3.   Cost of the permit is double ($40.00) in the event that construction
started before a permit was obtained.
   (D)   Permit Duration: A building permit to build a pool/spa is good for
sixty (60) days. (Ord. 836A, 7-26-2017)
4-7-2: REQUIREMENTS OF CONSTRUCTION OF POOLS/SPAS:
   (A)   Plans And Permit On Site: Village approved plans and permit must be on
the job site at all times.
   (B)   Construction Requirements:
      1.   A construction barrier is necessary to protect the area during
construction.
      2.   If a pool heater is installed, the gas company will be required to
confirm that the existing gas meter and service is sufficient for the added
demand.
      3.   Pool heaters shall be equipped with a readily accessible on- off
switch to allow shutting off the heater without adjusting the thermostat
setting.
      4.   Pool heaters fired by natural gas shall not have a continuously
burning pilot light.
      5.   Time switches that can automatically turn off and on heaters and
pumps according to a preset schedule shall be installed on swimming pool
heaters and pumps.
      6.   All electrical work must be hard wired and to code. The electrical
requirements are based on the Electrical Codes adopted by the Village's
electrical inspector (a copy of the codes adopted is on file with the Village
Clerk).
      7.   All excavated soil must be hauled offsite.
   (C)   Inspection: Inspections will be required as the project progresses.
Each inspection must be scheduled with the building inspector or electrical
inspector who must be given at least twenty four (24) hours' notice when
scheduling:
      1.   Fence.
      2.   Underground electric.
      3.   Concrete wall/slab.
      4.   Final inspection. (Ord. 836A, 7-26-2017)
CHAPTER 8
RESIDENTIAL OCCUPANCY REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
4-8-1: Scope of Chapter
4-8-2: Definitions
4-8-3: Compliance Required
4-8-4: Minimum Occupancy Requirements
4-8-5: Water Line Connections
4-8-6: Electrical
4-8-7: Utilities
4-8-8: Right of City Inspectors to Enter Buildings
4-8-9: Right of Owner to Enter Buildings to Make Repairs
4-8-10: Effect of Chapter on Other Regulations
4-8-1: SCOPE OF CHAPTER:
This chapter is applicable to occupancy for residential purposes of any
building or structure, altered or converted so as to be occupied for
residential purposes. The requirements imposed by this chapter shall be in
addition to the other applicable requirements for existing buildings imposed by
this code. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
 
                   Any building or structure which is wholly or partly used or
DWELLING:          intended to be used for living or sleeping by human
                   occupants; provided, that temporary housing as hereinafter
                   defined shall not be regarded as a dwelling.
                   Any room or group of rooms located within a dwelling and
DWELLING UNIT:     forming a single habitable unit with facilities which are
                   used or intended to be used for living, sleeping, cooking
                   and eating.
                   Any tent, trailer or other structure used for human shelter
                   which is designed to be transportable and which is not
TEMPORARY HOUSING: attached to the ground, to another structure, or to any
                   utilities system on the same premises for more than fifteen
                   (15) consecutive days. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
 
4-8-3: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
No person shall occupy as owner-occupant or shall let to another for occupancy
a dwelling unit, which does not comply with the minimum standards for basic
facilities set forth in this chapter, and such is hereby declared to be a
nuisance. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-4: MINIMUM OCCUPANCY REQUIREMENTS:
Every dwelling unit shall contain at a minimum:
   (A)   Lavatory Facilities: A room, separate from the habitable rooms, which
affords privacy and which is equipped with a flush water closet in good working
condition.
   (B)   Bathtub Or Shower: A room, separate from the habitable rooms, which
affords privacy to a person in the room and which is equipped with a bathtub or
shower.
   (C)   Sink: A sink in good working condition and properly connected to an
approved water supply system which provides at all times heated and unheated
running water under pressure and which is connected to an approved plumbing and
sewerage system.
   (D)   Electricity: At least two (2) separate floor or wall-type electric
outlets per room capable of receiving and receiving electrical service.
   (E)   Heating: Heating facilities, which are capable of safely and
adequately heating all habitable rooms. Portable heating equipment employing a
flame and heating equipment using gasoline or kerosene do not meet the
standards of this chapter and are prohibited. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-5: WATER LINE CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   Every sink, lavatory, and bathtub or shower required shall be properly
connected with water lines, which shall be in good working condition and
receiving water service.
   (B)   All plumbing fixtures required by this section shall be properly
connected to an approved water system and to an approved sewerage system.
   (C)   All plumbing shall be so designed and installed as to prevent
contamination of the water supply through backflow or any other method
contamination. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-6: ELECTRICAL:
Every outlet, fixture, and electrical wiring shall be properly installed and
maintained in good and safe working condition. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-7: UTILITIES:
No owner, operator or occupant shall cause any service equipment or utility
which is required by this chapter to be removed, shut off or discontinued for
any occupied dwelling let or occupied by him, except for such temporary
interruption as may be necessary while actual repairs or alterations are in
process, or during temporary emergencies. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-8: RIGHT OF CITY INSPECTORS TO ENTER BUILDINGS:
The Building Inspector or code official or his or her designee, in performing
their duties under this chapter, shall have the power during reasonable hours,
and upon showing of proper identification, to make or cause to be made an entry
into any private building or premises within the Village for the purpose of
making an inspection or test in the discharge of his official duties; provided,
however, that no inspection of an occupied dwelling shall occur without the
consent of a resident, tenant, or lawful occupant residing therein unless an
administrative search warrant is first obtained. (Ord. 931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-9: RIGHT OF OWNER TO ENTER BUILDINGS TO MAKE REPAIRS:
Every occupant of a dwelling or dwelling unit shall give the owner thereof, or
his agent or employee, access to any part of the premises occupied by him, at
all reasonable times, for the purpose of making such repairs or alterations as
are necessary to effect compliance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
931, 4-28-2021)
4-8-10: EFFECT OF CHAPTER ON OTHER REGULATIONS:
In any case where a provision of this chapter is found to be in conflict with
any provisions of any zoning, building, fire prevention, safety or health
regulation of this code, the provisions which establish the higher standard for
the promotion and protection of health and safety shall prevail. (Ord. 931, 4-
28-2021)
TITLE 5
FIRE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
FIRE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
5-1-1: Department Created
5-1-2: Members; Oath
5-1-3: Appointments
5-1-4: Meetings; Officers; Bond
5-1-5: Treasurer's Duties
5-1-6: Rules And Regulations
5-1-7: Firemen's Powers; Duties
5-1-8: Prohibitions During Fire
5-1-9: Compensation
5-1-10: Fees For Services
5-1-1: DEPARTMENT CREATED:
There is hereby established and organized the fire department of the village
for the prevention and extinguishment of fires. (Ord. 94, 7-20-1938)
5-1-2: MEMBERS; OATH:
The fire department shall consist of a fire department administrative
secretary, a fire chief, assistant fire chief, and not less than twelve (12)
other members. Said fire department administrative secretary, fire chief,
assistant fire chief, and members of the fire department are hereby declared to
be village officers, and shall, before entering upon the duties of their
respective offices, take and subscribe to the following oath or affirmation:
I do solemnly (swear or affirm, as the case may be) that I will support the
Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of
Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of
(Fire Department Administrative Secretary, Fire Chief, Assistant Fire Chief, or
Village Fireman, as the case may be) according to the best of my ability.
(Ord. 94-A, 10-11-1989)
The oath or affirmation so subscribed shall be filed with the clerk. The fire
department administrative secretary, fire chief, assistant fire chief and the
firemen shall each be provided with the proper badge of office, and shall have
police powers as hereinafter set forth.
The fire chief shall serve as the liaison to the mayor and village board
regarding fire department matters and in the absence of the fire chief, the
assistant fire chief shall serve as the liaison. The liaison will ensure the
mayor and village board are updated on issues that apply to compliance with all
federal, state and local laws, statutes, ordinances, regulations and safety
measures. (Ord. 704, 4-13-2011)
5-1-3: APPOINTMENTS:
The fire chief, assistant chief, rescue chief, administrative secretary and
other officers/firemen shall be recommended by the members of the fire
department and the mayor and village trustees will act upon such
recommendation. (Ord. 374B, 6-11-1997)
   (A)   Firefighter Training:
      1.   The village of Creve Coeur hereby elects to participate in the
program provided for in the Illinois fire protection training act.
      2.   Before an individual may commence service as a firefighter, he/she
must have been certified by the Illinois state fire marshal as a firefighter
II, as having successfully completed an approved training course as provided in
said act.
      3.   The firefighter II certification must be completed by the trainee
within his/her probationary period of twenty four (24) months. Failure of any
trainee to complete such basic training and certification within the required
period will render that individual and local governmental agency ineligible for
reimbursement funding for basic training for that individual in the fiscal year
in which his/her probationary period ends. The individual may later become
certified without reimbursement. (Ord. 647, 10-24-2007)
5-1-4: MEETINGS; OFFICERS; BOND:
The fire chief and firemen of the fire department shall hold a meeting for the
election of a treasurer and such other officers as may be necessary for the
proper organization of said department. Such election shall be held on the
fourth Monday in May of each year and said treasurer and other elective
officers shall hold office for a term of one year and until their successors
are elected and qualified. The treasurer of such fire department shall give a
bond in the sum of five hundred dollars ($500.00), payable to the village and
conditioned for the faithful performance of his duties as such treasurer, which
said bond shall be approved by the president and the board of trustees. (Ord.
94, 7-20-1938)
5-1-5: TREASURER'S DUTIES:
The treasurer of the village shall pay and deliver to the treasurer of the fire
department and take his receipts therefor, all monies received by him from the
two percent (2%) tax on the gross receipts of foreign fire insurance companies.
The treasurer of the fire department shall receive said money and shall pay out
the same only upon the order of said fire department when ordered by a majority
vote at any regular or special meeting thereof and only for the purpose of the
maintenance, use and benefit of such department. (Ord. 94, 7-20-1938)
5-1-6: RULES AND REGULATIONS:
The said fire department is hereby empowered to make all necessary rules and
regulations, in respect to the proper maintenance and functioning of said
department and the management of the funds in the hands of its treasurer. (Ord.
94, 7-20-1938)
5-1-7: FIREMEN'S POWERS; DUTIES:
When responding to a bona fide emergency in a personal vehicle, firemen shall
use only a blue oscillating light mounted on the dashboard of their vehicle.
While on duty at fires, firemen shall protect persons and property from injury,
and shall have authority to direct or order spectators to move away from the
scene of immediate danger when necessary to prevent injury to persons or
property or to allow firemen sufficient room for the proper performance of
their duty. Firemen, while attending any fire in the village, shall be vested
with police powers and shall have authority to arrest at or near the scene of
any fire, or while responding to any alarm, any person wilfully refusing to
obey any lawful order of the department or any member thereof, or for violating
any provision of this chapter. (Ord. 94A, 6-24-1998)
5-1-8: PROHIBITIONS DURING FIRE:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any vehicle over any fire
hose laying in any street or alley, or to touch any fire apparatus without
authority from a fireman on duty or from a member of the village board. (Ord.
94, 7-20-1938)
   (B)   Upon the sounding of the siren, bell or other warning device used upon
fire apparatus or other vehicles of the fire department, all operators and
drivers of vehicles shall drive their vehicles as near to the right curb or
right side of the street as is reasonably possible and shall remain standing or
parked at such right side until such fire apparatus has passed. It shall be
unlawful for the driver or operator of any vehicle, other than one on official
business, to follow any fire apparatus responding to a fire alarm, closer than
four hundred feet (400'), or to park any vehicle within three hundred feet
(300') of the place where the fire apparatus has stopped in response to a fire
alarm. (Ord. 152, 4-17-1946)
5-1-9: COMPENSATION:
   Members of the village of Creve Coeur volunteer fire department shall be
compensated in amounts determined by the Mayor and Village Trustees, as amended
from time to time.
   The fire chief shall receive such sums as the Mayor and Village Trustees
