penalty provided herein shall not apply to persons in violation of the
provisions of this section, but in lieu thereof, any person in violation of
this section who, after receiving written notice thereof from the public works
department, does not comply within one week after receipt of such written
notice, shall have water service terminated until such time as said violation
has been corrected.
(Ord. 767, 7-23-2014; amd. Ord. 767D, 5-22-2024)
8-1-18: INTERGOVERNMENTAL AGREEMENT PROVIDING FOR WATER SUPPLY COOPERATION IN
THE EVENT OF EMERGENCY:
   (A)   Continuance Of Water Main Connections And Shutoff Valves: Previously
heretofore, pursuant to a prior intergovernmental agreement between the parties
hereto, the village of North Pekin was granted the right to install shutoff
valves and connections with the water mains of Creve Coeur. It is agreed by and
between the parties that unless this agreement is otherwise terminated as
provided herein, the village of North Pekin shall continue to maintain in place
the presently existing shutoff valves and connections with the water mains of
Creve Coeur.
   (B)   Maintenance And Repairs: It is agreed by and between the two (2)
municipalities that all costs incurred for upkeep and repair of the master
meter and shutoff valves installed and maintained in conjunction with the
connection with the water main of Creve Coeur shall be paid for by the village
of North Pekin, Illinois. Said master meter and shutoff valves shall be and
remain the property of the village of North Pekin and at any time this
agreement should be terminated, the village of North Pekin shall have the right
to remove said meter and shutoff valves.
   (C)   Water Supply Production: Each municipality shall maintain the ability
to supply to the other water at forty (40) psi (pounds per square inch) except
at such time as the supplying municipality may be in an emergency situation, or
otherwise unable to do so.
   (D)   Water Rates: During the time the valves and connections described and
provided for herein are in operation, the consumer municipality shall pay to
the supplying municipality a sum equal to one hundred percent (100%) of the
highest rate between two (2) municipalities per one thousand (1,000) gallons of
water in effect at the time of consumption. The amount of water consumed shall
be determined by the increase or decrease of water pumped at each one of the
municipality's wells.
   (E)   Emergency Purposes Only: It is further agreed that the valves shall
only be used in case of an emergency or in instances where either party, due to
planned shutdown or otherwise, has unavailable to it sufficient water to meet
its needs, and not for the purpose of supplying the normal water needs of the
consuming municipality. The water operator of each municipality shall
immediately notify the water superintendent of the other municipality when
water is turned on or shut off by means of the connections made pursuant to
this agreement. At any time an emergency condition is to last for a period of
greater than thirty (30) days, the other municipality shall have the right to
terminate water consumption by means of the shut off valves installed on the
water main of Creve Coeur as agreed to herein. Any such shut off valve shall
not be left in the "on" position after the emergency ceases to exist,
regardless of the fact that thirty (30) days may not have elapsed since the
commencement of the emergency.
   (F)   Quality Of Water: The supplying municipality shall not be liable for
the quality of the water after water leaves the main of the supplying
municipality and enters the mains of the consumer municipality. Each
municipality shall undertake all efforts necessary to provide cross connection
protection.
   (G)   Term Of Agreement: This agreement shall be in full force and effect
from the date of execution and hereafter until amended or changed by mutual
agreement of both respective corporate authorities. It is agreed that neither
North Pekin nor Creve Coeur shall either directly or indirectly seek any
modification of this agreement through court action.
This agreement may be terminated by either municipality by giving to the other
six (6) months' notice in writing, authorized by the corporate authority of the
notifying municipality, indicating the intention to so do.
   (H)   Invalidity: If any provision of this agreement shall be declared
invalid for any reason, such invalidation shall not affect the other provisions
of this agreement which can be given effect without the invalid provision, and
to this end, the provisions of this agreement are to be severable.
   (I)   Construction: This agreement shall be construed in accordance with the
laws of the state. (Ord. 293-J, 6-14-1995)
8-1-19: CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL:
   (A)   Backflow Prevention Device: If, in accordance with the Illinois
plumbing code or in the judgment of the public works department, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
supply system, the public works department will give notice to the water
customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer
shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in
a manner in accordance with the Illinois plumbing code and all applicable local
regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices
as required by the Illinois plumbing code and local regulations.
   (B)   Cross Connection Control Devices: Only cross connection control
devices which are approved by the research foundation for cross connection
control of the University of Southern California, American waterworks
association, American society of sanitary engineering, or American national
standards institute or certified by the national sanitation foundation to be in
compliance with applicable industry specifications shall be used. Installation
of approved devices shall be made only as specified by the research foundation
for cross connection control of the University of Southern California, American
waterworks association, American society of sanitary engineering, or American
national standards institute. Maintenance as recommended by the manufacturer of
the device shall be performed. Manufacturer's maintenance manual shall be
available on site.
   (C)   Approval Of Private Water Supply: No person shall establish or permit
to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby
a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the village waterworks may enter the supply of the
municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
public works department and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
   (D)   Surveys And Investigations: It shall be the duty of the public works
department to cause surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and
other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual
or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and
investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at
least every two (2) years, or as often as the public works department shall
deem necessary.
   (E)   Right To Enter: The village or its authorized agent shall have the
right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to
the public water supply or distribution system of the village public water
supply for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross
connections, and the village or its authorized agent shall have the right to
enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public
water supply or distribution, system of the village public water supply for the
purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the
required cross connection control inspection. On demand the owner, lessees or
occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the public works
department any information which he may request regarding the piping system or
systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when
demanded, shall, within the discretion of the public works department, be
deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this
section.
   (F)   Penalty: Any person violating this section shall be fined in
accordance with the general penalty provisions of this code for each offense;
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues. The public works department is hereby
authorized and directed to discontinue, after ten (10) days' written notice to
the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection
in violation of the provisions of this section is known to exist and to take
other precautionary measures without notice as he may deem necessary to
eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution
mains, including, without limitation, the right to immediate cancellation of
water service without notice to any party to prevent actual or anticipated
contamination of the water supply; provided, that in the reasonable opinion of
the public works department or the environmental protection agency such action
is required to prevent actual or potential contamination of the water supply.
Such written notice may be either delivered personally to the occupant, or may
be sent to such person by certified mail.
   (G)   Return Receipt Requested: Water service to such property shall not be
restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance
with the provisions of this section, and until a reconnection fee of twenty
five dollars ($25.00) is paid to the public works department. Neither the
village nor its agents shall be liable to any customer of the water supply for
any injury, damages, or lost revenues which may result from the termination of
said customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this section,
whether or not said termination of the water supply was with or without notice.
   (H)   Contamination: The person or persons or entity responsible for
backsiphoned material or contamination through backflow, or the consumer
responsible if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through
an illegal cross connection or any improperly installed, maintained or repaired
device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear all costs associated
with the enforcement of this section, including reasonable attorney fees and
court costs incurred by the village.
   (I)   Adoption Of Regulations For Control Of Cross Connections: The board of
trustees of the village public water supply shall adopt such regulations as
they shall deem necessary to promote the elimination or control of existing
cross connections in furtherance of this section. (Ord. 293-J, 6-14-1995)
8-1-20: PROHIBITION OF WATERING:
   (A)   The mayor of the village is hereby empowered and authorized by his
order to prohibit the use of water from the village water system for the
watering of lawns and gardens, washing of automobiles, and filling of swimming
pools during periods of water shortage or low water pressure in the water
system.
   (B)   Any party who so uses such water during the period of such prohibition
shall be in violation of this section, and upon conviction thereof, subject to
penalty as provided herein. Any party who persists in the continued use of such
water during the period of such prohibition shall be subject to a fine of up to
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each such violation and/or immediate
termination of water service by the order of the village mayor. (Ord. 575-A, 1-
23-2002)
8-1-21: WATER LEAKAGE:
In the event there exists a water leak between the curb stop and meter or
building shut off, it shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property
on which said leak is located to repair said leak within ten (10) days after
receiving written notice from the village by first class mail, advising the
property owner or other responsible party or parties of the leak. If said leak
is not repaired within a ten (10) day period, the village shall discontinue
water service to the property without further notice. If said leak is
determined to be a hazard to the safety of the citizens of the village by the
public works department or by its authorized agent the water service shall be
discontinued without notice until the repair is made. (Ord. 293-J, 6-14-1995)
8-1-22: TAMPERING:
It shall be unlawful for any person not authorized by the village to tamper
with, alter, operate, or injure any part of the village waterworks or supply
system, or any meter, remote meter reading device, valve, curb stop, or fire
hydrant of said system. (Ord. 293-J, 6-14-1995)
8-1-23: ILLINOIS ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AGENCY REQUIREMENTS, INFRASTRUCTURE
FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE PROGRAM:
   (A)   Annual Review Of Rates And Charges: The adequacy of the water and
sewer rates and charges shall be reviewed not less often than annually, by
certified public accountants for the village in their annual audit report. The
water and sewer rates shall be revised periodically to reflect a change in
local capital costs or operating, maintenance and replacement costs.
   (B)   Revenues And Accounts: All revenues and monies derived from the
operation of the water and sewer system shall be deposited in the water account
of the water and sewer fund. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the
water department manager separate and apart from all other funds of the village
treasurer and deposited not more than five (5) days after receipt of the same,
or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the
mayor. The water department manager shall receive all such revenues from the
water and sewer system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation
of such system as the same may be delivered to her and deposit the same in the
account of the fund designated as the water and sewer fund of the village. Said
manager shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by
statute of the "Revised Cities and Villages Act", effective January 1942.
The village water department manager shall establish a proper system of
accounts and shall keep proper books, records, and accounts in which complete
and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the water and
sewer system, and at regular annual intervals she shall cause to be made an
audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and
disbursements of the water system.
In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report
shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the water facilities,
including a replacement cost. The financial information to be shown in the
audit report shall include the following:
      1.   Flow data showing total gallons received at the water plant for the
current fiscal year.
      2.   Billing data to show total number of gallons billed per fiscal year.
      3.   Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year.
      4.   Number of users connected to the system.
      5.   Number of nonmetered users.
   (C)   Agency Access To Records: The Illinois environmental protection agency
or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents,
papers and records of the village which are applicable to the village system of
user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and
transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and
general conditions to any state grant.
   (D)   Appeals: The method for computation of rates and service charges
established for user charges shall be made available to a customer within five
(5) days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the
method used or in the computations thereof shall be resolved by the village
trustees within twenty (20) days after notification of a formal written appeal
outlining the discrepancies. (Ord. 293R, 4-8-1998)
CHAPTER 1A
PUBLIC AND PRIVATE SEWERS
SECTION:
8-1A-1: Use Of Public Sewers Required
8-1A-2: Private Sewage Disposal
8-1A-3: Building Sewers And Connections
8-1A-4: Use Of The Public Sewers
8-1A-5: Protection Of Sewage Works From Damage
8-1A-6: Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
8-1A-7: Extension Of Sewer Mains
8-1A-8: Change In Occupancy
8-1A-9: Penalties
8-1A-1: USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS REQUIRED:
   (A)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place, deposit, or permit to be
deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the
Village or in any area under the jurisdiction of said Village, any human or
animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the
Village, or in any area under the jurisdiction of said Village, any sewage or
other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in
accordance with subsequent provisions of this Chapter.
   (C)   Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to construct or
maintain any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool, or other facility
intended or used for the disposal of sewage.
   (D)   The owner of all houses, buildings, or properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the
Village and abutting any street, alley or right of way in which there is now
located or may in the future be located any public sanitary sewer of the
Village, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet
facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this Chapter, within ninety
(90) days after date of official notice to do so, provided that said public
sewer is within one hundred feet (100') of the property line. (Ord. 499, 8-22-
1985)
8-1A-2: PRIVATE SEWAGE DISPOSAL:
   (A)   Where a public sanitary sewer is not available under the provisions of
subsection
8-1A-1(D) of this Chapter, the building sewer shall be connected to a private
sewage disposal system complying with the provisions of this Section.
   (B)   Before commencement of construction of a private sewage disposal
system the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the
Superintendent of the Sewage Department. The application for such permit shall
be made on a form furnished by the Village, which the applicant shall
supplement by any plans, specifications and other information as are deemed
necessary by the Village Board. A permit and inspection fee of twenty five
dollars ($25.00) shall be paid to the Village at the time the application is
filed. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985)
   (C)   A permit for a private sewage disposal system shall not become
effective until the installation is completed to the satisfaction of the
Superintendent of the Sewage Department. The Superintendent of the Sewage
Department or his authorized agent shall be allowed to inspect the work at any
stage of construction and, in any event, the applicant for the permit shall
notify the Superintendent of the Sewage Department when the work is ready for
final inspection, and before any underground portions are covered. The
inspection shall be made within forty eight (48) hours of the receipt of notice
by the Superintendent of the Sewage Department. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985; amd. Ord.
293-M, 11-13-1996)
   (D)   The type, capacities, location, and layout of a private sewage
disposal system shall comply with all recommendations of the State of Illinois
Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act and Code and with the State of Illinois
Environmental Protection Agency. No permit shall be issued for any private
sewage disposal system employing subsurface soil absorption facilities where
the area of the lot is less than thirteen thousand (13,000) square feet. No
septic tank or cesspool shall be permitted to discharge to any natural outlet.
   (E)   At such time as a public sewer becomes available to a property served
by a private sewage disposal system, as provided in Section
8-1A-1(D), a direct connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance
with this Chapter, and any septic tanks, cesspools, and similar private sewage
disposal facilities shall be abandoned and filled with suitable material.
   (F)   The owner shall operate and maintain the private sewage disposal
facilities in a sanitary manner at all times, and at no expense to the Village.
   (G)   No statement contained in this Section shall be construed to interfere
with any additional requirements that may be imposed by any County Health
Department.
   (H)   When a public sewer becomes available, the building sewer shall be
connected to said sewer within ninety (90) days and the private sewage disposal
system shall be cleaned of sludge and filled with clean bank-run gravel or
dirt.
8-1A-3: BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS:
   (A)   No unauthorized person shall uncover, make any connections with, or
opening into, use, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereof
without first obtaining a written permit from the Superintendent of the Sewage
Department.
   (B)   All disposal by any person into the sewer system is unlawful except
those discharges in compliance with Federal standards promulgated pursuant to
the Federal Act and more stringent State and local standards.
   (C)   There shall be two (2) classes of building sewer permits: (a) for
residential and commercial service, and (b) for service to establishments
producing industrial wastes. In either case, the owner or his agent shall make
application on a special form furnished by the Village. The permit application
shall be supplemented by any plans, specifications, or other information
considered pertinent in the judgment of the Village Board. A permit and
connection fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for a residential or
commercial building sewer permit shall be paid to the Village at the time the
application is filed. All industrial waste producers, as a condition of
building permit authorization, must provide information describing its
wastewater constituents, characteristics, and type of activity. The permit and
connection fee for all industrial waste producers shall be determined by
negotiation with the Village Board. In no case shall the fee be less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00).
   (D)   A building sewer permit will only be issued and a sewer connection
shall only be allowed if it can be demonstrated that the downstream sewerage
facilities, including sewers, pump stations and wastewater treatment
facilities, have sufficient reserve capacity to adequately and efficiently
handle the additional anticipated waste load.
   (E)   All costs and expense incident to the installation and connection of
the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the
Village from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned
by the installation of the building sewer.
   (F)   A separate and independent building sewer shall be provided for every
building, except that where one building stands at the rear of another on an
interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the
rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard, or driveway, the
building sewer from the front building may be extended to the rear building and
the whole considered as one building sewer.
   (G)   Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only
when they are found, on examination and test by the Superintendent of the
Sewage Department, to meet all requirements of this Chapter.
   (H)   The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building
sewer, and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing,
testing, and backfilling the trench, shall all conform to the requirements of
the Building and Plumbing Code or other applicable rules and regulations of the
Village. In the absence of code provisions or in amplification thereof, the
materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the
American Society of Testing Materials, Water Pollution Control Federation
Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard Specifications for Water and Sewer Main
Construction in Illinois shall apply.
   (I)   Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building
at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any
building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to the public sewer, sanitary
sewage carried by such building drain shall be lifted by a means which is
approved in accordance with subsection (K) of this Section, and discharged to
the building sewer.
   (J)   No person(s) shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior
foundation drains, areaway drains, or other sources of surface runoff or
groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected
directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer.
   (K)   The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall
conform to the requirements of the Building and Plumbing Code, or other
applicable rules and regulations of the Village, or the procedures set forth in
appropriate specifications of the American Society of Testing Materials, Water
Pollution Control Federation Manual of Practice No. 9, and Standard
Specifications for Water and Sewer Main Construction in Illinois. All such
connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the
prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the Superintendent of
the Sewage Department before installation.
   (L)   The applicant for the building sewer permit shall notify the
Superintendent of the Sewage Department when the building sewer is ready for
inspection and connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made
under the supervision of the Superintendent of the Sewage Department or his
representative.
   (M)   All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately
guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard.
Streets, sidewalks, parkways, and other public property disturbed in the course
of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the Village Board.
8-1A-4: USE OF THE PUBLIC SEWERS:
   (A)   No person shall discharge, or cause to be discharged, any stormwater,
surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated
cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer.
   (B)   Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to
such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural
outlet approved by the Superintendent of the Sewage Department. Industrial
cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged, on approval of
the Superintendent of the Sewage Department, to a storm sewer, or natural
outlet.
   (C)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the
following described waters or wastes to any public sewers:
      1.   Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or
explosive liquid, solid, or gas.
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids,
or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction with other
wastes, to injure or interfere with any sewage treatment process, constitute a
hazard to humans or animals, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in
the receiving waters of the sewage treatment plant.
      3.   Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than five and five-tenths
(5.5) or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or
hazard to structures, equipment, and personnel of the sewage works.
      4.   Solid or viscous substances in quantities or of such size capable of
causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the
proper operation of the sewage works such as, but not limited to, ashes,
cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar,
plastics, wood, unground garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and
fleshings, entrails and paper dishes, cups, milk containers, etc., either whole
or ground by garbage grinders.
   (D)   No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged the following
described substances, materials, waters, or wastes if it appears likely in the
opinion of the Village Board that such wastes can harm either the sewers,
sewage treatment process or equipment; have an adverse effect on the receiving
stream; or can otherwise endanger life, limb, public property, or constitute a
nuisance. In forming the opinion as to the acceptability of these wastes, the
Village Board will give consideration to such factors as the quantities of
subject wastes in relation to flows and velocities in the sewers, materials of
construction of the sewers, nature of the sewage treatment process, capacity of
the sewage treatment plant, degree of treatability of wastes in the sewage
treatment plant, and maximum limits established by regulatory agencies. The
substances prohibited are:
      1.   Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than one hundred
fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°F), (65°C).
      2.   Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous materials; or
oils, whether emulsified or not, in excess of one hundred (100) mg/l or
containing substances which may solidify or become viscous at temperatures
between thirty two (32°) and one hundred fifty degrees Fahrenheit (150°), (0
and 65°C).
      3.   Any garbage that has not been properly shredded. The installation
and operation of any garbage grinder equipped with a motor of three-fourths'
(3/4) horsepower (0.76 hp metric) or greater shall be subject to the review and
approval of the Village Board.
      4.   Any waters or wastes containing strong acid, iron pickling wastes,
or concentrated plating solutions whether neutralized or not.
      5.   Any waters or wastes containing iron, chromium, copper, zinc, or
similar objectionable or toxic substances; or wastes exerting an excessive
chlorine requirement, to such degree that any such material received in the
composite sewage at the sewage treatment works exceeds the limits established
by the Village Board for such materials.
      6.   Any waters or wastes containing phenols or other taste or odor-
producing substances, in such concentrates exceeding limits which may be
established by the Village Board as necessary after treatment of the composite
sewage, to meet the requirements of the State, Federal, or other public
agencies of jurisdiction for such discharge to the receiving waters.
      7.   Any radioactive wastes or isotopes of such half-life or
concentration as may exceed limits established by the Village Board in
compliance with applicable State or Federal regulations.
      8.   Any waters or wastes having a pH in excess of nine and five-tenths
(9.5).
      9.   Any mercury or any of its compounds in excess of 0.0005 mg/l as Hg
at any time except as permitted by the Village Board in compliance with
applicable State and Federal regulations.
      10.   Any cyanide in excess of 0.025 mg/l at any time except as permitted
by the Village Board in compliance with applicable State and Federal
regulations.
      11.   Materials which exert or cause:
         (a)   Unusual concentrations of inert suspended solids (such as, but
not limited to, Fuller's earth, lime slurries, and lime residues) or of
dissolved solids (such as, but not limited to, sodium chloride and sodium
sulfate);
         (b)   Excessive discoloration (such as, but not limited to, dye wastes
and vegetable tanning solutions);
         (c)   Unusual BOD, chemical oxygen demand, or chlorine requirements in
such quantities as to constitute a significant load on the sewage treatment
works;
         (d)   Unusual volume of flow or concentrations of wastes constituting
"slugs" as defined herein.
      12.   Waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to
treatment or reduction by the sewage treatment processes employed, or are
amenable to treatment only to such degree that the sewage treatment plant
effluent cannot meet the requirements of agencies having jurisdiction over
discharge to the receiving waters.
   (E)   If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be
discharged to the public sewers, which waters contain the substances or possess
the characteristics enumerated in subsection (D) of this Section, and/or which
are in violation of the standards for pretreatment provided in chapter 1, EPA
Rules and Regulations, subchapter D, Water Programs Part 128 - Pretreatment
Standards, Federal Register Volume 38, No. 215, Thursday, November 8, 1973, and
any amendments thereto, and which in the judgment of the Village Board may have
a deleterious effect upon the sewage works, processes, equipment, or receiving
waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public
nuisance, the Village Board may:
      1.   Reject the wastes;
      2.   Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the
public sewers;
      3.   Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or
      4.   Require payment to cover the added costs of handling and treating
the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges, under the provisions
of subsection (K) of this Section.
If the Village Board permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows,
the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the
review and approval of the Village Board, and subject to the requirements of
all applicable codes, ordinances, and laws.
   (F)   Grease, oil, and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the
opinion of the Village Board, they are necessary for the proper handling of
liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts, or any flammable wastes,
sand, or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be
required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall
be of a type and capacity approved by the Village Board, and shall be located
as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection.
   (G)   Where preliminary treatment or flow-equalizing facilities are
provided, they shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective
operation by the owner at his expense.
   (H)   Each industry shall be required to install a control manhole. When
required by the Village Board, the owner of any property serviced by a control
manhole shall install such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the
building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the
wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located,
and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the Village
Board. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense, and shall be
maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times.
   (I)   The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying
industrial wastes shall provide laboratory measurements, tests, and analyses of
waters and wastes to illustrate compliance with this Chapter and any special
conditions for discharge established by the Village Board or regulatory
agencies having jurisdiction over the discharge.
The number, type, and frequency of laboratory analyses to be performed by the
owner shall be as stipulated by the Village Board, but no less than once per
year the industry must supply a complete analyses of the constituents of the
wastewater discharge to assure that compliance with the Federal, State, and
local standards are being met. The owner shall report the results of
measurements and laboratory analyses to the Village Board at such times and in
such manner as prescribed by the Village Board. The owner shall bear the
expense of all measurements, analyses, and reporting required by the Village
Board. At such times as deemed necessary, the Village Board reserves the right
to take measurements and samples for analyses by an outside laboratory service.
   (J)   All measurements, tests, and analyses of the characteristics of waters
and wastes to which reference is made in this Chapter shall be determined in
accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of
Water and Wastewater", published by the American Public Health Association, and
shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples
taken at said control manhole. In the event that no special manhole has been
required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream
manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is
connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to
reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage works and to determine the
existence of hazards to life, limb, and property.
   (K)   No statement contained in this Section shall be construed as
preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the Village Board and
any industrial concern whereby an industrial waste of unusual strength or
character may be accepted by the Village Board for treatment, subject to
payment therefor, in accordance with the provisions hereof, by the industrial
concern, provided such payments are in accordance with Federal and State
guidelines for user charge system and industrial cost recovery system.
8-1A-5: PROTECTION OF SEWAGE WORKS FROM DAMAGE:
No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully, or negligently break,
damage, destroy, or tamper with any structure, appurtenance, or equipment which
is a part of the sewage works. Any person violating this provision shall be
subject to immediate arrest under charge of disorderly conduct.
8-1A-6: POWERS AND AUTHORITY OF INSPECTORS:
   (A)   The Superintendent of the Sewage Department and other duly authorized
employees of the Village, the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, and the
U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, bearing proper credentials and
identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of
inspection, observation, measurement, sampling, and testing in accordance with
the provisions of this Chapter. The Superintendent of the Sewage Department or
his representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes,
including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper, or other
industries beyond that point having a direct bearing on the kind and source of
discharge to the sewers or waterway or facilities for waste treatment.
   (B)   While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to
in subsection (A) of this section, the village board or duly authorized
employees of the village, the Illinois environmental protection agency, and the
U.S. environmental protection agency shall observe all safety rules applicable
to the premises established by the company and the company shall be held
harmless for injury or death to the village employees and the village shall
indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by village
employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or
property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the gauging and
sampling operation, except as such may be caused by negligence or failure of
the company to maintain safe conditions as required in subsection
8-1A-4(H) of this article.
   (C)   The superintendent of the sewage department and other duly authorized
employees of the village bearing proper credentials and identification shall be
permitted to enter all private properties through which the village holds a
duly negotiated easement for the purposes of, but not limited to, inspection,
observation, measurement, sampling, repair, and maintenance of any portion of
the sewage works lying within said easement. All entry and subsequent work, if
any, on said easement, shall be done in full accordance with the terms of the
duly negotiated easement pertaining to the private property involved. (Ord.
499, 8-22-1985)
8-1A-7: EXTENSION OF SEWER MAINS:
   (A)   The board of trustees shall first determine if an extension of a sewer
main is economically feasible based on the estimated cost of the extension and
the number of existing potential users that will be served by the extension. If
the extension is economically feasible then the village may install and pay the
cost of the extension at the discretion of the board of trustees. If the
village elects not to pay the cost of extending the sewer main then the person
or persons desiring sewer service shall install the extension at their own
personal expense upon written consent by the board of trustees. The village
shall not pay for any extensions to an undeveloped area such as a subdivision
being developed.
   (B)   When a sewer extension is installed by someone other than the village
the following conditions must be satisfied:
      1.   The village must approve all plans and specifications for any
extensions. The cost to the village of reviewing and approving the plans and
specifications shall be paid by the person submitting the documents.
      2.   Before any extensions are installed, the plans and specifications
must be reviewed and approved by the state of Illinois, environmental
protection agency.
      3.   Ownership, rights of way, and title must be conveyed to the village
for all extensions installed by anyone other than the village. The village will
maintain the mains thereafter.
      4.   No extension will be permitted if, in the opinion of the board of
trustees, the system does not have the necessary capacity to serve the proposed
extension. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985)
8-1A-8: CHANGE IN OCCUPANCY:
   (A)   Any user requesting a termination of service shall give written notice
to the village ten (10) days prior to the time such termination of service is
desired.
   (B)   If the user is not the owner of the premises, the user shall be
primarily responsible for payment of all charges and the property owner shall
be secondarily responsible for all charges not paid by the user.
   (C)   There shall be no charge for transferring the sewer service to the
subsequent user. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985)
8-1A-9: PENALTIES:
   (A)   Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter except
section
8-1A-5 of this article shall be served by the village board with written notice
stating the nature of the violation and providing a reasonable time limit for
the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the period of
time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations. The village board
may revoke any permit for sewage disposal as a result of any violation of any
provision of this chapter. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985)
   (B)   Any person who shall continue any violation beyond the time limit
provided for in subsection (A) of this section shall be fined an amount not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each violation. Each day in which any such violation shall
continue shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 575, 11-14-2001)
   (C)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall
become liable to the village by reason of such violation. (Ord. 499, 8-22-1985)
CHAPTER 2
SIDEWALKS
SECTION:
8-2-1: Permission to Construct; Lay
8-2-2: Construction of Sidewalks
8-2-3: Material
8-2-4: Dangerous Walks
8-2-5: Concrete Sidewalks
8-2-6: Private Construction Report
8-2-7: Obstructions
8-2-1: PERMISSION TO CONSTRUCT; LAY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct or lay any sidewalk upon any
of the streets and alleys of the Village without first having obtained
permission from the President and Board of Trustees to construct or lay the
same according to the provisions of this Code. The provisions of this Chapter
and all other provisions relating to sidewalks shall apply equally to the
outside or border street, as well as to all other streets of the Village.
8-2-2: CONSTRUCTION OF SIDEWALKS:
When any person directly interested shall make application to the President and
Board of Trustees for the construction of any sidewalk upon any of the streets
of the Village, the President and Board of Trustees may order the construction
of the same under the supervision of the Board of Local Improvements, of such
material and such width as they may direct. The cost of the material and the
expense incurred in the construction of such sidewalk shall be paid by the
party applying for the same, unless otherwise ordered by the President, and
Board of Trustees; provided, that when the party applying for such sidewalk
shall desire the same to be over six feet (6') in width. The President and
Board of Trustees may so order, if the party applying shall agree to pay all
necessary expense incurred thereby, and enter into an obligation to keep such
additional width of sidewalk in good condition and repair, without any expense
to the Village, so long as said sidewalk shall remain in use, and well and
truly keep said Village from all harm, damages and costs of suit, actions,
judgments, and executions that shall or may at any time arise, come or be
brought against said Village on account of any accident that may occur to any
person by reason of said portion of said sidewalk being out of repair or in a
dangerous condition at any time hereafter.
8-2-3: MATERIAL:
All sidewalks hereafter constructed in any portion of said Village shall be
composed of concrete, and shall be of such width as shall be determined by
resolution of the President and Board of Trustees.
8-2-4: DANGEROUS WALKS:
Whenever it is brought to the notice of the President or to the Board of Local
Improvements that any sidewalk or part thereof in said Village has become
dangerous to the public safety, he shall cause the same to be immediately
repaired or removed and report such action to the next meeting of the Village
Board.
8-2-5: CONCRETE SIDEWALKS:
All concrete sidewalks hereafter constructed in the Village shall be in
accordance with the specifications furnished by the Clerk, as furnished by the
Board of Trustees, and when any person shall enter into any contract for the
construction of concrete sidewalk within the Village, before entering upon the
performance of the same, he shall file with the Clerk a bond in the penal sum
of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with good and sufficient security, to be
approved by said Clerk, conditioned that such sidewalk shall be constructed in
accordance with the plans and specifications furnished by the Clerk, and that
such sidewalks shall be by him kept in good condition and repair for the period
of one year after the completion thereof.
8-2-6: PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION REPORT:
When any person shall obtain permission to construct any sidewalk within the
Village, as hereinbefore provided, he shall construct the same under the
direction and supervision of the Street and Alley Committee, and according to
the plans and specifications furnished him by the Clerk and when such sidewalk
is completed he shall apply to the Street and Alley Committee for their
acceptance of the same, and if the Street and Alley Committee shall refuse to
accept the same, he shall report to the Village Board the amount of sidewalk so
constructed, the material composing the same, and the manner in which it has
been constructed, for their acceptance or rejections, and if the President and
Board of Trustees refuse to accept the same, he shall proceed at once to
rebuild it according to the plans and specifications furnished by the Clerk,
and if he shall refuse or neglect to rebuild such sidewalk as herein provided,
and such sidewalk is in a dangerous condition or constructed contrary to any
provisions relating to sidewalks, the Board of Local Improvements shall remove
or rebuild the same as the President and Board of Trustees may direct.
8-2-7: OBSTRUCTIONS:
Whoever shall place, throw or have caused to be placed any obstruction in or
upon any sidewalk within said Village, except as authorized by ordinance of the
Village, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. (Ord. 11, 8-1-21)
CHAPTER 3
ILLINOIS RIVER REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-3-1: Swimming, Skiing Prohibited
8-3-2: Emergency Exceptions
8-3-1: SWIMMING, SKIING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to swim, bathe or water ski in the Illinois
River, easterly of the channel of said River, southerly of the Peoria-Pekin
Union Railroad Bridge and northerly of the Southerly Village limits bordering
the Village; the area above described being dangerous to life due to currents,
under-currents, stumps and submerged objects and sloughs that exist therein, as
well as being unhealthy due to pollution from various sources.
8-3-2: EMERGENCY EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing herein shall apply to emergency cases beyond the control of the
individual, not otherwise classed as voluntary nor to low enforcement or rescue
agencies performing their duties. (Ord. 323, 10-4-67)
CHAPTER 4
PIPING REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-4-1: Laying Pipe Near Water Supply
8-4-2: Pipe Encasement Requirements
8-4-1: LAYING PIPE NEAR WATER SUPPLY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to lay, repair, replace or use any pipe
containing gasoline, chemicals or other noxious chemicals harmful to the public
water supply, unless such pipes are encased for one thousand feet (1,000') in
all directions from the water supply in this Village. All existing pipes
carrying such gasoline, chemicals or noxious chemicals, shall be encased as
hereinafter provided, within one year from the date of passage hereof, and no
new installation, repairs, alterations or replacements shall be made on
existing installations within said one thousand feet (1,000') of any public
water supply, without full compliance with this Chapter.
8-4-2: PIPE ENCASEMENT REQUIREMENTS:
All pipes required to be encased under the provisions of Section
8-4-1 hereof shall comply with the following:
   (A)   All pipe lines containing gasoline, chemicals or other chemicals
harmful to a public water supply shall be encased as described in subsection
(J) hereof for one thousand feet (1,000') in all directions from any public
water supply in the Village.
   (B)   The encased pipes shall be laid on a gradient so as to give fluid
velocity of one foot (1') per second. This shall be accomplished by having the
pipes pitched so that it falls from a high point both ways to a manhole.
   (C)   Manholes shall be located one thousand feet (1,000') from the nearest
well or source of supply. Said manholes may contain more than one pipe
encasement, and all such manholes shall be well vented and so constructed as to
give a bottle-tight enclosure.
   (D)   Cathodic protection shall be provided for all pipes not enclosed and
no connections may be made at the manholes or their pipe encasement.
   (E)   All manholes shall be so constructed as to allow visual inspection.
   (F)   All manhole rings and covers, if pipes contain inflammable materials,
shall be constructed of nonspark materials.
   (G)   Manholes shall provide a well in case of leakage in the encased pipes.
The well shall be three feet (3') deeper than the lowest invert of the pipe
encasement.
   (H)   In case of a break in the enclosed pipe, the material shall be pumped
from the manhole into a closed tank or other similar type container so that the
ground around the manhole or in the restricted area, is in no way contaminated.
   (I)   The Village shall have the right to make visual inspection of all
manholes at all times, with right to ingress and egress upon any property
along, through or over which such manholes or pipes are installed. If a leak is
discovered, and the level of the escaping material in the well of the manhole
exceeds the height of the lowest invert of the encased pipe, the Village
reserves the right to pump out the escaping material and to collect from any
responsible party all costs and expenses incurred in connection therewith.
After the leak is corrected, the encased pipe shall be flushed with water to
eliminate all contamination in the pipe encasement. The Village shall have the
right to determination of the disposition of such waste flushings.
   (J)   Piping except in piping sections in pits and manholes, shall be
enclosed in a separate continuous sleeve of glass- cloth-reinforced polyester
pipe as manufactured by Haveg Corporation under the designation of "No. 7790"
or an approved equal, as approved by the Board of Local Improvements. Wall
thickness of encased pipe shall be three-sixteenths inch (3/16") minimum. The
pipe shall be laid in perfectly straight lines and shall continuously slope to
manholes and pits. Both ends of the pipe and its supports shall be supported
concentrically in a steel wall sleeve with the annular space between the pipe
and its sleeve packed with neoprene sponge and caulked water-tight with
neoprene putty. The encasing pipe shall be furnished with straight ends for
butt weld joining. Joints shall be resin bonded with welding materials, as
provided by Haveg Corporation, or an approved equal. The welding materials
shall include a resin, catalyst, glass fiber mats and wrapper strips. Approved
materials and welding shall be as prescribed by the Board of Local Improvements
as determined from established and recommended practices. (Ord. 264, 7-19-61)
CHAPTER 5
STREETS
SECTION:
8-5-1: Deposits On Streets
8-5-2: Removal Of Injurious Material
8-5-3: Other Obstructions Prohibited
8-5-4: Vehicles; Materials; Removal
8-5-5: Penalty
8-5-1: DEPOSITS ON STREETS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to throw or deposit upon any street, alley,
road or highway, any glass, bottle, nails, tacks, cans, lumber, junk, vehicle
bodies or parts, debris, waste, refuse, garbage, bricks, blocks, or any other
substance likely to injure any person, animal, or vehicle, or likely to
interfere with the free and unobstructed use of any street, alley, road or
highway by any traffic, within the village. (Ord. 258-A, 10-13-2004)
8-5-2: REMOVAL OF INJURIOUS MATERIAL:
It shall be unlawful for any person who drops or permits to be dropped or
thrown, upon any street, alley, road or highway any glass, bottle, nails,
tacks, wire, cans, lumber, junk, vehicle bodies or parts, debris, waste,
refuse, garbage, bricks, blocks, or any other substance, or any spillage from
loads, or any other destructive or injurious material, to fail or refuse to
immediately remove the same or cause the same to be removed.
It shall further be unlawful for any person removing any wrecked or damaged
vehicle from any street, alley, road or highway, to fail to remove any glass,
parts or other injurious substance dropped upon the said street, alley, road or
highway, from such vehicle or vehicles so involved. (Ord. 258-A, 10-13-2004)
8-5-3: OTHER OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to place upon, operate, or remain to be
present upon any street, alley, road or highway within the village, or to use
thereon, roller skates, skateboards, or motorized scooters. Further, it shall
be unlawful for any person to operate any remote control car, truck or other
remote operated mechanical device on or about any such public street, alley,
road or highway. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to place upon any
public roadway any basketball hoop, whether portable or permanent, or near or
adjacent thereto, in such a manner as would cause or allow a person to be in
the roadway while utilizing such basketball hoop, or other device, or which
would allow for the interference with the traffic flow or plowing of snow upon
any such street, alley, road or highway. (Ord. 258-A, 10-13-2004)
8-5-4: VEHICLES; MATERIALS; REMOVAL:
Whenever any police officer finds a vehicle standing upon the highway, streets,
road or alley, in violation of any of the provisions of this code, or any
glass, bottle, nails, tacks, wire, cans, lumber, junk, vehicle bodies or parts,
debris, waste, garbage, blocks, bricks, spillage from loads, any other
destructive materials, or materials likely to cause injury, or any such item,
device or gaming tool mentioned in section
 8-5-3 of this chapter, such officer is hereby authorized to remove the same or
require the driver, owner, or person in charge thereof, or responsible
therefor, to remove the same, or said officer may employ another to remove the
same at the expense of the owner, person in charge or other person responsible
therefor, which sum may be first advanced by the village of Creve Coeur, and
recovered in a civil action against said owner, person in charge or responsible
party, whether or not said owner, person in charge or responsible party was
aware of the existence of the incurrence of said charge or expense, or not.
(Ord. 258-A, 10-13-2004)
8-5-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating or aiding in the violation of this chapter shall pay a
penalty therefor in the sum of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for the first
violation, fifty dollars ($50.00) for any second violation, and the sum of
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the third and each successive
violation in a twelve (12) month period. Each day a person fails to comply with
or violates any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 258-A, 10-13-2004)
CHAPTER 6
EXCAVATIONS
SECTION:
8-6-1: Permit Required
8-6-2: Drains; Permit to Change; Fill
8-6-3: Barricades
8-6-4: Bonds
8-6-5: Issuance of Permits
8-6-6: Permit Fee
8-6-7: Notice of Improper Work
8-6-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to open, excavate or dig in any street,
alley or public thoroughfare in the Village without first procuring a permit
for such work from the Commissioner of Streets, and the furnishing of a
suitable bond, based on the faithful performance of all rules and regulations
prescribed pertaining to such work, including the backfill with sand and the
repaving of such street, in the manner as directed by said Commissioner.
8-6-2: DRAINS; PERMIT TO CHANGE; FILL:
It shall be unlawful for any person to change, alter, fill or deposit debris or
other object in any drain, or to interfer with any drain by construction or use
of a driveway, without first obtaining a permit for such work from the
Commissioner of Streets, specifying in detail, the exact nature of any such
work and such work so specified shall then be performed or constructed in
accordance with such permit.
8-6-3: BARRICADES:
All openings, excavations or other diggings shall be adequately barricaded and
well lighted with stormproof lights, from sunset to sunrise and all backfill
shall be made with sand, properly compacted and resurfaced with materials of
like kind and quality, to be approved by the Commissioner of Streets.
8-6-4: BONDS:
Bonds shall be furnished by the person to the approval of the Commissioner of
Streets, based on the full and proper compliance with this Chapter and to
indemnify the Village against all loss or damage the Village may suffer or
sustain by reason of improperly performing the work or from loss or damages
caused by reason of injury to a member of the public which said bond shall be
not less than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), or such additional sum as the
Street Commissioner may deem appropriate.
8-6-5: ISSUANCE OF PERMITS:
Permits shall be issued and the same shall be conspicuously posted at the sight
of any such work. Such permit shall be issued under the signature of the
Commissioner of Streets, and bear the name and address of the person to whom
issued, and shall state the expiration date.
8-6-6: PERMIT FEE:
The permit fee for such permit shall be one dollar ($1.00) to be paid to the
Commissioner of Streets.
8-6-7: NOTICE OF IMPROPER WORK:
Any work improperly performed shall be corrected within twenty four (24) hours
after notice given by the Street Commissioner, and unless corrected within said
time, the Village may complete such work and look to the bondsmen to make
compensation therefor, without further notice or demand whatsoever. (Ord. 245,
11-17-57)
CHAPTER 7
DRIVEWAYS
SECTION:
8-7-1: Permission Required to Cut Curbing
8-7-2: Culverts Required for Certain Driveways
8-7-1: PERMISSION REQUIRED TO CUT CURBING:
   (A)   No person shall cut any curbing nor construct or use any driveway over
any curbing, where curbings are provided, along any street or highway in the
Village, unless permission or approval thereof is first obtained from the State
Highway Department, where they have jurisdiction, and approval by the street
foreman and the Building Inspector.
   (B)   No person shall cut, install or construct any driveway over, upon, or
through any curbing along State Bond Issue Route No. 24 (State Route 29), in
the Village without permission in writing and compliance with the requirements
of the State Division of Highways, and also with the approval and consent of
the street foreman and the Building Inspector. (Ord. 235A, 11-9-88)
8-7-2: CULVERTS REQUIRED FOR CERTAIN DRIVEWAYS:
   (A)   No driveway shall be installed within the Village across any manmade
or natural drainage ditch or waterway lying within a public right of way or
being adjacent to a dedicated public roadway unless a culvert is first
installed by the Village in the driveway in accordance with the provisions of
this Section.
   (B)   Any person desiring to install a driveway requiring such a culvert
shall first contact the Village Street Superintendent. The Village Street
Superintendent shall estimate the cost of labor and material to the Village for
installing the necessary culvert and shall require the property owner to
deposit with the Village the amount of such estimate.
   (C)   All such culverts shall be installed by the Village using material
furnished by the Village, subject to the Village's right of reimbursement from
the property owner.
   (D)   Following installation of such culvert, the Village shall refund any
excess monies deposited with the Village to the property owner and the property
owner shall pay to the Village any additional monies which are required to
fully reimburse the Village for the cost of labor and material relating to such
installation.
   (E)   All culverts shall be of materials specified by and installed in
accordance with section 511 of the current edition of the "Standard
Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction of the Illinois Department of
Transportation".
   (F)   All culverts required pursuant to this Section shall have a minimum
diameter of twelve inches (12") or such larger diameter as is required by the
Village Street Superintendent in order to insure adequate drainage through the
ditch or waterway.
   (G)   All culverts required by this Section shall be at least ten feet (10')
longer than the width of the drive served by the culvert; provided, however,
that no such culvert shall be less than twenty two feet (22') in length.
   (H)   The invert elevation of any culvert required by this Section shall be
a minimum of one foot, six inches (1'6") below the edge of any adjacent roadway
and two feet, zero inches (2'0") below the center of any adjacent roadway.
(Ord. 504, 4-24-86)
CHAPTER 8
PUBLIC BENCHES
SECTION:
8-8-1: Purpose Declared
8-8-2: Permit
8-8-3: Time of Permit
8-8-4: Fees
8-8-5: Renewal
8-8-6: Permit Agreements
8-8-7: Denial or Cancellation of Permit
8-8-8: Hearing
8-8-9: Fee Refund
8-8-10: Bench Requirements
8-8-11: Suits; Bonds
8-8-12: Notice of Claim
8-8-13: Renewal of Permit
8-8-1: PURPOSE DECLARED:
For the convenience of the public, it shall hereafter be lawful for individuals
or corporations to install and maintain benches located upon public property of
the Village for the accommodation of passersby or persons awaiting
transportation, and to place advertising matter and signs upon said benches,
subject to the following regulations, limitations and qualifications.
8-8-2: PERMIT:
No such bench shall be installed or maintained without a permit obtained from
the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee as hereafter provided. The Chairman
of Street and Alley Committee shall be vested with the administration and
enforcement of this Chapter and with the authority to issue all permits
hereunder, and he shall have power to make reasonable regulations for the
carrying out of the provisions hereof. An applicant for a permit hereunder,
shall submit his application to said Chairman of the Street and Alley
Committee, which application shall give the location of the proposed bench or
benches and such other information as the said Chairman of Street and Alley
Committee may, in his discretion, require. One application may be made for one
or more benches, and one permit may be issued for one or more benches;
provided, however, that a separate fee shall be paid as hereafter stipulated
for each bench. The public property of the Village on or by which such may be
installed shall include public thoroughfares, streets, and sidewalks.
8-8-3: TIME OF PERMIT:
The exclusive right and franchise to receive permits hereunder and to install
and maintain the benches hereunder for a period of five (5) years.
8-8-4: FEES:
Each application for a permit hereunder shall be accompanied by a fee of three
dollars ($3.00) for each bench. Where the permit is to be issued after July 1,
and a fee of three dollars ($3.00) where the permit is to be issued before July
1 in any year.
8-8-5: RENEWAL:
The person securing such permit shall renew the same by paying three dollars
($3.00) on the first day of each subsequent January, or within thirty (30) days
thereafter; provided, that if such permit covers more than one bench, three
dollars ($3.00) shall be paid annually as aforesaid, for each bench covered by
such permit. For failure to pay such sum, the permit may be revoked and the
bench removed, as provided in Section
8-8-6 hereof.
8-8-6: PERMIT AGREEMENTS:
By applying for a permit, the applicant agrees that he will maintain the bench
in safe and sightly condition and that he will post and maintain an
indemnifying bond and public liability insurance policy, as hereafter required.
Upon thirty (30) days written notice of any failing in such undertaking, if
such default be not remedied within such time, the Chairman of Street and Alley
Committee may revoke the permit and may remove and store the bench and he may
charge the cost of such removal and storage against the permittee, who has been
guilty of such default. The permittee may recover the bench if he pays such
cost within sixty (60) days after such removal.
8-8-7: DENIAL OR CANCELLATION OF PERMIT:
The application for a permit shall be denied or the permit canceled during the
following circumstances:
   (A)   If the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee finds either before or
after granting a permit, that the maintenance of a bench at the proposed
location would tend to obstruct passage along a public way, or to create a
hazard to persons traveling thereon, he shall deny the application.
   (B)   If the abutting property owners or owner of property within one
hundred feet (100') of any bench protests in writing that they will be or are
adversely affected by the maintenance of such bench, a Committee consisting of
the members of the Streets and Alley Committee of the Board of Trustees shall
hear their grievances, upon reasonable notice to the person maintaining such
bench. If, upon such hearing, a majority of such Committee find that any
protesting property owner suffers special damages to his property by reason of
the maintenance of such bench, the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee shall
deny the application, or if the application has been approved, the permit to
maintain such bench shall be rescinded and the permittee directed to remove the
same within thirty (30) days.
8-8-8: HEARING:
In any case where an application is submitted, the Chairman of Street and Alley
Committee shall act upon same within twenty (20) days and shall file his
approval or disapproval of the same with the Clerk provided that where it is
necessary to hold a hearing on any such application, the Chairman of Street and
Alley Committee may extend such time. When the application is disapproved, or
where any permits are rescinded, a brief statement for the reasons of such
action shall be filed by the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee with the
Clerk.
8-8-9: FEE REFUND:
If a bench is ordered removed hereunder where the permittee is not at fault,
the Village shall credit the fee by the permittee for such bench, during the
year such removal occurs, against any fees to become due hereunder thereafter
from such permittee to the Village. If an application is denied, the fee
submitted therewith shall be credited to the permittee making such application
upon any future fees to be due to the Village hereunder from such applicant.
8-8-10: BENCH REQUIREMENTS:
All benches placed hereunder shall conform to the following:
   (A)   No bench shall carry any advertisement or sign containing any immoral
picture or profane, vulgar, or obscene words, and only such advertising matter
shall be placed thereon as is ordinarily displayed by other advertising
mediums; nor shall a advertisement or sign on any such bench, or any other word
or words which might mislead or distract traffic.
   (B)   No bench shall be more than forty two inches (42") high, nor more than
two feet six inches (2'6") wide nor more than seven feet (7') long.
   (C)   Not more than two (2) benches may be maintained at any one location
without a special finding by the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee, that
the public convenience requires more than two (2) benches at such location.
Benches shall be located only at bus or street car stops. The permittee shall
inspect each bench periodically.
   (D)   No bench shall be maintained in any alley, nor at any location where
the distance from the face of the curb to the property line is less than ten
feet (10') unless the Chairman of Street and Alley Committee finds in his
written approval of the application that to maintain a bench at such location
is in the public interest.
   (E)   Advertising shall be displayed only on the front and rear surfaces of
the back rest.
   (F)   Creve Coeur merchants shall be given first opportunity to purchase
advertising.
8-8-11: SUITS; BONDS:
The permittee or person obtaining a permit hereunder shall defend at his own
expense, any litigation arising from the installation or maintenance of a bench
for which he has obtained any such permit. The permittee shall file his or its
individual bond to save the Village harmless from any damages or suit for
damages alleged to arise from the installation or maintenance of any bench.
Sureties on such bond are not required by evidence of public liability
insurance in the amounts hereafter stated shall be filed at or prior to the
time of filing application for each permit with the Chairman of Street and
Alley Committee:
 
Public Liability Insurance:
    For death or injury to one person     $15,000.00
    Total limit of liability, personal inj30,000.00
    Property Damage, not less than        1,000.00
 
One bond and one insurance policy may be filed to cover the maintenance of any
number of benches.
8-8-12: NOTICE OF CLAIM:
The Village shall immediately notify the permittee of any claim of which the
Village has notice where such claim arises from the installation or maintenance
of any bench installed hereunder.
8-8-13: RENEWAL OF PERMIT:
A permit once granted may be renewed annually by the permittee or his assigns
upon the payment of the fee herein described unless such permit has been
revoked or cancelled for cause. (Ord. 164, 9-17-47)
CHAPTER 9
TRAFFIC ON STREETS DURING CONSTRUCTION
SECTION:
8-9-1: Traffic Diverted
8-9-2: Entering From Private Drive
8-9-3: Violate Signs
8-9-4: Use Prior to Rolling Operations
8-9-1: TRAFFIC DIVERTED:
When any street, alley or highway in the Village is being oiled, tarred,
asphalted, repaired, graded, maintained, or is under construction, all traffic
may be prohibited or restricted on any such street, alley or highway; provided,
however, that any such closing or restriction shall not be effective unless
said street, alley or highway is either:
   (A)   Closed by proper barricades or other signs, placed at the entrances of
other streets, alleys or highways entering the closed portion; or
   (B)   Posted with suitable signs indicating the restriction at all public
entrances; or
   (C)   Controlled by a police officer, watchman or flagman supervising or
directing traffic.
8-9-2: ENTERING FROM PRIVATE DRIVE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon, along
or across any street, alley or highway, or to enter the same from a private
drive or entrance, when such street, alley or highway is closed or barricaded,
as heretofore provided.
8-9-3: VIOLATE SIGNS:
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive or operate any vehicle upon, along
or across any street, alley or highway, in violation of any directional or
regulatory sign, or direction of a policeman, watchman or flagman.
8-9-4: USE PRIOR TO ROLLING OPERATIONS:
No person shall drive or operate any vehicle over, across, along or upon any
street, alley or highway, nor enter the same from a private driveway or other
entrance, when such street, alley or highway has been freshly covered, in whole
or in part, with tar, asphalt or oil, prior to the application of aggregate, or
prior to rolling operations, if rolling or compacting operations are to follow,
while the street, alley or highway is under construction, maintenance or
repair. (Ord. 238, 6-20-56)
CHAPTER 10
PUBLIC PARKS, PLAYGROUNDS AND PAVILIONS
SECTION:
8-10-1: Public Park, Playground And Pavilion Regulations
8-10-1: PUBLIC PARK, PLAYGROUND AND PAVILION REGULATIONS:
   (A)   All parks, playgrounds and pavilions located upon public property or
dedicated to public use shall be open for the use and enjoyment of the general
public each day from six o'clock (6:00) A.M. until eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M.
   (B)   It shall be unlawful for any person to be present on the premises of
any park, playground or pavilion upon public property or dedicated to the
public use between eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
unless the hours for use of said facility have been lengthened by the village
board or other appropriate supervising agency and a public notice is posted to
said effect.
   (C)   No person shall have in his or her possession any alcoholic beverage
in any park, playground or other public property, except in the original
package and with the seal unbroken; unless the sale of alcoholic beverages at a
public facility has been approved for special events by the village board and a
public notice is posted to said effect.
   (D)   No person shall cause any improved roadways in any park, playground or
pavilion area to be closed, locked or barricaded at any time without prior
approval of the village board of trustees.
   (E)   A person convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ord. 575-A, 1-23-2002)
   (F)   Pavilion rental fee shall be established by the village board annually
and published in the office of the village clerk.
Beyond the fee, there is also a fully refundable deposit required, above and
beyond the rental fee, to ensure that the pavilion is left in the same
condition in which it was rented. The fully refundable deposit amount shall
also be established by the village board annually and published in the office
of the village clerk.
In the event the pavilion is left in need of cleanup, the full amount of the
deposit shall be charged to the renter and the deposit will be kept. In the
event the renter cleans up after their use of the pavilion, the deposit will be
returned within thirty (30) days of rental. (Ord. 806, 3-9-2016)
CHAPTER 11
CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN THE PUBLIC RIGHTS-OF-WAY
SECTION:
8-11-1: Purpose And Scope
8-11-2: Definitions
8-11-3: Annual Registration Required
8-11-4: Permit Required; Applications And Fees
8-11-5: Action On Permit Applications
8-11-6: Effect Of Permit
8-11-7: Revised Permit Drawings
8-11-8: Insurance
8-11-9: Indemnification
8-11-10: Security
8-11-11: Permit Suspension And Revocation
8-11-12: Change Of Ownership Or Owner's Identity Or Legal Status
8-11-13: General Construction Standards
8-11-14: Traffic Control
8-11-15: Location Of Facilities
8-11-16: Construction Methods And Materials
8-11-17: Vegetation Control
8-11-18: Removal, Relocation, Or Modification Of Utility Facilities
8-11-19: Cleanup And Restoration
8-11-20: Maintenance And Emergency Maintenance
8-11-21: Variances
8-11-22: Penalties
8-11-23: Enforcement
8-11-24: Severability
8-11-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
   (A)   Purpose: The purpose of this chapter is to establish policies and
procedures for constructing facilities on rights-of-way within the Village's
jurisdiction, which will provide public benefit consistent with the
preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the Village
rights-of-way and the Village as a whole.
   (B)   Facilities Subject To This Chapter: This chapter applies to all
facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the public
rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the Village. A facility lawfully
established prior to the effective date of this chapter may continue to be
maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently constructed and
located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise,
license or similar agreement.
   (C)   Franchises, Licenses, Or Similar Agreements: The Village, in its
discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a
franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their
facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the Village
rights-of-way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into such an
agreement may request that the Village enter into such an agreement. In such an
agreement, the Village may provide for terms and conditions inconsistent with
this chapter.
   (D)   Effect Of Franchises, Licenses, Or Similar Agreements:
      1.   Utilities Other Than Telecommunications Providers: In the event that
a utility other than a telecommunications provider has a franchise, license or
similar agreement with the Village, such franchise, license or similar
agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement and any
lawful renewal or extension thereof.
      2.   Telecommunications Providers: In the event of any conflict with, or
inconsistency between, the provisions of this chapter and the provisions of any
franchise, license or similar agreement between the Village and any
telecommunications provider, the provisions of such franchise, license or
similar agreement shall govern and control during the term of such agreement
and any lawful renewal or extension thereof.
   (E)   Conflicts With Other Chapters: This chapter supersedes all chapters or
parts of chapters adopted prior hereto that are in conflict herewith, to the
extent of such conflict.
   (F)   Conflicts With State And Federal Laws: In the event that applicable
Federal or State laws or regulations conflict with the requirements of this
chapter, the utility shall comply with the requirements of this chapter to the
maximum extent possible without violating Federal or State laws or regulations.
   (G)   Sound Engineering Judgment: The Village shall use sound engineering
judgment when administering this chapter and may vary the standards,
conditions, and requirements expressed in this chapter when the Village so
determines. Nothing herein shall be construed to limit the ability of the
