specified by the Plat Officer, but not to exceed one year. Property owners
signator of surety bonds, shall provide guaranteed evidence of their ownership
of real estate pledged and that it is free and clear of other obligations,
including the payments of real estate taxes and special assessments. The form
of said bonds and checks shall be approved to the satisfaction of the Village
Attorney and shall be made payable to the Village of Creve Coeur, Illinois, or
its benefit.
When approved, the final plat shall bear the following certificate:
   “STATE OF ILLINOIS )
      ) ss.
   County of Tazewell   )
   I,                    Village of Creve Coeur Plat Officer, do hereby approve
this Final Plat in accordance with the provisions of the Subdivision Ordinance
of the Village of Creve Coeur, Tazewell County, Illinois, this          day of
         , A.D.         .
                                            
   Creve Coeur Plat Officer.”
Within sixty (60) days after approval of the final plat by the Plat Officer,
said plat shall be filed by the subdivider with the County Recorder, and if not
so filed, shall have no validity and shall not thereafter be recorded without
recertification by the Plat Officer. All plats (original tracings of said
plats) after being recorded, shall become the property of the County, and kept
by them for safe keeping.
For the approval of any final plat, as hereinabove required, the subdivider
shall pay into the General Fund of the Village as a fee for such approval, the
sum of one dollar ($1.00) for each lot, sublot, tract or parcel of land shown
upon any plat to be approved as a subdivision, and provided, further, that the
said fee for the approval of any plat shall be not less than ten dollars
($10.00). In addition to said fees set forth above, the subdivider shall
reimburse the Village for all engineering expenses of checking plats, water,
sewer and other plans, specifications, data, contours and for inspection of
construction of the facilities required by this Title, and all legal fees in
connection with said subdivision or relating thereto or to checking titles,
bonds, financial matters or the like; all costs to be paid prior to final
approval of the plat. (Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
11-2-5: BOUNDARY MAPS:
Any parcel of land may be divided into two (2) parts, either of which part is
less than five (5) acres, for the purpose of ownership, transfer or building
development provided no new street or easement of access is required, by
submitting an adequate map, certified by a Licensed Illinois Land Surveyor.
Such boundary map shall bear the certification of the County Clerk that there
are no delinquent taxes and/or assessments against the land or parcel described
in the boundary plat or map.
Such boundary shall bear a certificate of approval, signed by the Plat Officer,
as follows:
   “STATE OF ILLINOIS )
      ) ss.
   County of Tazewell   )
   I,                   , Creve Coeur Plat Officer, do hereby approve the above
boundary map in accordance with the provisions of the Subdivision Ordinance of
Creve Coeur, Illinois, this       day of         , A.D.       .
                                            
   Creve Coeur Plat Officer.”
No such boundary map shall be recorded or have any validity until it has been
signed and approved by the Plat Officer. The Plat Officer shall file one copy
of such boundary map in his office, the Plat Officer shall make a record of
such map and he shall not sign another boundary map further dividing said land
within two (2) years of the date of the approval thereof. In addition, any such
boundary map must otherwise comply with zoning requirements, lot sizes and the
like, if for other than merely increasing one’s needed or desired lot size.
Any survey plat of a parcel of land, which parcel is not part of a subdivision
as defined for the purpose of this Title, shall be entitled to recording,
provided it shall be endorsed with the following certification, signed and
sealed by the Illinois Registered Land Surveyor preparing the plat: “I hereby
certify at this parcel of land is not part of a subdivision requiring Village
approval under the Subdivision Ordinance of the Village of Creve Coeur,
Illinois, designated as Ordinance No. 351.” The certificate shall be signed by
the Surveyor, with his Illinois Registration number and date. Any violation or
failure to strictly comply with this Title shall be basis for action against
such Surveyor. (Ord. 351, 10-1-69; amd. Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
11-3-1: General
11-3-2: Streets
11-3-3: Easements
11-3-4: Blocks
11-3-5: Lots
11-3-6: Parks, Public Sites and Open Spaces
11-3-1: GENERAL:
The following standards and principals of design shall guide the laying out of
subdivisions:
The design of the subdivision shall be in harmony with and shall conform with
the Comprehensive Plan and shall be in accordance with good subdivision design
principles not otherwise set forth herein.
Natural features, such as distinctive trees or vegetation, streams, ponds,
hilltops, bluffs, creek bottoms and outlook stations or views shall be
preserved and enhanced wherever possible. In laying out a subdivision due
consideration shall be given to aesthetic features existing within the tract
being subdivided and which may add to the aesthetic quality of existing nearby
subdivisions.
11-3-2: STREETS:
The course, width, grade and location of all streets shall conform to the
Comprehensive Plan and shall be considered in their relation to existing and
planned streets, to topographic conditions, to public convenience and safety,
and their appropriate relation to the proposed uses of land to be served by
such streets and they shall conform to the following design standards:
Where not shown on the Comprehensive Plan, the arrangement of streets in a
subdivision shall either:
   (A)   Provide for the continuation of projection of existing principal
streets in surrounding area; or
   (B)   Conform to Thoroughfare Plan where applicable; or
   (C)   Conform to topographic or other conditions where continuance or
projection of existing streets is impractical or undesirable from the community
standpoint.
Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by through traffic will be
discouraged.
All new subdivisions along State and County Highways shall be arranged to
provide direct access to such Highways at intervals not less than one thousand
three hundred twenty feet (1,320'), except where impractical or impossible due
to existing property divisions or topography or due to undue traffic
concentration at points of such access. Also, roads and streets within such
subdivision shall be arranged to permit access to adjacent future subdivisions
without encroachment upon this regulation.
No street grade shall be less than one-half of one percent (.5%). No street
grade on major streets shall be more than five percent (5%) and on minor
streets shall not exceed nine percent (9%).
   (A)   Street Intersections: Streets shall be laid out to intersect at nearly
as possible at right angles and no street shall intersect any other street at
less than seventy degrees (70°).
Street intersections with center line offsets of less than one hundred twenty
five feet (125') are prohibited.
   (B)   Horizontal Deflection of Street Lines: Where connecting street lines
deflect from each other more than ten degrees (10'), they shall be connected
with a curb with a radius adequate to assure sight distance.
A tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long shall be introduced between
reverse curves on major and collector streets, where the curve radius is less
than five hundred feet (500').
   (C)   Alleys should not be permitted in residential districts.
   (D)   Right-of-Way: Street right-of-way widths not shown in the
Comprehensive Plan should not be less than the following:
 
Collector Street              80 feet
Minor (direct access streets) 60 feet
Marginal Access Streets       40 feet
Alleys                        25 feet
 
In a subdivision that adjoins or includes an existing street that does not
conform to the right-of-way width required above, one-half (1/2) of the
additional width shall be provided along each side of such street for the
entire frontage included within the land being subdivided, or as the Plat
Officer may determine is proper.
Dead-End Streets, designed to be so permanently, shall not be longer than six
hundred feet (600'), unless limitation of the site by reason of topography or
existing development make impractical development except with a longer length.
They shall be provided with a circular turn around having an outside surface
diameter of at least one hundred feet (100'). The center of the turn around
shall be located between the center line of the street and its right-of-way
line, facing into the turn around.
All streets shall be public and dedicated to the Village.
Reserve strips controlling access to street right-of-way shall not be permitted
except upon approval of the Plat Officer and when control and disposition of
the reserved strip is vested in the Village.
   (E)   Street Names and Numbers: The continuation of an existing street shall
have the same name. The name of a new street shall not duplicate the name of an
existing street within the area. The name shall be submitted for approval by
the Village Board.
All lots within the subdivision shall be assigned street numbers in accordance
with the numbering system of the Village.
11-3-3: EASEMENTS:
Easements across lots for utilities, water course drainage ways, channels for
streams, where provided, shall not be less than ten feet (10') wide and shall
be adjacent to or centered on lot lines where practicable.
11-3-4: BLOCKS:
The length, width and shape of blocks shall be determined with regard to:
   (A)   Provision for adequate building sites for the special type of use
contemplated.
   (B)   Requirements as to lot size and dimensions.
   (C)   Needs for convenient access circulation, control and safety of street
traffic.
   (D)   Limitations and opportunities of topography.
In cases where the block length exceeds six hundred feet (600') and where
deemed essential by the Plat Officer to provide pedestrian circulation to
schools, playgrounds, shopping centers and other community facilities, a right-
of-way dedicated to the public use for a walk way not less than ten feet (10')
wide shall be provided and dedicated.
11-3-5: LOTS:
All provisions of the Zoning Ordinance (Title 10 of this Code) concerning lots
shall apply, including lot area, width, and depth. No parcel, remainder, gore,
outlot or remnant of land which is part of the tract being subdivided shall be
created which by reason of lot width, depth, area, frontage, topography, or
lack of access thereto, cannot be used as a zoning lot, or be subject to
further subdivision in accordance with the terms of this Title. Any remaining
parcel or outlot which cannot be made to comply with the foregoing shall be
eliminated by combining the area thereof with one or more adjoining lots which
do comply, or by conveying the same for appropriate public use, subject to
acceptance of the same by some public body.
The lot shape and orientation shall be appropriate for the location of the
subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated.
Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be avoided, except where
essential to provide separation or residential development from major streets
or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation.
Side lot lines shall be substantially at right angles or radial to street lines
except where topography or drainage conditions warrant angling lot lines, or
where turn arounds of a permanent type are required.
11-3-6: PARKS, PUBLIC SITES AND OPEN SPACES:
When a proposed park, playground or school is shown in the Comprehensive Plan,
or in the opinion of the Plat Officer is necessary for the public welfare, the
Plat Officer may require the reservation of the appropriate area, not to exceed
fifteen percent (15%) of the area within the subdivision. Upon the approval of
a final plat containing the reservation for such public use, the corporate
authorities having jurisdiction of such use, be it a school board, park board,
or other authority, shall acquire the land so designated by purchase, or
commence proceedings to acquire such land by condemnation, within one year from
the date of the filing of such plat; and if it does not do so, the land so
designated may then be used by the subdivider in any other manner consistent
with this Title and the Comprehensive Plan. (Ord. 351, 10-1-69)
CHAPTER 4
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
11-4-1: General
11-4-2: Monuments
11-4-3: Streets
11-4-4: Sanitary Sewers
11-4-5: Storm Sewers
11-4-6: Water
11-4-7: Storm Drainage
11-4-8: Underground Utilities
11-4-9: Modification
11-4-10: Inspection and Acceptance
11-4-11: Water and Sewer Fees
11-4-1: GENERAL:
It is recommended that no grading, tree removal, site work or installation of
any required improvements be commenced until the preliminary plat has been
approved.
All grading, site work or installation of any required improvements shall be
done in the manner as to prevent flooding, washing, erosion, silting, or other
impairment of adjacent properties, storm drainage channels, bodies of water or
adjoining streets.
No trees, tree stumps, brush or similar material shall be buried or used as
fill in any area of a subdivision to be traversed by a street or road.
11-4-2: MONUMENTS:
Monuments shall be placed under the direction of an Illinois Registered Land
Surveyor at all block corners, angle points, points of tangency of curves in
streets, and at such intermediate points as shall be required by the Plat
Officer. The monuments shall be of such material, size and length as may be
approved by the Plat Officer and in addition, monuments shall be indicated on
the plat that relate to other established monuments and those of adjoining
subdivisions shall be shown on the plat, naming such other established
subdivision.
11-4-3: STREETS:
Street improvement plans for streets (and alleys where provided) shall be
prepared by the subdivider's registered engineer and shall be submitted to the
Village Engineer for approval. Upon approval of the street improvement plans by
the Village Engineer, the streets and alleys shall be constructed by the
subdivider in accordance with such plan, under the supervision of the Village
Engineer, who shall certify the completion in accordance with the approved
plans.
All utilities under the paved portion of the streets shall be provided or
installed before surfacing of the streets, except where they may be installed
without disturbing the surface of the streets. Wherever possible, utilities
shall be installed so as not to require disturbing the street surface in
repairing, maintaining or servicing such utilities.
After the completion of the street improvements, the Village Engineer shall
inspect the same and submit a written report to the Village Board, stating
whether or not the streets are completed and ready for acceptance by the
Village.
The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with street signs erected at the
intersections of all streets.
Street Improvements: Street improvements shall be provided in each new
subdivision in accordance with standards and requirements described in the
following schedule:
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/819dbfb241f1dc7a386f9ceac0da4f9650e9957d/
IMAGES/0-0-0-2296.png]
Notwithstanding the requirements set forth above, no additional paved width,
curb, gutter, base course or surface shall be required on an existing improved
street which is a part of the state, county or township road system, where the
land being developed abuts said street. A sidewalk, however, shall be required
for the full frontage of the subdivision on collector streets. (Ord. 351, 10-1-
1969)
11-4-4: SANITARY SEWERS:
When the sanitary sewer system is conveniently available, the subdivider shall
connect the subdivision with that sanitary sewer or some other municipally
owned sanitary sewer system.
Under special conditions, the subdivider may be permitted to construct a
separate sanitary sewer system to serve the subdivision, provided he complies
with the requirements of the Illinois department of public health in the
construction of such sanitary sewer facilities, and upon the further direction
and recommendation of the village engineer. Upon satisfactory completion
thereof, the entire installation, mains, connectors, disposal plant and system
shall be turned over to the village or Creve Coeur sanitary district, who
shall, at no cost to either the village or district, be and become the owner in
fee and such municipality shall then be the operator thereof, together with all
easements, rights, lands and facilities. (Ord. 351, 10-1-1969)
11-4-5: STORM SEWERS:
Storm sewers, footing drains and downspouts shall not be connected with or to
any sanitary sewer. (Ord. 351, 10-1-1969)
11-4-6: WATER:
The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with a complete water supply
system which shall be connected to the village water supply or to that of some
other municipality. Under special difficulties a subdivider may provide an
independent water supply system approved by the Illinois department of public
health and on specifications and requirements of the village engineer. Upon the
completion of construction and acceptance thereof, the entire system, mains,
valves, hydrants, storage tanks, pumps, controls and the like, shall be turned
over to the village within one year, together with all easements, land or
rights, without cost to the village, and thereafter and upon acceptance
thereof, the village shall be the owner in fee of all said property and
facilities and shall thereafter operate and maintain said system. (Ord. 351,
10-1-1969)
11-4-7: STORM DRAINAGE:
The subdivider shall provide the subdivision with an adequate storm sewer
system and stormwater controls including submitting any necessary plans and
drawings in conformity with the village stormwater control ordinance as
described in section
10-14-15 of this code. Such system shall be designed by a registered,
professional engineer authorized to practice in this state. Such plans then
shall be submitted to and examined by the village engineer for approval,
correction or modification. (Ord. 351, 10-1-1969; amd. Ord. 661, 9-10-2008)
A storm sewer system shall be provided wherever curbs are installed, and where
the evidence available indicates to the plat officer that the natural surface
drainage is inadequate.
Where the surface drainage is deemed adequate, easements for such surface
drainage may be required to be obtained by the subdivider. (Ord. 351, 10-1-
1969)
All storm drainage facilities, land, easements and rights shall remain the
responsibility and property of the subdivision and shall not become the
property of the village, upon acceptance of the subdivision plat, and
thereafter the subdivision shall maintain and operate such systems unless the
village board specifically accepts ownership, responsibility and control of the
stormwater drainage facilities and easements. If the subdivision retains
responsibility for stormwater drainage facilities, land, and improvements, the
subdivider shall submit for approval and then record as part of the
restrictions for the subdivision provisions providing for the maintenance,
repair and replacement of the improvements and easements. If the subdivision
fails to keep the improvements maintained and in proper repair, the village may
make any necessary repairs, replacement and maintenance and may charge the
subdivider if the subdivider retains any interest in the subdivided property
and the owners of the lots in the subdivision. The subdivision plans submitted
for approval by the village engineer shall include any required plans for
erosion control required under section
10-14-15 of this code. (Ord. 661, 9-10-2008)
11-4-8: UNDERGROUND UTILITIES:
All utilities, electric, telephone, water, sewer, cablevision and all other
utilities, shall be placed underground or if such cannot reasonably be done in
the opinion of the village, then such installations so far as is possible,
shall be placed on easements at the rear of the lots or such other place as the
village engineer and plat officer determine to be necessary either because of
circumstances, topography or undue hardships. (Ord. 351, 10-1-1969)
11-4-9: MODIFICATION:
Where the subdivider can show that the strict application of a provision of
this chapter would cause undue hardship because of unusual topographical or
other physical conditions peculiar to the site, the Zoning Board, together with
the recommendations of the village engineer and plat officer, may authorize
minor modifications in the application of such provisions as, in their opinion
and for reasons set forth in minutes of the commission, will not materially
impair the intent of this title and subject, also, to approval of the village
board as provided for in chapter 6 of this title. (Ord. 351, 10-1-1969; amd.
Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
11-4-10: INSPECTION AND ACCEPTANCE:
The subdivider shall provide an Illinois registered engineer who shall be
responsible for inspecting all phases of construction to ensure compliance with
approved plans, general laws and construction procedures of the village. The
village engineer should be kept informed of construction developments and may,
at any time during construction, inspect the improvements. The developer's
engineer should allow no connections, backfilling or covering of critical areas
of construction without prior approval of the village engineer. The village
engineer, upon receipt of an acceptable certificate by the subdivider or
developer's engineer attesting to the compliance of construction, shall inspect
said construction and submit a written report to the village board stating
readiness for acceptance of the improvements. (Ord. 451, 6-7-1978)
11-4-11: WATER AND SEWER FEES:
A combined fee for sanitary sewer, storm sewer and water service shall be paid
by the subdivider or developer prior to connection to any existing mains,
trunks or other village facilities. This fee shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00) per lot except in the case of multiple-unit dwellings which shall be
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per unit. (Ord. 451, 6-7-1978)
CHAPTER 5
PLATS AND DATA
SECTION:
11-5-1: Plats and Data For Conditional Approval of Preliminary Plat
11-5-2: Topographic Data
11-5-3: Plats and Data For Final Approval
11-5-1: PLATS AND DATA FOR CONDITIONAL APPROVAL OF PRELIMINARY PLAT:
A preliminary plat of the subdivision shall be accurately drawn to a scale of
one hundred feet (100') to one inch (1").
11-5-2: TOPOGRAPHIC DATA:
The topographic data shall include the following information:
   (A)   Approximate boundary lines and lot lines.
   (B)   Existing Easements: Location, width and purpose, with ownership,
depth, etc.
   (C)   Existing Streets: On and adjacent to the tract by name, right-of-way
width, location, type, width and elevation of surfacing, curbs, gutters,
culverts and sidewalks, if any.
   (D)   Existing Utilities: On and adjacent to the tract; location, size and
invert elevation of sanitary sewers, storm sewers, and where existing, location
and size of water mains; location of gas mains; fire hydrants; electric and
telephone poles and street lights; if any of the above are not available at the
site, indicate the direction and distance to the nearest ones and furnish a
statement of availability.
   (E)   Other Existing Conditions; Water courses, marshes, wooded areas,
dwellings, buildings and other significant features.
   (F)   Ground Elevations: On tracts based on U.S.G.S. datum, show contours at
verticle intervals as follows:
Slope of six percent (6%) or less -- two foot (2') intervals;
Slope over six percent (6%) but less than fifteen percent (15%) -- five foot
(5') intervals;
Slope over fifteen percent (15%) -- ten foot (10') intervals.
   (G)   Title and Certificates: Present tract designation; title under which
subdivision is to be recorded names and addresses of owners, acreage, scale,
North point; datum, benchmarks; relation to other known monuments; certificate
of registered land surveyor and date of survey.
The preliminary plat shall show all existing conditions required above in
topographic data and all proposals, including, but not limited to the
following:
   (A)   Streets: Names, right-of-way width, approximate grade and gradients;
   (B)   Lots: Lot lines, numbers and block numbers;
   (C)   Sites (Public): If any, to be dedicated or reserved for parks,
playgrounds, schools, churches or other public uses, showing the approximate
acreage of each site;
   (D)   Sites (Non-Public): If any, for shopping centers, churches, industry,
multi-family dwellings or any other non-public use including indication of
proposed use, showing approximate acreage of each site;
   (E)   Setback Lines: Give location of minimum setback lines.
   (F)   Other Preliminary Plans: When required by the Village Engineer the
preliminary plat shall be accompanied by profiles showing existing ground
surface and proposed street grades; typical cross-sections of the streets and
sidewalks.
   (G)   Zoning: Show zoning classifications of the subdivision and adjacent
areas.
11-5-3: PLATS AND DATA FOR FINAL APPROVAL:
The final plat shall meet the following specifications:
The final plat may include all or only a part of the area of the preliminary
plat as proposed in the application.
The original drawing of the final plat of the subdivision shall be eighteen
inches by twenty four inches (18" x 24"), or larger in six inch (6") multiples.
It shall be drawn to a scale of one hundred feet (100') to the inch. Four (4)
black or blue line prints shall be submitted with the final plat.
The following information shall be shown on the final plat:
   (A)   Land reference concurs in accordance with State Plat Act, to which all
dimensions, angles, bearings and similar data on the final plat shall be
referred.
   (B)   Tract boundary lines, right-of-way lines of streets, easements and
other right-of-way, and property lines or residential lots and other sites;
with accurate dimensions, bearings of deflection angles, and radii, arcs, and
central angels of all curves;
   (C)   Names of east street or other rights-of-way;
   (D)   Location and right-of-way widths or existing and/or platted streets
adjacent to the tract;
   (E)   Location and dimensions of all easements;
   (F)   Consecutive numbers for each lot or site within all subdivisions
having the same name or extensions, or the like;
   (G)   Purpose for which sites, other than residential lots, are dedicated or
reserved;
   (H)   Minimum setback line on all lots and other sites;
   (I)   Location and descriptions of monuments;
   (J)   Reference to recorded subdivision plats of adjoining platted land,
designating the name thereof;
   (K)   Certification by Illinois Registered Land Surveyor as to the accuracy
of survey and plat;
   (L)   Statement by subdivider dedicating streets, or rights-of- way,
reserving easements and any other sites for dedication or conveyance to the
public uses;
   (M)   Title, scale, North arrow, and date;
   (N)   Other data including such certificates, affidavits, endorsements or
dedications as may be required by applicable codes, ordinances and/or statutes
pertaining to zoning, dedicated streets, utilities and drainage facilities.
A certificate by the Plat Officer certifying that the subdivider has posted a
good and sufficient bond with the Village Clerk in a penal sum sufficient to
cover the estimate by a qualified engineer and approved by the Village Engineer
of the probable expenditures necessary to enable the subdivider to conform with
the standards of construction established pursuant to the provisions of this
Title. The bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful adherence to the rules
and regulations contained in this Title and within the time specified.
Protective covenants in form of recording.
Street and utility improvement plans shall be submitted and approved before the
final plat is approved. (Ord. 351, 10-1-69)
CHAPTER 6
MODIFICATION
SECTION:
11-6-1: General
11-6-2: Large Scale Development
11-6-3: Action by Village Board
11-6-4: Appeals
11-6-1: GENERAL:
Where, on appeal, the Zoning Board finds that extra-ordinary hardships may
result from strict compliance with this Title, it may recommend to the Village
Board a modification of the regulations so that substantial compliance and
justice may be done and the public interest secured; provided, that such
modification will not have the effect of nullifying the purpose of the
Comprehensive Plan, nor be a change that others may take generally, nor
otherwise violate this Title. (Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
11-6-2: LARGE SCALE DEVELOPMENT:
The standards and requirements of this Title may be modified by the Zoning
Board in the case of a plan or a program for a planned development for the
Village, or a neighborhood unit, which in the judgment of the Zoning Board
shall exceed the minimum requirements for adequate public space and
improvements for circulation, recreation, light, air and service needs of the
tract when fully developed and populated and which also provides such covenants
or other legal provisions as will assure conformity to the purpose of the
Comprehensive Plan. (Ord 962, 10-26-2022)
11-6-3: ACTION BY VILLAGE BOARD:
In recommending modifications wherever provided for in this Title, the Zoning
Board may prescribe such conditions, as will, in its judgment, secure
substantially the objectives of the standards or requirements so modified. The
recommendations of a modification by the Zoning Board shall be conditional and
shall be subject to final approval of the Village Board. (Ord 962, 10-26-2022)
11-6-4: APPEALS:
Whenever a subdivider is aggrieved by the decision of the Plat Officer with
regard to a final plat, he may file an appeal to the Village Board from such
decision within ten (10) days of the date thereof; such appeal shall be filed
with the Village Clerk and by him forwarded immediately to the Zoning Board for
their recommendation for action by the Village Board. The Village Board shall
hold a hearing and may affirm or reverse, in whole or in part, the decision of
the Plat Officer, and in that instance shall have all the powers and duties of
the Plat Officer, including the right to modify such order. (Ord. 351, 10-1-69;
amd. Ord. 962, 10-26-2022)
CHAPTER 7
ENFORCEMENT; PENALTIES
SECTION:
11-7-1: Enforcement
11-7-2: Penalties
11-7-3: Policy
11-7-1: ENFORCEMENT:
The Village President, with the concurrence of the Village Board, shall appoint
the Plat Officer who shall serve at the pleasure of said Board. They shall fix
his salary. No officer so designated by the Board as its Plat Officer shall
engage, either directly or indirectly in the business of surveying, and no map,
plat, or subdivision shall be received for record, nor shall the same have any
validity, which has been prepared by or under the direction of any such Plat
Officer in violation of the provisions of this Section.
11-7-2: PENALTIES:
No map, plat or subdivision shall be entitled to record in the County or have
any validity until it has been approved by the Village Board in accordance with
the provisions of this Title.
Whenever it comes to the knowledge of the Plat Officer that any provisions of
this Title have been violated, it shall be his duty to notify the Village
Attorney of this fact; furnishing all pertinent information and report of the
matter, and the Village Attorney shall then take appropriate action to enforce
this Title or effect compliance therewith.
11-7-3: POLICY:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the Village Board, in adopting this
Title to provide for the health, welfare and orderly development of the
Village, and as such this Title is necessary in the interest of the public
benefit, health and welfare. (Ord. 351, 10-1-69)
